39057992.review:
Guacamelee is a colorful metroidvania styled platformer reminiscent of the older Super Metroid and Castlevania games. If you enjoyed playing these games chances are you will enjoy Guacamelee.

Pros:
+Beautiful Mexican themed world that feels unique.
+Responsive controls so no frustration.
+Great combo system which allows you to chain together combos easily.
+Easily earned currency in game which you can use to upgrade stats or change wardrobe to gain certain bonuses.
+Learning curve for the game isn't hard.
+Unique bosses to fight throughout the story.
+Pollo Power!, Yes you can turn into a fighting chicken.

Cons:
-Game can be a bit on the easy side since difficulty doesn't really come from the enemies but rather traversing obstacles and solving environmental puzzles.
-Game can be a little short especially for those only concerned with playing through the story. However if achievement hunting you could possibly get some more hours of gameplay.

38971073.review:
[h1] Introdução	[/h1]

Guacamelee! STCE é a versão definitiva de "Guacamelee", trazendo ajustes, novas fases e chefe e alguns elementos da jogabilidade. Trata-se de um Metroidvania com elementos de beat 'em up tendo o folclore mexicano como tema. Nele controlamos Juan, um aldeão que sonhava em ser um luchador, que é morto pelo vilão Carlos Calaca, um esqueleto que deseja usar a filha de El Presidente num ritual que fundirá os mundos dos vivos e dos mortos, para que ele governe sobre todos. No mundos dos mortos, Juan é escolhido pela máscara de um lendário luchador e retorna para enfrentar Carlos.


[h1] Jogabilidade	[/h1]

Guacamelee! STCE funciona como todo metroidvania. Um jogo 2D de plataforma com um vasto mundo aberto cujas "fases"desbloqueiam à medida que o jogador adquire as habilidades necessárias para alcançar novas localidades, como pulo duplo, escalada e até voo. Seu grande diferencial se dá pelo sistema de combate, um puro beat 'em up cheio de golpes e combos incrivelmente divertido com movimentos típicos de lucha libre. Um poder que permite transitar entre os dois mundos cria um fator chave no jogo e em seu sistema de transição entre as fases e solução de puzzles e missões. Há ainda o medidor "muy macho", uma espécie de modo berseker e uma das novidades desta versão do jogo.
Guacamelee! STCE pode ainda ser jogado por até 4 players, e possui uma variedade grande de skins que conferem habilidades aos personagens (Juan e Tostada), além de suporte para as skins criadas na Oficina Steam.
Seus pontos fracos, são dois. O primeiro, o jogo é muito curto, podendo ser facilmente concluído em menos de 10 horas.
E o segundo, a forma como se apresentam os bloqueios de caminho do mapa. 90% deles se resumem a pedras coloridas que só podem ser quebradas por uma habilidade de mesma cor. Isso tira um bocado do desafio, pois, ao invés de precisar descobrir como passar, qual habilidade nova irá permitir que você prossiga, a informação está lá desde o começo. 

[h1] Visual	[/h1]

A arte de Guacamelee! STCE é simplesmente fantástica. Sprites grandes, coloridos e muito bem animados, uma arte que combina o estilo cartunesco dos anos 2000 com a própria arte mexicana e aqui um destaque para este elemento. Os cenários, os NPCs, inimigos e todo o mais são cultura mexicana pura. A ambientação é perfeita, bela. Vilarejos, templos antigos, e até mesmo uma ilha de bonecas estão presentes. O jogo ainda faz inúmeras referências a jogos famosos nos diversos cartazes espalhados pelo seu mundo.

[h1] Som	[/h1]

O grande destaque sonoro vai completamente a trilha sonora, que assim como o visual, encorpora perfeitamente o folclore e a cultura mexicana. Música tradicional do México, e muito bem reproduzida, com uma versão normal e uma versão "Mundo de los Muertos" para cada faixa. Para quem aprecia folk, vale MUITO a pena comprar a trilha sonora do jogo.

[h1] Em suma...	[/h1]

Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition é um jogo demasiado divertido. Um metroidvania muito bem construído com um sistema de combate divertido e empolgante. Desafiador na medidade certa, com personagens carismáticos e um conteúdo robusto de cultura e folclore mexicano. A falta de criatividade nos bloqueios de caminho do jogo pode ser algo negativo, mas, não ofusca o brilho desta obra, ela apenas poderia ser ainda melhor. Seu único problema mesmo é ser curto, mas, o elemento multiplayer e o desejo de completar o 100% do jogo podem manter aceso o desejo de um replay.


[h1] NOTA	[/h1]
✫✫✫✫

It's a very beautiful game.

It has an incredible concept based in the idealization of Mexican culture, the whole game plays like a fantastical tale from old times, the characters, and universe, are fantastic, the story is interesting, and filled with charm.

The aesthetic, and, or, art style, is beautiful, and distinctive, incredibly colorful, and goes perfectly well with the themes that this games deals with.

The game design its fantastic, incredibly simple, and straightfoward, yet intelligent, and with a lot of depth.

The puzzles, platforming, and combat systems, and areas, are fantastic, different, and enjoyable to play through.

The game also has great replayability with upgrades, secrets, and different endings to achieve.

It might also be one of the few "metroidvanias" that I like because it actually gives you a general idea to which area you need to go next.

It is a very intuitive, casual, yet deep, intelligent, and beautiful game.

Totally recommend it.

38264383.review:
Решил я всё-таки купить Super Turbo Championship Edition спустя более года с прохождения золотого издания и не пожалел. Игра действительно расширилась. Если память мне не изменяет, в игру было добавлено целых две больших локации и ещё всякие мелочи. Слишком давно я играл в оригинал, чтобы вспомнить всё, чего там не было.

Вообще Guacamelee! - очень даже хорошая метроидвания. У игры очень правильная продолжительность (около 10 часов), способностей у главного героя предостаточно, противники более-менее разнообразы и требуют разного подхода. Игра имеет мексиканский колорит, что придаёт ей шарму. Из минусов отмечу не очень плавное управление (не столь критично) и бесящее падение героя после каждого удара.

В общем, Guacamelee! даёт всё, что требуется от Метроидвании, не вызывая при этом особого разачарования и раздражения. Второе прохождение игры (после первого на Gold Edition) вызвало больше положительных эмоций, особенно тем, что удалось без обращения к интернету достичь истинной концовки. Если у вас есть Gold Edition и вы сомневаетесь в покупке Super Turbo Championship Edition, ждите скидок и покупайте. Лично я не пожалел о приобретении, особенно учитывая, что оригинал достался мне в составе Humble Indie Bundle.

Всем любителям метроидваний рекомендую.

38105731.review:
以14小時來完成這個遊戲, 有以下感想:
1. 動作遊戲來說, 不是很難但是也不容易, 有時要試十數次才能過關.
2. 遊戲畫面也算美觀, 以小型遊戲來說算不錯.
3. 這款遊戲有一個好設定, 就是當跌落遊戲活動範圍外, 會在最後的位置重新來過, 因為這樣可以減少不斷重覆的"跳跳". 有時在難度高的關卡, 要重新來過真的讓人很失望.
4. 以石頭頭像來傳送不同地點位置, 若果隨時可以用位置轉移的功能便更好.
5. 遊戲中只有一個儲存檔, 有時想從某一個位置重新遊戲,也沒有方法.
6. 投擲功能有點沒有實際作用, 除了擲仙人掌外, 就只有捉雞和蟹的小遊戲才用到.
7. 最後首腦有點難度, 本人也要回去找未開啟的寶箱升級, 才能打敗它.
8. 有一個很多玩家也不清楚的問題, 就是不知道SUPER TURBO版本和GOLD版本有甚麼分別.也不知道玩那一個版本才對.

結論:
1. 2D動作遊戲, 若果以這遊戲般的"高難度跳躍", 是遊戲中可得到樂趣的最大阻礙, 很多類似的"跳跳"遊戲, 也讓人不能快樂地完成遊戲. 因為很多也是以反應來過關, 而並非考驗用甚麼方法去過關.
2. 這遊戲的打擊感也很好, 至少讓人有在攻擊的感覺.
3. 建議"跳跳"遊戲可以在最後跳躍失敗的位置重新來過, 因為不斷重覆沒有意義的跳躍, 對遊戲的耐玩性可能成反比(因為不是每個人也會喜歡重覆一個關卡十數次來玩). 本人也說過遊戲太難, 不是"玩家"玩"遊戲", 而是"遊戲設計師"玩"玩家".

37988625.review:
Guacameleeee!!! SuperTurboChampionshipEdition!

What a blast this game is, I can't seem to get enough of it! At first from the aesthetic, I wouldn't be able to enjoy this title. But, after having been given a lengthy run, I will say that it's pretty good. It is fun. It is fair. It is progressively rewarding.

It's a metroidvania title with a luchador theme, which is an odd mix but if you disregard the theme and take the game as the former then you may like it.

However, after delving more hours into this game, I must warn any player that this game is one of those demanding games that requires a player's peak performance. There will be platformer parts where you're going to die at before getting it right. In fact, you're probably going to die a lot in this game whether you're good or not. Trial and Error is part of it's genre and that's present in this game.

Which is unfortunate considering how much fun you begin to have about from the beginning into midway of the game. Then the brakes just seem to halt and skid before taking a dip in the later part. It's understandable as to why because of progression, but there comes a point where there's hard and then there's ridiculous hard. This game can go from hard to ridiculously hard mainly with the timing mechanics and even some of the enemies in the game. Also, the final boss is really no push over, so that's a heads up for you as to what to expect  out of him when you do finally reach him.

As for version recommendation, there are two versions of this game to pick from. I got both Gold and STCE. Go with STCE, because there's more content packed in, some tweaks done, a little more refined work put into the game and a couple bonus areas.

I'd still recommend the game under the basis, despite it's hardassery in difficulty, because the game does play fair. There's no game over screen being thrown at you that wastes your time. There's no exaggerated death animations you have to watch over and over. There's none of that to be found here, you simply hit a bunch of spikes and you're warped back to the last spot you were at. So, you can't say that this game is Contra-hard, but it's a little up there.

Go suplex some skeletons and give those winged beasts some piledrivers!

Hello there. I bought this great looking game due to the positive reviews and the fact that I like 2D action games such as Dead Cells and Ori. Usually I am not afraid of ingame challenges, but this game has started to really upset me due to the combination of bad controls, very challenging jumping sequences and unfair mob AI. I will try to sum up my personal pros and cons below.

Pros:
+ great music (at start)
+ funny main character
+ possible co-op
+ nice graphics and design
+ stable game (so far)
+ fair price and content

Cons:
- very annoying music (might be due to the countless retries...)
- several try & error jumping sequences
- unfair enemy mobs (e.g. shielded enemies hid in corners stacked up on each other)
- inaccurate and overloaded controls (makes fights and agility sequences very hard)

At the time of writing I had to give up mid-game and I am not sure, if I will give this game another chance...

游戏是典型的2D横版过关动作游戏，类银河战士恶魔城标签，支持本地4人合作，娱乐性会提高不少。没有中文，但影响不大，任务地点都会标注在地图上，到达目的地随即触发剧情，跑图过程中会多次碰到伪装成山羊的老巫师，授予你新的能力，使用不同的能力来冲破阻碍道路的不同颜色的石障。随着游戏进展，难度会呈指数增长，在学习了阴阳切换技能后，频繁需要你多种能力技能完美衔接来跑图，容错率较低，一旦失误 ，重新来过[spoiler] 简直丧心病狂:)	[/spoiler]好在保存点比较多，又没有生命数限制，不建议键盘游玩  [spoiler] 你们会抓狂的:)	[/spoiler]。
建议购买人士：银河战士恶魔城类游戏玩家（不过相信你们应该都有了！）Platform类爱好者
不建议购买人士：路痴及手残玩家
+迷之墨西哥元素 +各种彩蛋 +阴阳切换机制
+整体艺术水平和执行力 +别出心裁的打击感设计 +能力构造出的连击系统丰富
-BOSS设计 -关卡设计
如此多的要素使得本作成为一部无比绝伦的优秀作品！[spoiler] 即使原价也绝对值得入手	[/spoiler]

36911000.review:
If you're wondering if this game is worth buying or not, just buy it already!

I first played Guacamelee Gold Edition in Normal Mode, and thought it was awesome.
Then I played it again in Hard mode for the achievements, and enjoyed it very much.

When Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship edition came out, I had my doubts if it was worth, for someone who had already beaten Guacamelee Gold Edition twice, with 100% conclusion... but now, I tell you: IT IS!!!

This version of Guacamelee improved what was hard to improve. Added more characters, scenes, enemies, skill, maps, all while exploring Tostada's past and telling her story (!).

This new version gave me several new hours of gameplay, and got me and my girlfriend so hooked that we played Normal Mode and Hard mode on my steam, and are planning on doing it in hers, too (we also already bought it for her account!).

That's how good this game is. I'm seriously expecting a sequel in the future. Games of this level surely deserve.

36559458.review:
[h1]Review zu Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition[/h1]

GUACAAAMELEEEEE! SUUUUPPPEEERR TURBO CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION!
Und so schreit dich das Spiel beim Starten an. Es zeigt schon von Anfang an, welche Art von Spiel man sich da gekauft hat. Eines das sich selbst nicht ernst nimmt und es dem Spieler unter die Nase reibt.
Ich muss ernsthaft gestehen, dass ich ursprünglich höhere Erwartungen an Guacamelee hatte. Ich habe einst von diesem Spiel gehört, nachdem es als "eines der besten unbekannten Metroidvania" betitelt wurde. Tja, da hab ich wohl meine Erwartungen zu hoch geschraubt. Versteht mich nicht falsch, das Spiel ist gut, hat jedoch so seine Macken.
Besonders lobend möchte ich noch den Humor des Spiels erwähnen. Dieser wird nicht jedermanns Sache sein, aber mindestens eine kleines Schmunzeln wird wohl für jeden drin sein!

Kommen wir für die Schnellen unter uns einfach mal zur Pro-Contra-Liste:

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]

+ Stimmiger Soundtrack mit lateinamerikanischem Flair
+ Koop vorhanden
+ Der Humor des Spiels ist stellenweise echt lustig und manche Charaktere sind einfach nur zum Schießen. Verraten möchte ich da jetzt nichts.
+ sehr kurze Ladezeiten
+ Diverse Anspielungen auf andere Videospiele, Filme und Serien. Da wären z.B Super Mario, Metroid, How I met your Mother, Star Wars etc. (Ich habe bestimmt noch nicht alle entdeckt!
+ Das Kampsystem ist erschlagend! Es fühlt sich einfach nur großartig an Skelette zu verdreschen!

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]

- deutsche Übersetzung ist fehlerhaft
- Falls die V-Sync aus ist, so gibt es ein kleines Flackern auf der horizontalen Achse des spielbaren Juans. Irgendwie nervig und mit nur 60 FPS möchte ich nicht spielen...
- Selbst wenn ich mit dem GamePad spiele werden mir manche Tasten der Steuerung noch als Tastaturvariante angezeigt. Zu finden auf der Karte.
- Es gibt eine Gegnerart, die Knochen auf dich wirft. Sollte man gegen eine überschaubare Anzahl von Gegnern kämpfen so kann man diese gut sehen und auch entsprechend ausweichen, doch in manchen Stellen des Spiels ist dies einfach zu penetrant... Überall riesige Gegner, kleine, schnelle und diese roten Skelette die einen mit Knochen abwerfen... Irgendwann ist es ja dann wohl mal genug oder?

[u][b]Prontra:[/b][/u]

+- Durch den Skelettshop renne ich am Anfang des Spiels gefühlt jede Minute hindurch. Liegt allerdings daran, dass dies die Speichermethode des Spiels ist. Dennoch irgendwie nervig, da dann das Spiel für Bruchteile einer Sekunde stoppt. Jedoch sind die Checkpoints sehr fair platziert, selbst im letzten Teil des Spiels.
+- Die Symbole auf der Karte sind mir zu groß.
+- Die Bosslebensanzeige ist in der vorherigen Cutscene, oder Diskussion wenn man so will oben einsehbar und nimmt einfach die Spannung, ob man einem Boss gleich gegenüberstehen muss oder nicht. Sehr schade eigentlich...
+- Sollte man von einem Gegner getroffen werden, so ist die [i]Knockoutzeit[/i] (nennen wir sie jetzt einfach mal so) deutlich zu lang. Man wird sogar richtig zurückgestoßen. Heißt man wird dermaßen bestraft, wenn man in einem Raum voller Gegner mal getroffen ist, was für normale Menschen ansich eigentlich kaum unversehrt möglich ist.
+- Die Fähigkeiten, die man sich im Laufe des Spiels erwirbt, um neue Gebiete zu erkunden, sind irgendwie einfallslos, aber was will man anderes erwarten, wenn man mit seinen Fäusten, Füßen und seinem Kopf kämpft... Die Fähigkeiten sind halt eigentlich nur diejenigen, dass man verschiedenfarbige Blöcke zerstören kann. Naja.
+- Steuerung könnte manchen etwas zu fummlig sein, aber wie sagt man so schön? Übung macht den Meister!

Ich kann das Spiel also empfehlen. Habe mir persönlich mehr Fähigkeiten gewünscht um mehr Abwechslung zu garantieren, aber dennoch ist Guacamelee ein Spiel, dass definitiv von jemandem mal gespielt werden sollte, dem das Metroidvaniagenre liegt! Der Normalpreis von 13,99€ ist ansich in Ordnung und ein sehr fairer Preis!

Ich danke fürs Lesen und wünsche sehr viel Spaß beim Spielen! ;-)

http://store.steampowered.com/app/275390/Guacamelee_Super_Turbo_Championship_Edition/

36503109.review:
Started this expecting a Metroidvania as a brawler, and it is. The metroidvania elements are pretty bad though, felt pretty linear and was always guided where to go.
However, this is some fantastic combat. Feels somewhat similar to a Smash Bros game, and you know we don't get that Subspace Emissary anymore. Very simple combat commands, all are just a single direction+a button, and they all have great crowd controls, throws, and can chain them easily. Only problem I would have is dodging enemies is too easy, felt like I was a psycho just mindlessly attacking everyone. Enemies lose their attack animation when you attacked them, so once you get that first punch in, it becomes easy. There's lots of gigantic guys where this is not the case, but it's still too easy to dodge them. Maybe this problem is solved on hard, but overall the enemies themselves are lacking in AI and attacks.
The setting is great, but the music is very lacking. It's not bad, but it feels like there were only 5 songs the entire game.
This game is great, but I hope the sequel expands on all it's shortcomings. The potential is all there.

36502372.review:
[h1]타코맛 매트로배니아 게임[/h1]

구아카밀레 슈퍼 터보 챔피언쉽 에디션은 멕시코풍이 풀풀 풍기는 매트로배니아입니다.
주인공이 힘이 넘치게 되는 복면을 쓰고 여자친구를 구하기 위해 적을 소탕한다는 내용으로, 여러지역을 떠돌며 스테이지를 하나 클리어할 때마다 하나의 특수능력을 얻고 적을 깨부숩니다.

이 게임의 대표적인 특징중 하나는 차원변화입니다.
막혀있는 길을 차원변화로 뚫거나, 때리지 못하는 적(그림자)를 차원변화로 때릴 수 있습니다.
나중에 가면, 이 차원변화를 수시로 이용해야하는 스테이지가 나오게 됩니다.
이 시스템애 대해선 불만이 있는데, 그건 아래의 단점에 몰아서 서술하도록 하겠습니다.

또 하나의 대표적인 특징을 들으라고 한다면 그건 특수능력으로 깨부술 수 있는 보호막입니다.
중반부정도 가시면 왠 색깔을 띈 보호막을 가진 적을 보실 수 있을 겁니다. 그 적들은 그 색에 맞는 특수능력을 써야지 타격을 입힐 수 있습니다. 보호막은 깨지면, 얼마 뒤에 다시 재생됩니다.
이 시스템에 대해서도 불만이 있어서 이후의 이야기는 단점에 몰아적도록 하겠습니다.

긍정적인 평가가 많아서 기대했는데 솔직히 실망감이 좀 큰 작품입니다. 아래에는 대표적인 단점을 적어놨습니다.

[b]1. 게임의 시스템에 대하여[/b]
우선 차원변화에 대해 말씀드리겠습니다. 솔직히 말해서 귀찮습니다.
플레이어가 머리를 굴리도록 맵디자인을 잘 짜면 뭐라고 하질 않겠는데, 구아카밀레에서는 이 차원변화라는 시스템을 잘 이용해내지 못했다는 느낌이 큽니다. 구아카밀레에서 차원변화를 이용하는 경우는 크게 3가지입니다.
1. 그냥 막힌 벽이 보일 때
2. 그냥 그림자적이 있을 때
3. 딱봐도 차원변화 적용하면서 이동해야할 때
위의 사항들을 보시면 알겠지만 차원변화는 머리를 굴려가며 쓴다기보다는 그냥 무의식적으로 깜빡이켜듯 쓰는 것밖에 안됩니다.
특히 적들과 싸울때 그림자적(차원변화를 해야 때릴 수 있는 적)과 그냥 적이 있는데 차원변화 하면서 때리기 귀찮습니다.
왜냐면 현재 차원의 적을 다 쓰러트리고 나서야 차원변화를 쓰게 되기 때문이거든요. 그냥 현재 차원의 적을 다 잡으면 무의식적으로 키게 됩니다. 위에서 말한 깜빡이랑 다를게 뭔지.....

그리고 보호막 시스템도 영 좋은 평가를 내리지 못하겠습니다. 짧은 게임분량을 숨기려고 시간을 질질끌게 하기 위해 만들은건지 뭔지... 참신하다고 다 좋은 건 아닙니다. 중요한 것중 하나는 게임의 흐름을 방해하지 말아야하는 겁니다.
뒤로 가면 갈수록 특수능력이 늘어나는데, 거기에 비례해 적들의 보호막색도 다양해집니다. 그럼 그 보호막색을 기억하고 특수능력의 커맨드를 기억해야 합니다. 저같은 경우에는 그래도 막힘없이 하긴 했지만 여간 귀찮은게 아닙니다 이거. 기억하고 있던 특수능력으로 부술 수 있는 보호막색을 한 번 까먹으면 귀찮게 모든 특수능력을 다 때려박아야됩니다. 이게 게임 흐름을 끊어먹는 1등공신입니다.
제작진도 그 점을 아는 지 이번 확장팩에는 색 무시하고 때려부술 수 있는 업그레이드가 추가되었습니다. 근데 이걸 얻는게 후반부라는 걸 생각하면 영...

이 게임은 퀘스트도 불편한 데, 주는 보상이 영 시원찮아서 하고 싶은 맛이 안날 뿐더러 퀘스트자체도 썩 재미있진 않습니다
이것도 마찬가지로 왜 있는지 모르겠습니다. 그냥 게임에만 집중하게 만들면 더 효과적일 것 같다는 생각이 드는데 굳이 이런 [b]불필요한[/b] 퀘스트들을 만들어서 게임의 흐름을 방해하는 이유는 대체...

[b]2.게임자체[/b]
경쾌한 멕시코풍의 노래와 독특한 스타일의 그래픽같은 것들은 좋은 점수를 줄만합니다.

그렇지만 별 다를 바 없는 맵디자인은 까이기에 충분합니다. 지형이 달라져도 다른 곳과 비슷하다는 느낌을 받았습니다. 왜일까요?
비슷하게 쓴 색, 곡선이 일체 존재하지 않아 비슷해질 수 밖에 없는 디자인때문입니다.
매트로배니아하면 다른 지역으로 갈때의 두근거림이 있어야 하는데, 이 게임은 그런게 없습니다. 제가 캐슬배니아를 하면서 새 지역에 들어설 때 그 지역의 이름이 나옴과 동시에 처음보는 지형이 나올때의 두근거림을 생각하면.....

적들도 영 맘에 안듭니다. 이 게임은 적들과의 인카운터가 자주 발생하는 편인데, 적의 종류가 적을 뿐만 아니라, 적의 패턴도 단순합니다. 다른 게임은 맵디자인으로 똑같은 적이라도 다른 느낌을 연출해낸다면 이 게임은 그런게 일절 없습니다. 이걸 그나마 차원변화시스템이 커버해주고 있는데 위에서 말했듯이 결과는....


장점
+독특한 그래픽과 흥겨운 멕시코풍 노래
단점
- 맵디자인이 비슷비슷함
- 참신하지만 [b]귀찮은[/b] 시스템
- 쓰는것만 쓰게되는 특수기술
- 단순한 적 패턴

그래도 그냥저냥 할만해서....
평점은 5/10

36185719.review:
Game World, Story and Theme
Guacamelee is a Metroidvania.  The level design is solid and the locations varied.  There is quite a bit of optional content to play through and explore.
The game has a Mexican theme.  This is exceptionally well done and infuses every aspect of the game.  The visuals are beautiful and detailed.  The soundtrack is one of the best I have encountered.
The story is simple, but beautifully told.  The game has a great sense of humour, and the characters you meet are highly memorable.

Gameplay
Guacamelee is a beat-em-up with a focus on combos.  It is intense and fun and has a dynamic and forgiving combo system.  The combat has a feeling of weight and impact.
There is also a strong platforming element.  This is very well done, as it presents creative challenges to overcome.  Platforming often involves an element of puzzle solving.
Exploring the levels is fun, as you gain some neat abilities as you progress.  The combat and platforming can both be quite difficult at times, and some of the optional content can be extremely difficult indeed.

Conclusion
Guacamelee is a delightful and funny game with a memorable theme and awesome, varied gameplay.  I would highly recommend it.

35897715.review:
I'm a big fan of metroidvanias, and this was on my bucket list of metroidvanias to play. I have to say, I was pretty disappointed:

The difficulty is too easy until the last parts of the game. I'm not asking for the game to be Dark Souls, but I expect the difficulty to be somewhat consistent, and if the game is going to be making Metroid references, I expect it to not be a complete pushover. Instead, the early and middle parts of the game give you so much health, health regen, and health-refilling checkpoints that I could carelessly walk into attacks without consequence and beat most bosses first try. At least the last sections of the game put up a fight.

The "gates" that stop your progress until you find the appropriate item feel so bland. In other metroidvania games, you might have a platform that can't be reached until you get double jump/dash, or a piece of the environment you can't interact with until you get a specific item. I mean, a veteran of metroidvanias could easily recognize the gates when they see them, but at least those try to be a bit subtle or creative. In Guacamelee, you break yellow blocks with the yellow power, red blocks with the red power, blue blocks with the blue power, etc. It reminds me of Fischer Price toys where you put the square in the square hole and the circle in the circle hole.

The level design is bland. I can remember about two areas of the game. The color palettes, textures, themes, enemies, and room layouts of the areas are homogenized to the point where I can barely tell them apart. The jungle area feels like "rocks with grass", the desert area feels like "rocks with sand", the temple area feels like "rocks with engravings". Every single area of the game has the same kinds of enemies. The platforming manages to be more distinct from area to area, so I'll give the game credit for that. Compare this to a game like Hollow Knight, where I can remember almost every single area of the game because they all have distinct textures, color palettes, themes, enemies, etc. Hell, the entirety of Castlevania Symphony of the Night took place inside a castle and I can remember its areas better. Maybe the individual regions of Guacamelee are too small to properly develop any real personality.

On top of the areas being so forgettable, they feel very unrewarding to explore. The level design is incredibly linear, so most of the time, you're just going straight along the path the game tells you to go along. The linear level design also makes the secrets incredibly easy to spot: if you see a branching path, that's a treasure chest, go grab it. Remember those colored blocks I mentioned earlier? The map labels every single one of those automatically, so you basically already know where to go if you're backtracking to discover secrets you couldn't get on your first run through an area. Oh, and basically every single treasure chest in the game is either money, health, or stamina. The only interesting rewards you'll find are the mask pieces.

The enemies have no variety. The majority of the enemies are skeletons. You got regular skeletons, skeletons that throw bones, fast skeletons, big skeletons. The endgame skeletons are basically the same as the early game skeletons, except they have shields, or are elite, or come in massive numbers, something along those veins. The bosses would are actually kind of interesting, but unfortunately, most of them are complete pushovers.

I'll give the game credit for its good art, good music, and somewhat enjoyable combat and platforming.

Overall, the game wasn't bad, it was just mediocre. Why settle for mediocre when there are great games though? Before you consider this game, go buy Hollow Knight, Ori and the Blind Forest, Momodora, Axiom Verge, or any of the countless metroidvanias on Steam that are so much better than this first.

35799289.review:
I'm a bit torn on giving Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition (STCE) a thumbs down, but I feel it's important for prospective buyers/players to know that STCE is significantly worse than Guacamelee! Gold Edition. 

STCE brings a number of modifications to Guacamelee, all of which are negative (apart from the 4P support). First, there are two large new areas, both of which serve as filler, breaking the flow of the game while not introducing any new concepts. Arguably the best part of the second area is the new character that serves as a boss, but said boss fight is relatively simple and the character takes focus away from the stronger original cast. Secondly are the combat changes: the "rebalancing" of enemies and the Intenso power. Javiar Jaguar, the stand-out boss from the original game, has been nerfed to an absolute pushover. Moreover, the Intenso power is absolutely game breaking, making every combat encounter in the game a joke. That wouldn't be so bad if you could ignore it, but the developers added certain combat encounters where the difficulty goes through the roof if Intenso isn't used (rooms with multiple enemies with white shields, hitstun-immunity, and/or non-dodgable attacks).  These rooms generally feature Intenso-refilling barrels or enemies as well, so the intention is clear. Of course, there's plenty of Intenso to go around even for easier rooms and bosses, trivializing combat entirely. 

In short, STCE is still a good game, but the original release was a GREAT game, without the broken combat "rebalancing" and padding. Please buy/play Guacamelee! Gold instead.

34804332.review:
Pros
Beautiful graphics, good soundtrack, and variety. The way the game uses abilities you learn in different ways over time for platforming segments really amazes me. The way a side dash could be used to break a specific block but then you must immediately switch dimensions to avoid a hazard and then take out the enemies is really fun to do. Giving you 3 different base combat approaches, 4 special abilities that get throughout the game ("that uses an ability meter"), a grapple move with different add-ons, and 2 special movement abilities. That does not even include the other forms and their abilities. As you can see, there is a lot of variety in this game.

Cons
The more does not always mean the merrier, as a seasoned guacamelee player, you understand the moves how to use them, and the game can be pretty fun. But to a friend or sibling you are bringing in later to play, they become confused and overwhelmed with the amount of things you can do. The dimension swapping is used beautifully in platfroming segments, but not as well in combat. Some enemies cannot be attacked in one dimension, so you have to switch. That is good design, but the enemies can always attack you, regardless of dimension. Later in game, when they pile on multiple enemies from multiple dimensions, instead of getting challenging, it gets frustrating. This caused me to loathe any combat segment later in game. Also most bosses are very "cheap", with too much health and a very small window to attack them. But I've always felt that was the problem for most metroidvania bosses. When they are to weak, you breeze through and completely forget them. When they are too HARD (Final Boss), then it isn't fun. You are no longer a fighter against a very powerful foe, and you must learn their technique to win. You are waiting for them to attack, dodging, attack, waiting, dodging, attacking, losing, repeat, repeat, REPEAT. This wouldn't be so bad if it didn't happen that often, but later in game, bosses become harder, and more of them.

Best Parts of the game:
Abilities (you must learn them)
Enemies
Platforming segments
Graphics style
Music
Characters
Story
The Arena section

Worst Parts of game:
Bosses (most)
Enemies (Later in Game)
Difficult learning curve (if you come in later)

With so little Cons, you'd think I love the Game, and I do, but those few nagging details were so prevalent, especially in the last third of the game, that I can't recommend this game. I do love it, and I'm glad I bought it, but it  left me with such a sour taste that I cannot recommend it. If you can deal with those issues. Then buy it.

34681083.review:
Salut à toutes et à tous et bienvenue dans cette nouvelle review qui aujourd'hui va-nous amené à parler de ses fameux sites de ventes de jeux en quantité "très limitée"....

Car oui, ses derniers temps, il faut le dire, mais nous sommes véritablement submergé des petits jeux indépendants sortant sous forme de version "limités". Effet de mode du au succès d'un certain "Limited Run" ? Surement, mais il faut bien l'avouer, ses petits jeux font très mal au portefeuille lorsqu'on est collectionneur ou que l'on désire posséder tous ses jeux indépendants fort agréables...  Et dans ses jeux en version "ultra limitée", il y eut dernièrement ce jeu qui fit battre mon coeur à 200% lorsque j'ai appris qu'il sortait en version physique... Ce jeu n'est autre que Guacamelée SUPER TURBO CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION !!

Le sourire, le coeur qui palpite, je ne pouvais raté cette occasion de pouvoir possédé une version de ce jeu qui m'a vraiment marqué ! Et quel jeu mes aïeux ! Découvert totalement par hasard dans un bundle de jeux sur PC (90% des jeux indépendant je les connais grâce à leur sortie PC de toute façon...), c'est avec plaisir que j'ai découvert ce jeu réalisé par le DrinkBoxStudios, un petit studio canadien qui avait auparavant opérée sur Tales from Space : About Blob qui fit un petit succès bien que trop peu connu du grand publique...

Sortie en 2015 sur toutes les plateformes actuelles, Guacamélée STCE est issu de la rencontre de plusieurs genres totalement différents que sont le Beat m'Up, le plateformer mais aussi et le plus curieux... Le Metroidvania !

Mais avant de parler du Gameplay, parlons du scénario dantesque que Guacamélée dispose ! L'histoire se concentre sur Juan Aguacate, un jeune paysan vivant paisiblement au beau milieu des champs qui un jour, pile au moment de la fameuse fête des Morts au Mexique, va voir son destin totalement basculé lorsqu'il va retrouver son amour d'enfance, la jeune fille del présidente ! Hélas ! Malgré leurs retrouvailles, cette dernière va se faire kidnappé par un horrible personnage nommé Calaca, un homme mi-mort/mi-humain qui va éliminé Juan devant les yeux de la jeune demoiselle... Laissé pour mort et plongé dans l'autre monde, Juan ferra la rencontre d'une mystérieuse luchador dénommée : Tostada qui va lui remettre un objet bien particulier... "le masque du luchador". Prenant son courage à deux mains, Juan enfilera ce fameux masque et partira à la rescousse de sa chère et tendre !

Un air de déjà vu ? Oui, cela reste encore une nouvelle fois le fameux héros qui va sauver sa princesse, mais contrairement à tous ses autres jeux, Guacamélée s'en moque totalement et joue justement sur ce cliché pour proposer une histoire originale totalement barrée avec des personnages secondaires uniques en leur genre. Les dialogues sont même à mourir de rire par moment et font d'ailleurs d'énormes clins d'oeil soit au jeu vidéo en général ou bien carrément à la pop culture. C'est du scénario solide, il n’y a pas de doute !

Vous allez me dire, comment Beat m'up et Metroidvania peuvent-il cohabité ? Et bien, c'est très simple ! Guacamélée se joue de long en large comme un Metroidvania, le joueur peut avancer dans des niveaux ouverts ou tous les chemins sont possibles pour avancer à condition d'avoir les bonnes capacités ou événements activés. Bien sur sa route, Juan rencontrera des ennemies qu'ils tenteront de l'arrêté dans son aventure...

En tant que Luchador, Juan devra utiliser ses compétences de combattant pour envoyer ses fameux ennemis au tapis ! Bourrant les différentes combinaisons sur la manette, le panel de mouvements de Juan est très complet et peut réaliser tout type de combo pour anéantir ses ennemies. De plus au cours de l'aventure, le joueur aura aussi la possibilité d'acquérir des techniques spéciaux pour pouvoir à la fois détruire ses adversaires de façon spectaculaire, mais aussi, et comme dans tout Metroidvania, passé certains passages complexes pour pourvoir débloqué de nouvelles routes qui était alors inaccessibles sans cette dernière.

Et c'est la qu'on se rend compte que le Beat m'up et le Metroidvania peuvent être compatible ! car certes on se bastonne face à des hordes et des hordes d'ennemies, mais cela reste dans des environnements ouverts ou le joueur peut accédé à plusieurs chemins possibles et/ou trouver des passages secrets permettant de récupérer des upgrades pour Juan !

Car évidemment qui dit Metroidvania, dit forcément Upgrade dans des zones cachées (même si Guacamélée n'est pas aussi pervers que Super Metroid il faut l'avoué...). On y retrouvera l'upgrade de vie qui permet d'avoir plus de vie. L'upgrade d'endurance, permettant d'utilisé plusieurs fois ses compétences spéciales et enfin l'upgrade d'INTENSO, qui plus loin dans le jeu permettra au joueur d'avoir plus de temps pour utilisé son INTENSO, mais je vous laisse découvrir ce qu'est ce fameux "INTENSO".

Bref vous l'aurez compris, c'est un Gameplay au petit oignon et véritablement fun ! Il y a vraiment de bonnes idées partout et on ne se lasse pas un instant du jeu. Surtout qu'en plus le jeu est même jouable à 4 simultanément, ce qui nous réserve des heures de fun en COOP. Et il nous propose même des réalisés des quêtes annexes sympathiques en échange d'upgrade ! Que demandé de plus ? Ah oui ! Comptée 7-8h pour finir le jeu et plus du double si vous voulez absolument tout avoir et finir toutes les quêtes annexes !

En plus d'avoir un Gameplay des plus corrects, Guacamélée peut se vanter par sa réalisation technique fantastique qui envoie véritablement du rêve ! Graphiquement, le jeu est très propre, coloré et nous plonge parfaitement dans cette drôle fête qu'est la fête des morts mexicaine ! Les développeurs ont été très minutieux dans chaque détail du jeu qu'ils ont même jusqu'à intégrer quelque easter egg en arrière fond dans le décor ou bien tout simplement en fessant des allusions évidentes et visibles au premier regard !

Pour la musique, on a le droit évidemment à des compositions originales avec des instruments typiques de la musique mexicaine ! Elle est plutôt agréable à écouter et joint avec le jeu, la musique fait vraiment passe-partout... Cependant il est quand même dommage qu'aucune de ses musiques n'arrive à vraiment sortir du lot... Car pour nos amis mélomanes qui écoute les bandes-son de jeux sur leur baladeur favori, ne vous attendais pas à écouté la bande-son en boucle... J'ai tenté et cela m'a très vite lassé ...

Concrètement je n'ai pas de vrai défaut à donné à ce Guacamélée qui est comme vous l'avez compris dispose d'un scénario et humour bien ficelé, d'un Gameplay au petit oignon, de réalisation plus que correcte et surtout une durée de vie assez conséquente pour tout joueur qui se respecte !

Finalement que demandé de plus ? Le jeu est très bon, ne coute pas cher, est disponible sur tous les Marketplace et peut se jouer jusqu'à 4 joueurs simultanément ! Avec cette review qui je l'espère vous à convaincu, foncé acheté le jeux si ce n'est pas déjà fait ! 34505327.review:
[h1]INTRODUCCIÓN[/h1]
Guacamelee! es un Juego de plataformas de la categoría "Metroidvania", llamado asi porque toma el sistema de plataformas de Metroid y el combate de Castelvania, mezclandolos para así patentar su estilo de juego. El juego se ambienta en la Cultura Mexicana, y nos cuenta la Historia de Juan, un Hombre que se dedica al destilamiento de Tequila en su Pueblucho, hasta que el proclamado rey del mundo de los muertos; Carlos Calaca, desea fusionar ambos mundos, el de los vivos y los muertos, para asi ser el máximo gobernante, Juan impulsado por el secuestro de Su amada, se embarca en una aventura para detener a Calaca, con la ayuda de la legendaria máscara del luchador, y la guardiana de la Misma, Tostada.

[h1]PRESENTACIÓN[/h1]
El juego es presentado con una estética "Flat", es decir diseño plano, y hay que admitir que se ve simplemente hermoso, está bien pulido, es colorido, es dinamico, y los personajes son reconocibles, se ven muy bien, y se mueven acorde a su diseño. A esto se le suma la espectacular estetica basada en México, Detalles como los fondos, las paletas de colores, los acabados de objetos como casas, templos, pueblos, ciudades, valles, estatuas, simplemente el juego grita a viva voz (En el ambito de diseño) "VIVA MÉXICO", describirlo en texto no basta, debes verlo con us propios ojos. Entre otras cosas el presentar una historia basada en la que quizas es la festividad mas importante de México, el dia de los Muertos, le da un plus bastante alto, algo cliché tal vez, pero bien ejecutado, se hacen referencias a la festividad, por ejemplo [spoiler]Los puntos de guardado, que asi mismo son la tienda, son las muy reonocidas Calaveritas de Azucar en un pequeño altar[/spoiler], es una bonita referencia a la festividad, y no es la única hay muchas mas, y no solo eso, el juego todo el tiempo Hace referencias a otras franquisias, juegos e incluso Memes de Internet, y darse cuenta de las mismas te puede sacar una sonrisa, son detalles pequeños que alegran tu experiencia de juego, y que te impulsan a encontrar mas. Oh y la Banda sonora... Es simplemente exelente, el juego implementa los intrumentos tradicionales Méxicanos, y se denotan generos como la Balada suave y la Serenata, y en partes en las que hay bastante acción, como areas de exploración y combate, la música se ajusta a la misma, mientras que en areas como ciudades o pueblos la música es serena y tranquila, muy bien ejecutada, es buena hasta el punto en que no te cansas de oirla.

[h1]JUGABILIDAD[/h1]
Guacamelee! Esta plenamente y obviamente inspirado en Juegos como Castelvania Symphony of the Nigth, y Super Metroid (Hasta su descripción en la tienda lo Menciona), aparte tiene un sistema de combos en el cual puedes encadenar varios ataques y luego agarrar a tu enemigo para lanzarlo o darle un golpe de gracia, esto está muy bien establecido, es un sistema de combate divertido, facil de aprender, y funciona muy bien incluso si hay ordas de enemigos. Ademas cabe mencionar que desde su ultima actualización, el juego se puede jugar hasta con 4 prsonas en pantalla (Antes esto estaba limitado a solo 2 Jugadores), lo cual da para una muy buena experiencia en multijugador, ya que entre todos se puede planear una estrategia para derrotar a enemigos mas facilmente o completar el juego mas rápido, bastante [spoiler]INTENSO![/spoiler]

[h1]VEREDICTO[/h1]
[b]9.5/10 - BUENISIMO[/b] ¿Vale La Pena?, Vale Cada **** Peso. AHORA COMPRALO GÜEY!.
Vale la pena, definitivamente lo vale. Guacamelee! es basicamente una carta de amor al genero de las plataformas, un juego divertido, visualmente hermoso, entretenido, con una historia muy bien estructurada, y personajes carismaticos.
Tiene una cantidad justa de logros, y una duración justificable y visto y considerando que el juego tiene [spoiler]Mas de un Final[/spoiler] Vale la pena experimentarlo y saber en que termina la historia.

Я вообще давно не припомню, чтобы мне было так весело в платформере. Может только в Rayman Origins, но там веселье спадает через какое-то время и начинается рутина и борьба за бонусы, а в Guacamelee - всё отлично до самого конца.

34338381.review:
WOW THIS IS FABULOUS. Bright colors, techno mariachi music, and beautiful, BEAUTIFUL 2D platformer handling. And sometimes I get to be a chicken. It is everything I didn't know I wanted in a Metroidvania. 

Before I bought it, I thought this was a go-to-the-right-beat-em-up like the arcade version of TMNT or THE SIMPSONS. But then it came up during a lookup of Metroidvanias and I had a closer look. I still wasn't quite sure if it was the game for me. THEN there was a sale--get the Super Turbo Championship Edition, Gold Edition, AND soundtrack for $6. I couldn't pass up the deal.

Since the Super Turbo version looked to be the more "complete" version of the game, I deleted the Gold version and started my GUACAMELEE journey.

This game does a ton of things right. Checkpoints are generous. The beat 'em up sections are fun to complete, even when playing on a keyboard. Miss a platform jump (in a series of them over water), and instead of going back to a last checkpoint, you go to the last bit of solid ground you stood on. THANK YOU, GUACAMELEE, FOR RESPECTING MY TIME.

I groused at first about the lack of double-jump, but in the end, I was glad they made me use the Rooster Punch so often, because then I discovered its versatility. Then when I did get double jump, I found myself using it differently. 

Within hours, I was zipping across the neon landscape like a champ, goat-jumping off walls while switching dimensions and punching skeletons in the face like a stud. THAT'S what I play platformers for.

The abilities upgrade system is a little weak -- at times it was hard to see how spending pesos improved said abilities--

As a kid, I fell in love with Castlevania: Symphony of the Night for its dark-yet-fun horror-gothic vibe. I grew up with the Donkey Kong Country games. I've played nearly all the Nifflas platformers, which have a chill mystique. GUACAMELEE has the wonderful quality of movement of ALL those games PLUS a zesty feast for your eyes and ears, the most festive, fun platformer I've played in a L O N G time. 

Come for the platforming, stay for the art. And chicken.

I 100% completed this game in 20.9 Hours. Story mode can take about 4-7 hours without completionisting.

A metroidvania beat em up? Sign me up! A wonderfully fun game that anyone will love. The levels are wonderfully designed and the music works perfectly for each place even though it does get repetitive after 10 hours. Any challenges are always fair and will test you on what the game has taught you while you play. Spamming is not an option here.

Completionists will have a decent time here. Nothing is hard to achieve it just takes a ton of time to finish it. Prepair to collect everything by passing puzzles that'll test you on your knowledge of the game. You'll also have to play through the game twice for the hard mode. I recommend this game at any price if you plan on 100% it. Maybe a bit cheaper if you want to just play through quick which is a bad idea.

This game is splendid.  It's a solid brawler with Metroidvania influences, with the latter influences being implemented tastefully as to not waste the player's time with tons of backtracking (a common complaint in other Metroid-influenced games).

The music is fantastic, and the humor tongue-in-cheek.  I was surprised this was made by a bunch of Canadians as the subject matter, while funny, is a little bit casually-racist.  Didn't bother me at all, but I could see it being a barriers to others.

I would definitely recommend playing this with a controller, as all 2D platformer games.  With that said, controls are nice and tight , though I recommend using the D-pad over the Thumbstick as the combos definitely benefit from that precision.

All in all, this comes recommended.

33025376.review:
Guacamelee! is a action platformer with combo-based melee combat and exploration elements. You play as Juan, a farmer who gains superpowers after finding a mysterious luchador mask. You fight through throngs of enemies in a Mexican-inspired setting on your quest to rescue El Presidente's kidnapped daughter.

Super Turbo Championship Edition is rather pointless (and frankly greedy) rerelease of the game with rebalanced encounters, some new content and a poorly implemented new mechanic. In hindsight I should have just played the earlier Gold Edition instead of buying this one. Rather annoyingly there's no discount anymore for upgrading from the Gold Edition and you have to pay the full price for this one even if you own the earlier release .

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The game has a strong visual style that fits the theme well. Unfortunately the visuals leave a lot to be desired on a technical level. A lot of the artwork is rather poorly done and the animations in particular are terrible. Also, the game does not properly support 16:10 resolutions.

The game also suffers from rather heavy tearing on my system. Enabling vsync will fix the issue but leads to extremely nearly unplayable controller lag.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The sound effects are decent enough although there seemed to be issues with the timings of some sounds. The music is well done if rather repetitive and fits the theme well. There's no real voice acting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game plays like a fairly typical metroidvania with combo-based melee combat. You explore the maps and unlock special powers that let you progress to new areas. These powers are pretty standard from wall climbing and double jumping to various attack moves that let you break through special color-coded walls.

You also gain the power to switch between the land of the dead and the land of the living, although nothing particularly inventive is done with this ability. In practice it's mainly used for a lot of rather repetitive and tedious platforming sections.

My early impressions of the combat were quite positive. Chaining the combos is fun and the combat flows quite well. Unfortunately as you progress the game keeps adding more and more gimmicky elements that mess up the core gameplay. Having to constantly break enemy shields and switch between the land of the dead/living just breaks the flow and makes the combat lot less enjoyable.

Way too much of the combat also takes place in small closed-off arenas. I certainly felt that this was a rather baffling design choice in a metroidvania game and would have preferred more open-ended encounters.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
I found the game pretty easy on normal difficulty, although this will be heavily dependant on your ability to pull of combos and your platforming skills. The final area is certainly a big step up in difficulty and some of the optional puzzles and areas are quite a bit harder too.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The controls are pretty solid on a gamepad. Some moves can feel slightly imprecise, however.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
The story is very basic and cliché. The writing is pretty terrible too and the jokes in particular are extremely cringeworthy. I felt that much more could have been done with the Mexican theme.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
Overall the game is fairly polished and I didn't encounter any major bugs.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Personally I found Guacamelee! a somewhat disappointing game. The core gameplay is solid enough, but the game introduces way too many poorly implemented powers and gimmicky enemies that end up making the combat lot less fun. The writing is pretty terrible too and the exploration aspects are not particularly satisfying. It's not a terrible game by any means, but I still didn't find it enjoyable enough to recommend.

It took me little under 6 hours to play through the game on normal. I didn't bother with most optional areas, just completed the main story.

Muito, mas muito bom. Nada como um bom e delicioso metroid-vania, e esse é um belo de um deles. A arte é massa demais, eu curto muito esse estilo! A história é clichêzona (mocinha raptada, resgatar do vilão e tal), porém muito divertida e cheio de referências cult. O combate, pra mim, é o ponto forte: é bem fluído, precisa de timing e habilidade e muito prazeroso. Lembra um pouco Dust An Elysian Tail, só que mais tático. Você tem que pensar nos movimentos que vai fazer, e não simplesmente esmagar botões. Quando você pega o jeito, é muito relaxante e satisfatório. Tem puzzles, mas não dá bem pra chamar de "puzzle"... eles requerem mais habilidade do que raciocínio. Bem desafiadores. O jogo sempre te puxa pro limite do que ele te ensina em seguida, o que é ótimo.

Recomendo demais, vale muito a pena!

Pretendo zerar este e depois jogar o Turbo Edition.

31225949.review:
I’m not giving this review a non-recommendation because this is a bad game, maybe it just doesn’t float my boat.

I like the music in this one, they are unique and fits each area just right, the Mexican folklore is awesome and very well done, but that’s about everything I like about this game.

I’m confused with the graphics choice here, I feel that sometimes it wants to be a 2D HD game, and sometimes it wants to be a Pixel Art or a Retro kind of graphics, it wasn’t easy on the eyes.

Also the gameplay have its share of imperfection, you only have a limited type of enemies, and the combats are so far in between the platforming sections, there is no joy in leveling up or killing enemies simply because there is not enough reward in doing so, you can only collect hearts and skulls to slightly upgrade your stamina and health, and few more boring abilities to buy.

The platforming is good, although it’s majorly flawed by some confusing and dull mechanics, like the portal that you have to go into to make some platforms appear and disappear, or the climbing up and down to reach new areas, they all sounds good on paper, but the execution is awful in my opinion.

The map is confusing, even the mini maps are confusing, you don’t know what’s what until you start to memorize areas.

Again, maybe it just me that can’t enjoy this one, it felt like a chore in the 4 hours I spent in, it’s boring and uninteresting. Couldn’t beat and the game and don’t have an interest to do so, this game gets a boring 4 out of 10.

30943274.review:
I just want to say first that Guacamelee has great gameplay. However, good gameplay can only go so far and the rest of Guacamelee's element fall short.

The thing about Guacamelee is that it has a good premise. It looks really fun, colorful and wacky and all these qualities hints that you are about to enter a wonderful and original world full of spectacles. But it is sadly not the case and you start realizing it when you notice that there is barely no interesting NPC hanging in the couple of towns there is and all the temple look like one another making hard to remenber your adventure in Guacamelee. Even the music is pretty bland and forgettable. Then come the bosses. They all have cool design and are indeed interesting by themselves, but they still end out as flat and boring. They try as hard as they can to have emotion and something interesting to say, but all that effort is wasted when Juan (the protagonist) just stand there, emotionless, waiting for them to shut up so he can move on.

It was a mistake to take the silent protagonist route with Juan and if, they had to do it, they should have done it the same way Zelda does by having the hero emote and having a lot of interesting NPC filling the void that Link leave.

Overall, I still had fun with this title and the ending sequence is the only part where I can say, weirdly enough, none of these issues I mention are present and I really felt satisfied at the end. But still, I though there were going to be more charm and personality in this game.

O produtor de Super Metroid havia dito em entrevista que não tinha mais espaço para um Metroid 2D porque as ideias esgotaram nesse sentido. O que houve depois foi um limbo: não teve metroid no Nintendo 64. Só voltariam a existir Metroids novamente na forma 3D, na série Prime, ou no GBA, finalmente em 2D, mas décadas depois. 
Guacamelee prova que um metroidvania tem ainda muitas possibilidades de mecânica sem precisar ser hermético. É um jogo divertido, engraçado, e com easter eggs por toda parte, recompensando a exploração, não só com itens, mas com lembranças. Fica evidente que os desenvolvedores puseram muito amor no jogo, porque são muitas homenagens, tornando tudo muito pessoal. Joguei o jogo no modo normal e o desafio foi na medida. De qualquer forma existe um post-game bem técnico e segredos para os jogadores mais exigentes, como num bom metroidvania. Outros destaques são a trilha sonora, que fica na sua cabeça depois que você para de jogar, principalmente a do Canal de las Flores e a direção de arte, que foi um ponto decisivo para eu comprar o jogo: tudo é muito minimalista e vibrante ao mesmo tempo. A temática mexicana é constante e até a adaptação dos poderes do luchador seguem a temática. Super recomendado!

30388173.review:
Guacamelee super turbo championship edition è un esplosivo gioco indie platform/azione in 2D, sviluppato e pubblicato da DrinkBox Studios. Il gioco è stato rilasciato il 21 agosto 2014 per Pc, Ps3, Ps Vita, Ps4, Xbox One, Mac OS e Linux.

La storia, che ha luogo in una località messicana in cui elementi sovrannaturali e leggende del folklore si intrecciano, narra dei piani di conquista del mondo dei vivi da parte del grande Carlos Calaca, il signore del regno dei morti. Per poter attuare il suo diabolico piano, egli rapisce la figlia del presidente di un piccolo villaggio di contadini. Juan, un uomo forte e coraggioso, innamorato della ragazza, cerca di fermarlo ma invano, venendo ucciso con poco sforzo da Calaca.
Mentre finisce nel regno dei morti, viene a contatto con una misteriosa maschera che non solo lo resuscita, facendolo tornare tra i vivi ma lo trasforma anche in un potentissimo luchador, in grado di affrontare l’esercito di morti di Calaca e i suoi eccentrici compagni. Con l’aiuto di Tostada, guardiana della maschera e degli strani poteri elargiti dal vecchio maestro Uay Chivo, Juan comincia il suo viaggio, per fermare i folli piani di Calaca, liberare la figlia del presidente e salvare il regno dei vivi e quello dei morti.

In questo gioco, leggende del folklore, personaggi strani e animali antropomorfi si intrecciano a formare una storia epica, dai tratti malinconici ed esplosivi. Durante il viaggio da una località all’altra, con foreste, miniere, caverne oscure, città piene di vita, templi abbandonati protetti da creature feroci, deserti roventi e vulcani, dovremo farci strada attraverso orde di scheletri, chupacabra e molti altri nemici che compongono l’esercito di Calaca, da sconfiggere a suon di pugni, calci, lanci pazzeschi e poteri come la schiacciata del rospo o il montante cedrone.
Il design delle zone, dei personaggi e dei vari nemici è ben realizzato, le musiche sono esplosive e coinvolgenti in ogni località che esploriamo, con segreti da scoprire grazie ai vari poteri che sbloccheremo nel corso del gioco. Inoltre, per poter risolvere alcuni enigmi o per sconfiggere certi nemici, dovremo destreggiarci tra il mondo dei vivi e quello dei morti, completando anche una serie di quest nelle varie città in cui andremo, per ottenere monete per acquistare nuove abilità e potenziamenti per i personaggi.
 
La storia viene narrata attraverso i filmati di gioco ma anche tramite le varie situazioni assurde e i siparietti comici tra Juan e i vari personaggi della vicenda. Le zone del mondo, i nemici, i personaggi e gli scontri contro i Boss sono realizzati in maniera eccellente così come le straordinarie musiche che ci accompagnano nel corso della nostra avventura.
Rispetto alla versione Golden, la Super Turbo Championship Edition può vantare nuove sfide, nuove zone da esplorare, nuovi poteri (come la modalità Intenso, uno stato mistico che ci permette di buttare giù anche i nemici più ostici), nuovi costumi con abilità pazzesche (lanci più potenti, stamina che non si esaurisce, ecc…), nuove varietà di nemici, la fantastica possibilità di giocare in co-op fino a 4 persone in contemporanea e nuovi Boss da sconfiggere. Nonostante le zone del gioco non sia molte da visitare, grazie alle nuove modalità Normale e Difficile la giocabilità è assicurata, sia giocando in singolo che divertendosi con altri amici in co-op, grazie anche ai nuovi nemici di classe Elitè, nuove abilità e arene esplosive, dove massacrare gli avversari con stile, violenza inaudita e potenti bombe pollo.

- Trama 8.4/10
- Personaggi 8.8/10
- Grafica 8.8/10
- Sonoro 8.6/10
- Rapporto Qualità/Prezzo 9.0/10
- Sviluppo della Storia 8.4/10

Voto Personale 8.6/10

30307748.review:
So, first things first, controller is greatly required to play this one. Default key mapping is pretty crappy, but at least it allows you to remap keys to whatever you want. Fun fact, it is the literal first controller support game I play, that doesn't recognize my cheap PS2 knockoff at all, no big deal tho, just used Xpadder. Another detail is that the game randomly crashes when switching areas, had it crash twice at temple of rain, and one when returning to Santa Luchita. Laptop hugely exceeds requirements, so not a specs issue.

On to the game, it feels pretty fine, a well done mashup of a platformer beat-them-up, altho the tutorials feel somewhat clunky and, by the time you reach the guy who explains your moveset, you already had to clear your way thru a few baddies and thus, already know what he has to teach. Fighting feels fluid and not overly complicated, just button mash and dodge at the right time, platforms make good use of your moveset and feel compelling.

The atmosphere feels pretty colorful and lively, and while the mexican theme is laid out quite a bit over the top, it feels right in sync with the rest of the game. Colour palletes are well used and the game feels right. Story is not the most original and character names are... wonky, but work well with the atmosphere the game is trying to set.

Got this one as part of a big Humble Bundle along with lotsa other stuff, so I paid like a buck for it, ofc at that price, game's a steal, and well worth what I paid for it, but even at full price, it's worth its salt. Haven't tried out local multiplayer, which is a feature less and less games seem to still carry now, so a big plus for that, however without true controller support, I wouldn't be able to either way (Xpadder only turns controller into a makeshift keyboard), and honestly, I'm not coughing up the cost of a XBOX controller for one game, when every other recognizes my generic one just fine. Other than that, sure, get it.

30207019.review:
This is one of the best Metroidvania's I've played in recent memory. Combat is great fun, with all your special moves being fun, useful and feeding into fluid combos. Enemy design is good. Level design is very good, and makes excellent use of each power you gain. I especially love all the creative ways they used the light-world/dark world mechanic. It's got secrets and extra challenges galore for more hardcore gamers.

Also, the heavy mexican and day-of-the-dead themeing does a lot to make the game feel fresh compared to other videogames, and thematically cohesive. It also has a good sense of humor.

Criticisms: Using a keyboard, the controls for some of the special moves are finnicky--you can't do the rising uppercut unless you let go of the left/right arrow keys, for instance. And for people who have trouble with even mild colorblindness, you'll have a lot of trouble with colored shields some enemies (and bosses) get which can only be broken by the corresponding move. The red and green ones are very similar shades and they can get muddied further by ambient lighting effects in some areas (ie fire). The game would have benefitted from a colorblind mode.

Other than that though, this is a solid game that I highly recommend.

30163246.review:
Guacamelee! is a Metroidvania style beat 'em up. I've played this game two times through. Once with this edition and once in the Gold Edition. But there is a few things that really ruined things near the end for me. 

[h1] Care [/h1]
The first issue I found was what felt like a lack of caring for this game from the developers. I understand that this is the third time this game has been sold, and it was originally a PS3 game. However, if you play as Toastada, none of the dialogue is changed, originally she was intended as the player two character Why should I get the option if they're not going to do anything to identify the fact I am playing as a different character? Not to mention the UI, because Drink Box made this as a four-player party game, which the tight platforming sections would beg to differ. The developers stuck Press Start 3 times across the screen at the top, it is very distracting and ugly.

[h1] Difficulty [/h1]
The next problem I have is the difficulty. The game is very stilted and boring in the majority of the game. The game is well placed but there is a lack of enemy variety that becomes apparent after the desert section of the game. Which post that area of the game, you hardly see new versions of enemies until they give 5 or 6 enemy types "Black" versions, which are the same in every way but they randomly break your combo and flow by teleporting.

[h1] The Story [/h1]
I had no feeling for any of the main characters. The writers spent too long trying to make you feel for the antagonists. The only thing I supposedly know about the love interest is "She is smart and Beautiful" A quote from an old lady in the beginning of the game. I don't know her name because she is called "El Presidente's Daughter" I've played it twice and that's the only name I know her for. Beyond that the new section of the game added in the DLC from Gold Edition, is to explain Toastada's past. She saved a village from a volcano. I'd argue it's the best written portion of the game, but even that is lacking in the writing department.

[h1] Fighting [/h1]
The fighting was dry, just mash X or whatever your basic attack is, until you can grapple, supplex, repeat. Outside of that, having to switch dimensions on the fly in battle adds the smallest layer of interest, outside of that switching between the two worlds only serves to add frustration, because you can't impact enemies in the other world at all. As for the shields, they either come back too quickly or are pointless. Essentially the shields come in two varieties, either you must combo a white shield away in order to dish out damage, or use a super move to break it. Also on the occasion I felt the controls glitch out, using a super move then going to attack on the occasion will launch you into another super move.

[h1] Intenso [/h1]
Intenso gives you the ability to buff your character temporarily. I'd argue this could be the best part of the added content. Intenso let's you bust through the combat and murder enemies outright.

Spoilers down here!
[spoiler] [h1] Mask Pieces [/h1]
There are five mask pieces to get at the end of the game for the true ending. Unless you're going for completion, it's pointless to get them, it doesn't add anything besides flight for chicken mode. Which flying only is helpful for people looking to get 100% of the maps. Each mask piece offered little challenge to me, except for the one in the second to last temple or so, Sierra.

[h1] Final Boss [/h1]
The final boss has a random difficulty curve. In his first form Calca teleports around the screen, which at first feels unfair, but once you understand the general pattern and how to avoid him, it is easy to avoid him and it is rather well put together. His second form mad me originally quit the game. Two years ago when I 'finished the game' I couldn't because his fight was poorly put together and expects you to last throughout the gauntlet of health he has. On my second play through Intenso made him kneel before me, and with the devil suit I easily survived the fight. This is the only portion of the game I'd argue is hard, but it is for the wrong reasons.

[/spoiler]

[h1] Art [/h1]
Okay the game is beautiful. The artist(s) used a Mexican-Inspired artstyle and it shines throughout the game and it truly charms me. I believe the only reason I played this game again is because I thought it looked awesome and I needed to beat Calca, not many games I haven't beaten because they were too hard and only because of that.

[h1] Memes [/h1]
This game suffers from being of it's time. All over towns you can see posters referencing other games, or internet memes from 2012 or so. And it feels like it's trying to force you into liking the game.

[b] I'd rate this game a C+ [/b]
Which is not okay from a developer releasing this game for the third time. If a company like Nintendo or Blizzard did this with a game being released three times within 2 years or so, I'd be a splotch on their credibility as a company.

30026171.review:
(This game was a gift from ArtificialRaven.  Thanks, bro!  Ironically, it comes from Humble Bundle, the same place I got the previous version from.)

[i]Guacamelee!  Super Turbo Championship Edition[/i]...what a mouthful.  For the sake of this review (And to make it easier on the eyes), we'll snip it to SCTE.  Yes, I played the Gold Edition first...which was 3 years ago.  I heard about this edition and added it to my wishlist, I forgot about it until it landed in my lap.  So...another game, another review!  ( http://steamcommunity.com/id/Shrodu/recommended/214770  Link to the review of the Gold Edition)

So, what makes STCE so special?  Well, like it's previous counterpart (a brawler/platformer hybrid that's fun to enjoy), but with MORE content, including a few additional levels, an additional boss, an additional power, Up to 4 player Co-Op, and...MULTIPLE SAVE FILES (Gold only had 1).  STCE has half the achievements that Gold had, but it's still a nice experience.

There aren't any real gripes about this version since it essentially fixed what was wrong with the Gold Edition.  I would personally say that this game would be great at a price of around $12.  If you're thinking of getting Gold Edition, I can't stop you.  I only suggest that you get this version instead since you're getting more bang for your buck!

8/10  A great experience and a lost gem on Steam that you should definitely have in your library.

29531801.review:
I love fighting games! I love them too much. Heck, I don't even like video games that much, honestly. Fighting games are usually the only games I play... but Steam sales. Oh, Steam sales. Lord Gabe gave Guacamelee a price of one... little... dollar... and a few cents. So, I picked it up because... Steam sales. All I can say is that it is alright. Not something I'll come back to, as there are way too many fighting games out there. They're all waiting to be mastered. I can't get myself to play this again for fun!

Sans has stole the president's daughter and now it is up to you, Zangief, to save the daughter for mutha russia. Yeah, I don't pay attension to stories of video games. I mean, if I did, then Street Fighter would I confused me so much... 

Anyway, this is a fun beat'em up with lots of platforming and combat. The combat is satisfing and there is plenty of enemy varity. The enemies are never unfair, just challenging and tough in numbers. 

Combos are REALLY satisfing in this game. They are performed by using all of your unique attacks in anyway you want. This game feels like playing 3.0 PM Mewtwo or Melee Fox in turbo mode. YOU'RE UNSTOPPABLE! Want to cancel shoryuken into headbutt? Feel free to. The best part is you can upgrade your abilities to wombo combo your enemies even more. You can upgrade your stamina bar to cancel into more special moves in a combo. Want to add a belly flop into that uppercut head combo? BOOM! You can now once you get the upgrades. It is easy and VERY satisfing to come up with a long combo yourself out of moves that you didn't even consider that useful in a fight. It is so tasty to try all your combos against unique opponents who require different methods of comboing. 

Heck, battles don't feel like they come often! Your mostly platforming, fighting bosses, and reading or seeing a bunch of video game/culture references. Bust it Bill: The black, angry Ralph. A wood sign that resembles Cactuar. Using an axe to cut down a bridge that a monster tries to cross to kill you to then be told your princess is in another castle. However, these jokes can be very corny at times when ALL of the games you play pretty much constantly make these references. This game does but a lot of twist on these classic references to other games, but not enough to not come across as corny. But that could be just me. A lot of people love these random references for some reason...

Great game! Pick it up for prices anywhere below 30 dollars. Except if you are me and you have too many fighting games to play. In that case, buy it if it is... a dollar. 7.5/10, above average.


PLEASE TAKE NOTE THAT I GOT THIS GAME FOR A DOLLAR.

29348299.review:
A defined and fascinating artsyle in two different worlds, that you can flip to on the fly, combined with easy to pick up and play gameplay highlight the brilliance of Guacamelee. Drinkbox really branches out with this game from the Blob games, which were great in their own right if more simplistic.

Guacamelee has personality to spare, engaging and true metroidvania gameplay, and never really outstays its welcome. If you are at all interested in the artstyle that alone is enough to play. This one is a beauty, and I really enjoy being able to switch to the dead world when I want to. It is worth it to see this in 4K. Its mechanics are all sound as well to my liking, and quite honestly the theme and tone are so creative and unique I cannot imagine metroidvania fan wanting to miss this.

Challenge can be basically chosen by the player as there are a variety of skins you can unlock. I love playing with the fragile character that gains more money. It makes the game about a perfect difficulty, and much more akin to something like Ori. And it's up there with that game too.

The writing can grate at times, but in general it's pretty cool and even funny. The Spanish language background to everything is glorious. The traditional upgrades and RPG elements round out an impressive package that was heavily upgraded itself from the Gold edition released before it. Extra levels and additions complement beautiful art and elements of Mexican culture.

At 4K with some injected SMAA along with the in-game AA you basically have very few jaggies. Looks better on PC than PS4 this way for sure. Outstanding game.

29189571.review: Combine the satisfying, exploration-heavy platforming of Metroid with the fluid and forgiving combat of Smash Bros, and you have the foundation of Guacamelee. Add to this how faithful the developers are to Mexican culture, and you have yourself a charming and colorful game. The memes within Guacamelee will date fast, but I was impressed with how the game still managed to engage me outside of the gameplay. It feels as if they were added as a safety net, but Drinkbox makes it pretty clear that they don't need to fall back on pop culture references to create a captivating world. Not quite Grim Fandango, but surprisingly close. One last thing worth noting; if you feel the game could've ended on a better note, keep playing. You'll find some great closure if you do.

29070939.review:
This little indie game of 2013 is a pearl on it's own.

Following the Metroidvania genre, this game is about rescuing a girl while punching skeletons (and some other things) luchador style. In order to progress, you'll learn a bunch of moves that help you navigate the world (a shoryuken to get some height, a ground pound, etc...). Each move can break one type of blocks and while those moves is good for traveling, they works really great for fighting as well.

While the game is mostly inspired by the mexican culture (from the design of the characters and background to the music), you'll find tons of references to other video games franchises. For an indie game, this is some of the smoothest animation I've seen of a 2D game, no movement feel clunky or out of place. Sadly, the different area are a little too cliche and don't expect a deep story, it's about the same level as a Mario game.

The game is filled with collectibles and optional challenges. The difficulty is well balanced (while the beginning seem quite easy, some enemies become tricky to fight and the platforming tight. If it's still too easy for you, you unlock hard mode once you beat the game (basically, enemies has double hp and inflict double damage). The game isn't that long but if you try to 100% it, it'll take some time (it took me ~10h to get all but one achievement : beating the game in hard mode)

You can play local coop in this game to make thing more crazy. There is even a workshop to download custom skins, without altering the gameplay. The sad thing is that the community isn't very active and there isn't that many skins to download (97 for the gold edition, 52 for this one).

Speaking of editions, on PC you can chose between 2 editions : The gold edition and the Super Turbo Championship edition. 
The gold edition is the base game, a port of the original from PS3/Vita.
The STC edition is a tweaked base game with tons of stuff added (new abilities, enemies, areas, etc ...)
Since the price of the STC is just 1€ more than the gold edition, there is no real point to get the gold edition (unless you REALLY want those extra custom skins)

Overall, a really solid game, not that ambitious but with very few flaws. I still would recommand to wait 'till it's on sale though (it dropped below 5€ this last winter sale).

29022588.review:
Decently enjoyable Metroidvania that loves to throw all sorts of aggressive video games references at you.
Revisiting this title sometime after playing the “Gold Edition” and found both enjoyment with and frustration towards similar aspects of the game through both playthroughs. However, I suppose that ‘Super Turbo Championship Edition’ as a tad easier due to adding the Super Meter and perhaps just getting better with time. There is still the insane challenge secrets if you’re looking for some tough stuff to get mad at.

Dislikes:
The, well, Special Moves with the B button usually have a lot of lag on them making some platforming delayed and janky. I get that for combos it’s supposed to feel good when you cancel into them but 
I love references to other games within games but, especially in the town area, it’s a bit much. Keep the references as easter-eggs or subtle things. Don’t just make the power-ups statues straight up Chozo.
Backtracking feels sluggish, there is a sort of dash but requires a wall and a straight shot. There’s a lot of open and straight planes that take a while to traverse with you want to check a lego block that you haven’t smashed yet.

Disclaimer:
[Game playable with four friends. Will make you feel lonely if finished by yourself.]

Basically:
Take it or leave it, it’s not a bad game. Buy it if you like Metroidvanias, have friends around and have some extra cash to spend. Don’t go for 100% unless you have ballz of steel.

Note to self: Lol, review for Gold Edition was very salty. My B.

28572985.review:
Beat 'em up and metroidvania combined? This game makes it work better than you'd think. The moves are integrated seamlessly for both combat and platforming, especially the red and blue moves. And it's actually a good thing that it gets easier to get upgrades as you gain abilities even though they were accessible with an earlier ability. You'll be thankful, as this game goes from somewhat easy but not too easy early on to downright brutal in the later levels, though thankfully not too much harder between any two succeeding levels. Sadly, I lack the raw skill to take down what seems to be the final boss[spoiler]'s true form[/spoiler], though it's still apparent, as it was when I struggled on earlier bosses and level segments, that it really is my own skill keeping me from winning, and it was my own skill that carried me to victory up until now.

The plot and villains are nothing to write home about, but they're still lovable and entertaining and, importantly, carry the excellent gameplay.

The Mexican style is a nice touch, though sadly the style of music is not to my liking (and the boss music especially doesn't sound much like boss music), but I'm being more fair to this game because of that.

So, overall, if you want either a beat 'em up or a metroidvania and can tolerate the other, especially if you'd appreciate both together, this game is for you!
