28385213.review:
Es geht um HÜhner.

Einleitung:
Guacameleea ist ein Mix aus Plattformer, Metroid-Prime, Double Dragon und viel Hommage an bekannte Spieletitel. Ich wollte es zuerst aufgrund der Koopfähigkeit kaufen, hatte aber dann keine kompetenten Mitstreiter gefunden, bzw. überhaupt jemand, der gerne diese Art von Spiel mit mir spielen wollte. 
So unscheinbar es am Anfang auf mich wirkte, sodass ich nach zwei drei längeren Spielesessions die Lust verlor, so hat es daraufhin irgendwann diesen süßlich schweren aromatische Geschmack wie Club Mate entwickelt, der zwar anfangs befremdlich doch dann immer angenehmer wird, bis man schließlich immer wieder gerne davon nippt.

Geschichte:
Man(n) ist Juan, ein Luchador, naja, erst mal ein Junge vom Felde, der dabei zusieht, wie die Tochter des Bürgermeisters entführt wird und nun darauf aus ist, sie zu retten.
Sein Gegenspieler ist Calaca und seine Untergebenen, die alle ihren eigenen Charme versprühen und zu den guten Bosskämpfen gehören, die das Spiel zu bieten hat. Der Humor kommt dabei nie zu kurz, auch wenn mein einglisches Vokabular nicht ausreicht, um alle Verweise 100% zu verstehen.

Spielstil:
Das Spiel ist ein Beat-Em-Up, in dem man von Areal zu Areal wechselt und dort Gegner mit Kombination (Juggling) Würfen und Spezialattacken vemöbelt. Hinzu kommt die Fähigkeit noch auszuweichen, was seinen sehr angenehmen Spielfluss ermöglicht und man gerne auf den Zähler in der linken oberen Ecke schaut, wie viele Treffer man verteilt hat, bevor man selbst getroffen wurde. 
Dabei setzt das Spiel gekonnt auch auf Pausen innerhalb der Ausführung einer Animation, sodass man Angriffe sehr gut aneinanderreihen kann, ohne das Gespür eines Street Fighter Profis besitzen zu müssen. 
Neben den Kämpfen kommen ganz viele Hüpfpassagen ins Spiel. Die sind dabei so großartig und frustierend, aber schaffbar ausgearbeitet, dass diese mir bisher mit am meisten Freude bereitet haben. Wer Rayman Legends gespielt hat und die Herausforderungen mochte, wird auch hier seine Freude haben.
Zu den Richtungen kommt übrigens noch eine weitere Dimension, die man beachten muss, wenn man solche Passagen erfolgreich schaffen möchte. Wer Giana Sisters gespielt hat, weiß, was ich meine. 

Zu diesem kommt das Finden weiterer Fähigkeiten, die wie bei Metroid andere Wege freischalten können.

Grafik
Das Spiel ist konsequent in einem Stil gehalten und der ist angenehm für die Augen, auch wenn manchmal die Charaktermodelle klein wirken. Dafür hat man wiederrum mehr Überblick über die ganze Situation, was bei einer Massenprügelei auch von Nöten ist. 
Das Spiel geizt dabei nicht an Farben, ist aber auch nicht überladen und behält diesen mexikanischen Flair bei.

Sound
Es gibt leider keine Sprachausgabe, aber die Hintergrundmelodie ist sehr unterstützend für die ganze Atmosphäre, sodass man sich selbst fast ein Sombrero aufsetzen möchte um dann getreu die Musik mitzusummen. 

Fazit
Guacamelee macht alles richtig. Es ist nicht zu lang, hat keine unnötigen Strecken, hält sich mit unnötigen Nebenquest zurück und bietet ein gutes Kampfsystem, gute Charaktere, viele Anpassungsmöglichkeiten, Hühner und das für einen ordentlichen Preis

28065250.review: Fantastic Metroidvania with a awesome fighting game mechanics...

28041561.review:
I must admit, I wanted it out of curiosity in the beginning, but I couldn't expect how much fun it could actually be.

The fighting system feels fast, responsive, and with a lot of potential for combos, and juggling enemies in the air. Each move you have has a specific purpose and is clearly differentiated from the others, creating a small yet varied set of tools at your disposal. Yet one can't help but think that a couple more moves wpuld help make battles more varied and interesting. The tactical side of things, later on with the addition of shielded and alternate dimension enemies you can't just  take them all on at once, you have to be more methodical, to decide which targets are a priority, which should be knocked down for later. 

The game can be pretty tactical, yet not so much so as to become slow or unenjoyable. The game doesn't ask you to make big plans about each fight, but to assess the situation and make on-the-fly choices to defeat you enemies in the most efficient, safe, fashion. And that makes it actually rather enjoyable. 

Unfortunately, however, the difficulty from battles comes more from the ammount of enemies rather than the individual enemies themselves. They never really feel dangerous on their own right, all of them being rather slow and having pretty big tells for when they're going to attack, making it easy to avoid them. Instead, the danger comes from having to keep track of a lot of enemies at once. Yet, at the same time, it makes sense, since it helps keep the flow of the game, whereas single, difficult enemies might make it slower. Overall, the combat is good and has quite a lot of potential

The art style is indeed pleasing to the eye, it looks really colourful yet clean and simple. It's nice to look at and adds character to the game, it works with it, whereas a more realistic approach, at least in my opinion wouldn't have been half as charming

However, one thing the game does suffer from, is it's really short length. I finished the campaign in about ten hours, and I really took my time and 100%'d it. And while it's true that it's better to not overstay your welcome and instead leave a good memory, I'd say Guacamelee!, however, left too early, leaving you wanting more but without much else to do, as the game doesn't really have much in the way of post-game content, other than the El Infierno and Caverna del Pollo challenges. Granted the game does have a good ammount of exploration to do to get all the secrets, it rather goes by fast

Another small problem the game has, is it's lack of online co-op capabilities. While it's understanable that it could cause a lot of problems and frustration with an uncoodinated group, it would also be great fun when it worked. It would be a really nice feature to have when your friends aren't available for some Luchador action.

As I have rambled a lot, and with purpose of making the list more approachable, I'll include a list of pros and cons:

Pros:

+Very solid and entertaining fighting style that doesn't get old
+Well differentiated moveset where every move has its clear purpose
+Lots of enemies that make for varied encounters and strategies to beat them
+Colourful and clean artstyle that adds charm to the game and has just enough ammount of detail to not feel boring
+The enemies, thanks to the art style are inmediately recognizable, and thus you are rarely confused about what you should do
+A good amount of costumes, with their own effects, that allow even more variety in your battles, and in my opinion, look pretty nice
+Chickens

Cons:

-The game suffers from a really short length, leaving you wanting more with no real way to ease that craving
-Not much in the way of post-game content. It's a small game
-The movelist, although differentiated, is rather small. It could have done with some more moves
-The platforming requires good eye-hand coordination late-game. Can become frustrating if you have poor reflexes
-A little too heavy on the memes
-No online multiplayer support

The game, overall, is really good and I enjoyed it inmensely. I'm also impressed in how well the extra areas are included in the game, I didn't know they were add-ons until I looked them up due to how well integrated they are. The only real complain I have about the game is the short lenght. It's a small game, but a really good one. I would definitely recommend it

Guacamelee je opravdu výborná hra. Krásně namalovaná, se super soundtrackem a se zajímavým zasazením do (s největší pravděpodobností) Jižní Ameriky. 
Začínáte jako místní pekař, který se připravuje na jakousi slavnost, při které má přijet prezidentova krásná dcera. S tou se znáte, jako děti jste si spolu hráli. Ale jako v každé hře, nic netrvá věčně a radost ze shledání není moc dlouhá, kráska je unesena zlým kostlivcem a vy ji chcete zpět. Díky kouzelné masce se z vás stává Luchador a vy začínáte trestnou výpravu proti všem kostěným obludám  v okolí, zabíjít nepřátele po desítkách, kupujete si speciální oblečení, které má vše plusy a minusy, takže si vyberete nějaké podle svého herního stylu. Nepřátelé (a hlavně bossové) jsou různorodí a nikdy nevíte, s čím přijdou. Hra je sama o sobě těžká, a ještě k tomu se na klávesnici ovládá dost špatně, doporučuji gamepad. 27308106.review:
So, what if instead of a sexy blond babe in power armor, you were a mustachio'd luchador? And what if instead of blasting energy-sucking amoeba, you piledrive skellingtons into the ground? That's basically Guacamelee, a metroidvania with a healthy helping of spicy hot salsa.

Ok, so it's got the Mexican flavour gimmick. What else? How about those supertight controls for that unusually deep combat system for this type of game? Fabulous lucha action in well though-out levels? A surprisingly nice story with memorable characters? Maybe some excellent audiovisual design with a toe-tapping soundtrack? A sense of humor and plenty of Easter Eggs? Split Screen co/op? Chickens?

This game is a champ and probably one of the best metroidvania available on pc.

I rate this game 5 out of 5 bananas.

What my ratings mean:
1 bananas - Crap. Turn around & don’t look back.
2 bananas - Bad. Not really worth it.
3 bananas - Average. For fans of the genre or a sale.
4 bananas - Good. Won't waste your time.

26866554.review:
Moi qui pensais que tout avait été fait dans les jeux de plate-forme, j'ai pris une belle claque en découvrant Guacamelee.
La réalisation de ce jeu est superbe jusque dans les moindres détails.

- Les graphismes colorés tout d'abord, et ce style graphique si particulier.
- La jouabilité impeccable, les commandes répondant au quart de poil (manette Xbox très fortement conseillée). Les actions s'enchainent à un rythme d'une fluidité déconcertante.
- Le gameplay qui introduit de nouvelles possibilités d'actions à mesure du jeu, permettant de bien maitriser les acquis avant l'aller plus loin, et offrant d'avantage de combos à chaque "déblocage" d'une nouvelle manip.
- La difficulté bien dosée. Terminer le jeu reste assez simple, accéder à la bonne fin demande plus d'acharnement. Pour ceux qui veulent s'acharner à récupérer tous les items, il y a du défi. Et le mode difficile porte vraiment bien son nom.
- La musique exceptionnelle, complètement dans le ton. Une mention spéciale au Boss Theme.
- Le rythme, qui alterne correctement les phases de castagne, de plate-forme, et recherche et de dialogue.
- L'humour, du gros LOL en perspective à des moments souvent inattendus. Le titre annonce un peu la couleur.
- Les références geek, le jeu fourmille de détails, de références vidéoludiques, et autres QR-codes. La encore, le "SUper Turbo Chanpionship Edition" du titre est évocateur.
- Le multi sur le même écran, pas testé mais a le mérite d'être présent. Peut constituer une aide précieuse pour venir à bout du mode difficile.
- La capital sympathie, basé sur l'ensemble des critères ci-dessus, au top car on ne s'ennuie jamais.

En bref, une excellente surprise que je recommande plus chaudement que des enchiladas sortant du four !

Con poco mas de 6 horas de juego, me atrevo a escribir este analisis para Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition, el cual es el siguiente:

Apartado tecnico:
[list]
[*]Tenemos un cuidado y colorido apartado grafico (tomando en cuenta que es un port de PsVita) escenario vistozo, buena iluminacion, todo se adaptan a lo que desean reflejar.
[*]Una maquina con caracteristicas decente, lo corre sin problemas (no poseeo un pc poderosa pero si lo suficientemente 
capaz de correrlo sin problemas)
[/list]

Historia
[*]Puede escucharse un poco "normalita", cliche e incluso tosca, pero no es así, todo lo contrario; tenemos una histora buena, con buena narrativa, no podemos pedirle mas a este juego.
[*]Los enemigos son algo que tambien se tomaron del folklor Méxicano, como méxicano me alegra que nos tomen en cuenta.
[/list]

Jugabilidad
[list]
[*]La combinacion de ambos mundos (vivos y muertos).
[*]La secuencia de los combos, no es muy dificil adaptarse a ellos, en unos cuantos minutos de práctica, seras todo un experto.
[*] Los poderes que vas ganando confrome pases juegando, es otro plus que mejora tu experiencia de juego.
[/list]

Banda sonora
[list]
[*] La música suena a su ritmo, tiene muy buenos OST que ambienta perfectamente la escena.
[*]No son lo  mejor que puede haber en el juego pero, le funciona perfectamente. 
[/list]

En conclusión, el juego es bueno, tendras unas 10 horas de juego, 20 si quieres sacar todos los logros que tienen en steam, pero esa ya es cuestion de gustos. Recomendada la compra, mas si lo consigues en rebajas, no puedes perdertelo.

8/10

So from playing both versions of Guacemelee! at 100% achievements, I can give a proper review.

I'd recommend this over gold.

QUE.
JOGO.
BOM.

Tem uma história bem curta, mas se buscar completar 100%, dá umas boas 20 horas de exploração e de uma das melhores experiências de Metroidvania que tive nos últimos tempos. Vasculhar tudo e desenhar todos os mapas por capricho se torna muito recompensador no final, que te dá vontade de começar outro save imediatamente pra completar tudo de novo. 
Comandos precisos; temática muito interessante; diálogos bacanas; cenários lindamente desenhados; trilha sonora também; gimmicks; segredos; easter eggs e referências a memes, videogames, filmes e cultura pop... Um dos melhores jogos indies que já tive contato, e o meu atual favorito na minha biblioteca da Steam. 
Se ainda não tiver a versão original, corre e compra logo e sem pensar duas vezes essa Super Turbo Championship Edition. Tem bastante conteúdo adicional, que vão além de uma DLC: Visuais aprimorados; novas áreas; novo boss; roupas que aplicam efeitos além da utilidade estética; o modo "intenso"; três slots para save (no original, tinha somente um); fases retrabalhadas e aprimoradas... É o suficiente pra até quem tem o jogo original possa aproveitar mais que o suficiente dessa nova versão do jogo, que é de fato a definitiva.
No mais, COMPRE.

25405615.review:
Guacamelee is a Metroidvania style game that takes place in Mexico. It has a nice mix of combat, platforming, with clever writing and charming characters.

The story is simple but is interesting and keeps you motivated to play through. You play as Juan, a simple Agave farmer living the simple life and are asked by the church to help set up for the Dia de Los Meurtos celebration. The priest who asked you there also asked the presidents daughter, who is your childhood friend/sweetheart to show up and help as well, and after a touching reunion she asks you to drop by and say hi. That's when Calaca, leader of the dead rises and attacks, kidnapping the Presidents daughter you and killing you (don't worry, you get better). Now you gotta stop Calaca from merging the worlds of living and dead and save your sweetheart. But your princess is probably in another temple.

The gameplay is pretty solid. Combat flows nicely (in a sort of beat'em'up style) and focuses on trying to juggle enemies to keep a combo going. There are only a few times I felt like I got stopped do to something out of my control in combat, but the penalty is minimal (it usually respawns you in the last room) so it wasn't too bad. In terms of the platforming they make full use of every single mechanic in the game, including an uppercut (that you'll use often as an extra jump), a dash (that you'll use to extend your jump or reposition yourself), wall jumps/climbs/boosts, hell even the headbutt that only stalls you in mid air is used for movement. The only complaint I have about combat is sometimes the controls feel a tad clunky, as in I will use an uppercut and nothing will happen.

Music is catchy, and I never felt bored listening to it. Few games have me go "I just want a new songs" so it was nice to see this avoid that, even if the same song plays for extended periods of time.

As a Metroidvania game it suits the genre pretty well, even if a lot of secrets are pretty obvious where they are (I can jump here, I bet there is something there). This is made more apparent by giant colored blocks that stand out so much you could probably see them from a mile away, and they only restrict you from getting there until you have a set ability. There is only one secret I had to search up a guide for and I still don't know how I was supposed to piece it together. [spoiler]You have to press a switch, run 3 screens over to find a now open hole in the ground that is only apparent if you open up the map and has no other indication[/spoiler].

The game isn't too challenging unless you are going for 100%, and even those parts aren't too terribly punishing. Most punishments just send you a couple screens away.

Also if you like references this game has a LOT. We are talking about posters that advertise "Bust-it Bill", main villain quoting Star-Wars... everything you can think of and more is probably referenced here, even simple memes like TF2's "MENTLEGEN?"


Overall Guacamelee is a solid Metroidvania game that makes great use of all the mechanics it gives. The gameplay is smooth, with only a few issues. Definitely suggest it if you are interested in a good Metroidvania game.

It's not perfect, but it's a blast.

I got this for free on PS4 a while back, and I had some trouble. I decided to purchase it on sale on Steam, so I could enjoy it with my 360 controller. I didn't put it down for 4 days. As far as the gameplay goes, it's the proper amount of infuriating, as a Metroid/Castlevania clone should be. And make no mistake there; don't even waste your time trying to play this without a controller. 

There is little for wrestling fans here, despite the theme. It does a good job being entertaining, and despite a load of DANK MEMES in the set dressing, the game is relatively unobnoxious in regards to visuals. Although I played through the game as Juanita, the main character is entirely silent, and the 


Expect an 8-hour story and twice that if you are a completionist. Or half that if you're a speedrunner, this game is a speeders dream.

Advice: You'll have to use your GPU Vsync because the in-game VSync cuases awful input lag, and without it, there is a bunch of tearing. However, the game runs great, and I've been playing it for days.

25319298.review:
タイトルが某ストリートのファイターなゲームのパロディな通り、
Guacamelee! Gold Editionを無印とするとver1.5といった具合の本作。
GEではお金を使ってパワーアップを購入しないと掴みからの派生技が使えなかったが、
STCEでは最初から使えるようになり、それを前提とした難易度の調整などが入っている。
GEからの魅力はそのままに、STCEでは戦闘中の戦略性や地形を利用した敵の処理など、
様々な追加要素が盛り込まれており正当進化系といえる。

大きな変更点として、比較的序盤からINTENSOというパワーアップ要素が使えるようになった。
ゲージがあるときにこれを発動すると、一定時間攻撃力が爆発的に高まり、
一気に多数の敵を殲滅していくことができる。
使用しなくても普通にクリアは可能だが、ある程度慣れてくると
ここぞという場面でこれを発動し、難敵の集団を一気にノーダメで殲滅するといった
芸当も可能なため爽快感がある。
ただしこの発動中も無敵というわけではなく、攻撃を食らうとダメージは普通に受けるし
敵を倒せないまま効果時間が終わってしまう場合があるため、
いかにダメージを受けないように敵を倒していくか？厄介な敵の動きを
どう止めるか？という戦略性は失われていない。

Hardモードではただ単に敵をぶん殴って倒していれば良いというわけでもなく、
投げの派生技をうまく利用してクラウドコントロールを意識する必要があるなど
テクニカルなプレイングが求められるバランス。

とりあえずGEを1周とSTCEを1周、気に入ったらHardモードをプレイするだけでも
相当楽しめるにも関わらず、たまに80%オフが来る場合があり400円以下で
GE+STCE+サントラが買えてしまうという圧倒的コスパも魅力的。

Just finished the game 100% and I can say, whoo. That was really fun.

On the plus side, first thing that comes to mind is the gorgeous visuals. The whole game is just a work of art from beginning to end. You can probably tell just looking at the screenshots.
The combat system starts out really simple but ramps up with each new ability you get, where by the end of it you're basically an unstoppable LUCHADOOOOOORE and it feels fantastic. <3
If you're into "mexican" music, the soundtrack's pretty damned good too. The one song I didn't enjoy was for the Canal area.
Lastly, ff, the characters are really neat. I love the flame headed alcoholic guy. I actually felt bad after taking him and a few of the others out.
Downsides? I'd say the story feels a little hastily written. Not much there but it works. Kinda like the old school "Princess peach has been kidnapped, gotta go save her" sorta dealio. That and sometimes the challenge is absurdly difficult. I'm looking at you, Sierra mask piece. FUCK YOU.

If I were to rate it, I'd give it like an 8.5/10. Lots to love.
If you like it, also check out Ori and the Blind Forest, very similar feel to it, just with a different theme.

25081824.review:
I have just 100% this game and put in more than 70 hours into this game. So this review will be from the persective of actually playing this game all the way through.

I am a huge metroid fan and this game completely filled that nitch. the progression of added abilties as you go through the game was spot on for me. there are some times were it was annoying having to backtrack. however it is not entirely required if you are not going for 100%. Also there are (olmecs??) to help with the travel so you dont have to run for a hour to get somewhere.

I also enjoyed the RPG elements of the game. being able to upgrade though the money system was a nice perk. the costumes were also a nice touch and came in handy for the inferno rooms to help with different trouble spots

the difficulty ramped up nice and steady. I never felt like it curved up to sharp. The inferno rooms are the hardest part of the entire game so if you are looking for a challenge in this game that is were you should go. It reminded me allot of the VR rooms in bionic commando rearmed.

music, sound and art style are great. I enjoyed the visuals allot and the music was a nice mix of authintic with some electronic elements added to it. A good comparison might be donkey kong country returns. while not the same it has the same illustrated feel.

gameplay was tight however i did have some quirks that i had trouble with. when playing the combo chicken arena i often had issues with the controls pushing juan the oppositie direction of what i pushed. in other wards doing a uppercut to the left instead of the right. breaking the combo fow. outside of this though it wasnt to much of a problem with the rest of the game. I also liked how things were mapped to the controller. in fact the feel there was more like the metroid prime series (visors) then say super metroid. 

as for the beat em up style this game uses. i normally get tired of these type of games. (think heavenly sword, or final fight maybe) but this game switched things up so much i really did not get tired of it tell around the 60 hour mark which was fine as i was playing back through it on hard mode by that time.

speaking of hard mode. It really is hard mode. If you just want to rush through the game and beat calaca hard mode isnt that much harder. you loose more health, there are more enemies, and the bosses have some extra patterns. Now if you want to 100% hard mode, that is difficult. especially the inferno rooms. my advice is try to 100% as much as you can before going to inferno.

In the end i love this game and is one of the games i platinumed this year. I dig the style, the cheesy and funny lines from the NPC were entertaining. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the metroidvania style of games as this is one of the best ones.

25081312.review:
Guacamelee! takes the throne as one of the best 2D action Metroidvania platformers.  It is a giant bag of eye and ear candy with masterful level design, intuitive controls, and a fresh spin on a familiar story.  The pacing feels just right between stages and power-ups.  Some of the platform puzzles can be tricky but rewarding once they're figured out and fun to solve with the arsenal of cool abilities and combos (a controller is pretty much imperative). With plenty of checkpoints and fast travel locations, progression and backtracking never really feel like a chore.  Previous levels are a joy to revisit once Juan (or Tostada) becomes a mighty luchador and can blow through them with ease.  The enemies and bosses are varied and entertaining.  Spend coins to unlock costumes and buffs, all of which make Juan, well, super buff (but with slight nerfs in certain areas depending on the costume).  At a certain point, you will feel like an OP beefcake.

The game does quite a bit of handholding, however, with so many checkpoints and conventient respawn locations.  Sometimes it feels like there is very little at stake, and so Guacamelee! might seem a little too casual for more hardcore gamers.  There are, on the other hand, enough in-game and Steam achievements to warrant multiple playthroughs and serious skill-honing.

24859869.review:
[h1][/h1]

[i]Test effectué par un handicapé, main droite exclusivement pour le jeu[/i]


[b]Catégorie de jeu :[/b] Plateforme/Action 2D

[b]Le principe :[/b] On saute sur les plateformes, on tue les monstres, on ouvre les portes, on récupère un pouvoir, on tue un boss...


[b]La durée de vie :[/b]  6-10h (selon la difficulté, le skill et la volonté de tout explorer)

[b]Jeu fun ? Jeu intéressant ? Jeu pour l'histoire ?[/b] Jeu résolument fun, même dans l’ambiance !

[b]Mon avis développé :[/b] 

Dès le lancement du jeu, on comprend dans quoi on met les pieds : “GUACAMELEEEEEEE SUUUUPEEEER TUUURBO CHAMPIONSHIP EDICHIONE !” en mode Ready To Rumble, et la musique latino qui démarre. Ou plutôt, on est pas bien sûr de comprendre si c’est voulu ou ringard. Et on commence le jeu avec une petite appréhension que ce soit mal dosé (non, faut pas une dose de cheval, Perceval). Mais, sans vous dévoiler tous les gags, c’est au final très réussi ! Ca mêle des histoires de télé novélas, de croyances latinos, de moments kitschs et certains… Vraiment WTF. J’ai une transformation qui me vient à l’esprit, mais je vous laisse la découverte intacte, c’est tellement plus marrant quand on tombe dessus sans le savoir !

Niveau graphismes, son, ambiance : c’est réussi. C’est pas “beau”, mais c’est propre, cohérent, bien fini, bien pensé. C’est agréable, et au service du rire et du gameplay. Même la musique “Old el Paso” ne gave pas ! On sent qu’ils ont été en roue libre sur certaines choses, mais pour notre plus grand plaisir !

Parlons gameplay : il ne fait pas partie des plus précis, ni des plus complexes. On a cependant assez de profondeur de gameplay avec les différents coups puissants, les variantes, les prises, le mode “héros” qui booste les dégâts, les double sauts et rebonds… Et bien d’autres choses encore ! Il y a surtout la gestion entre le monde des vivants et celui des morts : bien switcher vous permettra d’accéder à certains endroits, de trouver d’autres PNJ, de résoudre des passages de plateforme. C’est pas aussi bien fait que dans Outland (niveau précision et technique), mais vraiment rien de rédhibitoire. Vous risquerez de vous énerver un peu sur certains passages de plateforme, mais rien d’horrible non plus. Même les costumes permettent une approche du jeu différente selon les power-ups (plus fragile mais plus puissant, meilleure recharge mais moins de santé, etc…)

Mes seuls regrets sont peut-être la relative facilité de se défaire de la plupart des monstres, et même des boss qui ne demanderont pas forcément un timing précis ni une grande réflexion pour trouver la technique d’approche.

[b]En Bref :[/b] Un très très bon moment que ces quelques heures de Guacamelee ! Alors oui, ça n’est pas le plus beau, le plus précis et le plus fouillé des jeux du genre… Mais c’est certainement le plus drôle, léger, qui met la pêche et la banane, te fait donner des marrons par centaines, bref le jeu des 10 fruits et légumes par jour. On y rejouera peut-être qu’une fois dans quelques années pour la tranche de rigolade et le côté “bon moment”, mais c’est une franche réussite pour moi !

24382744.review:
Because I own over 1000 games, I never really bothered to look at this game before. However, in the 2016 Summer Games Done Quick Marathon, Guacamelee was played and it seemed fun. So I decided to give it a go.

To start, Guacamelee is a platformy fighter kind of game, but since you are reading this review, I'll spare you the trouble of repeating what the description already says. The gameplay is really smooth and really good to say the least. The physics are consistent, the platforms are good, the hitboxes of enemies are consistent and normal, and the game just does a very good job with all the platforming and abilities. To put it short, you won't rage at this game because of some glitch. You have some basic moves and you pick up more along the way which allow you to continue your journey on. The difficulty gets harder and harder as you progress through the story and because you start unlocking more abilities, the need to combo them and use them correctly adds to how it gets harder. However, no matter how hard it got, the game always gave ample save points and checkpoints that wouldn't punish you too much. Some of the platforming parts and fights actually took me so many tries (over 20 with some). The boss fights for this are also very smoothed out. Almost all of the bosses had two "phases" or more where they have a different attack pattern or form. You go in blind, die to their attacks because you don't know what they are and then go in again and learn from your mistakes. It is a Dark Souls type of boss fighting experience, but easier. Lastly on the gameplay, there are a LOT of secrets and extra exploration areas to go to which make the game quite interesting.

Aside from the gameplay, Guacamelee has an interesting story, even if some parts may be intentionally cliche. Since we are on the story, there are certain parts of it that are actually funny and sometimes they even make meme jokes and references. The art of this game is also super crisp and nice. It also features a unique style of art which I enjoyed quite a bit. There is also nothing to complain about with the music as it fits the game perfectly and is just quite good.

Overall, I really cannot find many faults with this game at all. It is just simply fun, smooth, and well done. I really appreciate SGDQ for introducting this game to me and I would recommend this game to anyone.

Rating: 9.0/10
Recommend Price: $10 or under

24288755.review:
Guacamelee is a metroivania platformer set in a cartoonish, hilarious Mexican world. You play as Juan, a humble agave farmer turned undead luchador. As you progess, you will unlock more and more fighting moves to allow you to access new areas. The platforming challenges are very good, and will test your ability to use all of Juans move to progess, or get to hard-to-reach rewards. This game is full of well hidden secrets to discover. The biggest highlight is the combat system. It may feel unintuitive at first, but after some time and additional moves unlocked, you will be dishing out "CARNAGE!" to hordes of unique enemies. The boss fights are also very good as well. It took me about 15 hours to 100 percent the normal game, though the time it takes may vary depending on completion level and skill.

Note: THIS IS THE VERSION OF THE GAME YOU WANT TO GET. Super turbo championship edition has additional levels, challenges, bosses, features, etc. that the gold and original version do not have.

This has become one of my favorite games on steam. I would recommend this to anyone craving a platformer game, especially to someone with a metroidvania craving. The game has enough content that I think it would be a worthwhile buy even at full price. If on sale, BUY IT WITHOUT A SECOND THOUGHT.

24128365.review:
Genre: Lucha Libre-themed Metroidvania beat 'em up platformer.

Caveat: I don't care about player skins or multiplayer, so I refrain from judging those. The story is about saving a damsel and the world. Everything else...

Great sound, visuals, mechanics and level design, with a fresh brand of humor added in. The game is always conveying a feeling of liveliness and the grappling mechanics make the fights interesting. My only (minor) gripes are that the 'Intenso' feels like a cheat, rather than something that the game was designed with in mind, and the side questing and chicken-mode felt underdeveloped.

The gameplay mixes metroidvania-esque exploration with beat'em up combat, with a focus on moves that not only deal damage, but also improve mobility when platforming.

The pacing is good and ends at just the right time imo. I've spent about 18hrs exploring 100% of most areas. The game helpfully shows you on the world map which areas you've fully explored by gilding them; there are 15 areas in total.

Difficulty-wise, it's not hard at all, unless you decide to explore off the beaten path for extra challenges. If you do, you may get a few extra hours' worth of somewhat more difficult gameplay. It's by no means infuriating though, Guacamelee is not and isn't trying to be a super-difficult game.

- All the little details

Cons:

23959295.review:
Skeletons.
Chozo statues.
A talking goat.
Countless references to beloved games and movies.
Hilarious dialogue.
Chickens.
Dimension swapping.
Incredible fighting combos pulled off in mid-air.
Beautifully caricatured Mexican in-game world.

However.... Lime-green shields and yellow shields do not mix with protanopia, unfortunately. I've died multiple times because of that fact.

Update to review:
Having played now to the final area, I've been a bit dissappointed and am knocking some from the score. The endgame, for some reason, shifted gears from super fun combo-happy throw-your-enemies-around-the-screen combat to arbitrarily difficult twitch reflexes and unfair fights. You're required to repeatedly shift dimensions perfectly in time, and one horrific fight required you to cling around on walls and hit enemies in mid-air (using a skill I won't reveal) perfectly or else you fall to your death instantly. When I reached the final dungeon itself (this twitch section was the approach), I discovered hordes of the same enemies I'd been fighting the whole game. The only difference was that this area merely replicated the enemies over and over and over, forcing me to fight ten or fifteen of them at the same time. This may sound like normal game design, but keep in mind that half of the enemies are in one dimension and half in the other, meaning that you can't even damage half of them and they're able just to repeatedly hit at you while you try to deal with the other half. If one enemy gets a hit off on you, you're locked in hitstun for quite a while (every hit in Guacamelee results in Juan being launched off his feet) and only pure luck dictates whether another enemy will hit you before you prepare a dodge. In addition, many of these enemies have green or yellow shields. Again, I have protanopia. When I use trial-and-error to hit at a shield and it's the wrong color, allowing the enemy to hit me back and locking me in hitstun, finally killing me and forcing me to begin the entire battle again because I HAVE A STUPID EYE MUTATION BY NONE OF MY OWN CHOICE, that's frustrating. There are no words to describe how frustrating that is. Imagine strolling along on your favourite nature walk, only to find that someone's set a fire and burned down the scenery only to annoy you. That's how frustrating it is. It's so frustrating, in fact, that this update to review is being written after a ragequit. I rarely, rarely, rarely ragequit.

The endgame is bad. It trades the fun combat of the early game for arbitrarily difficult combat against hordes of enemies. The hordes of enemies don't have a trick to them. There isn't any make-the-floor-disappear-so-they-fall-in-the-lava element to them. It's just you versus an unfair set of skeletons with ambiguously-colored shields. Horrible. Now I'm going to have frustrating nightmares and ragequit my night's sleep.

[strike]9/10[/strike] 8/10 for a Metroidvania.

23777791.review:
You'd think with a title like Guacamelee, this game would have guacamole be some sort of central thing to the plot or something. It's not. The title's just there to sell the game's aesthetic. And you'd think that a game like this that goes so far out of its way to give life to its little cartoon Latin America would try and capitalize on what Latin American culture has to offer in terms of themes storytelling, sort of like what 2015's Book of Life ended up doing, or like what Clover did with Okami and Japanese folklore.

But wow. Not Guacamelee miss its chance to do that, it dives off a cliff to avoid it.

Gorgeous animation, beautifully thematic visual design are all wasted here in a game who's core is bogged down by an overwhelming amount of lame, blatant references to other video games have nothing to do with this one (I still can't wrap my head around the Hotline Miami billboard) and 2013 era memes that not only cringy and extremely dated, but break the immersion the art and music worked so hard to encourage. And if you want to give the game props for being mechanically functional and satisfying, that's fine, but there are better games that are better at even just being metroidvanias than Guacamelee is.
Pair that with writing that's clichéd but alright at best when it’s not busy explaining its jokes and winking to the audience and you’re left with just a hollow, cynical shell of a game that thinks pleasing a crowd is the same thing as being good. It thinks that a cultural aesthetic can be worn and sold like a costume. It's gross, it's cringy, but it's worst of all just plain lazy. And that's a damn shame. 

Don't buy this game.

Guacamelee! es un metroidvania con un arte basado en la cultura mexicana. Apenas sé algo sobre la cultura de México pero este juego se centra sobretodo en la festividad de el Dia de los Muertos, el cual es Patrimonio Cultural Inmaterial de la Humanidad, que no es poco.

El juego es colorido y divertido, repleto de "guiños", que mas bien són homenajes a otros videojuegos más o menos famosos. También cabe destacar el humor propio que esta presente practicamente siempre que se interactua con los demás personajes, ya sean los pueblerinos, los muertos e incluso los propios enemigos. 

Como metroidvania que es, iremos desbloqueando distintas habilidades para poder avanzar y explorar el mapa pero sobretodo para explorarlo y escubrir secretos o bonificaciones extra.

Los logros no son excesivamente dificles para quienes quieran comlpetarlo al 100%. No hay demasiado y algunos solo requieren tiempo y/o dedicación.

Como ya he mencionado, Guacamelee! mantiene el humor durante casi toda la aventura pero en el final y los creditos, al menos a mi, me ha dejado reflexionando y ver como algo tan simple y natural ha estado presente durante toda la experiencia. No es un tema nuevo, pero a mi me ha dejado buen sabor de boca. Todo encaja perfectamente y es simplemente genial. 

En conclusión, compra muy recomendada para aquellos que disfruten de los metroidvania y busquen algo original y sobretodo, con personalidad.

23026109.review:
Dip your chip into this tasty treat.

With Guacamelee: Super Turbo Championship Edition, Toronto-based indie developer DrinkBox Studios mashes up 2D Metroid-inspired exploration and platforming with brawler-style combat, then seasons it all with heavy doses of Mexican culture, video game nostalgia, and lively humor. The 2013 original skipped Nintendo hardware, but luckily Wii U owners get to experience this expanded, definitive take on the game with new areas, abilities, and enemies.

Guacamelee: STCE stars Juan, a lowly agave farmer bestowed with a super-powered luchador mask after a brave--but failed--attempt to rescue El Presidente’s daughter. Juan’s ensuing journey is presented in a cartoony manner that rarely wavers from a peppy, humorous bent, though I found the narrative’s handful of serious notes surprisingly compelling, as well. That being said, the story is never really intrusive. It doesn’t overpower the gameplay, but flavors it well, combining with a Mexican setting and vibe rarely explored in video games to form a vivid, refreshing personality that’s a tremendous asset to the experience.

Juan’s adventure takes him across a series of gorgeously rendered locales, and the Metroid-inspired progression in regards to new abilities yielding newly accessible areas is pervasive throughout. The game does a good enough job with this structure, and its world is fun to explore. There’s always another hidden health or stamina upgrade to be found or perhaps an amusing easter egg referencing video games or pop culture lurking somewhere around. The ability progression makes it so that things really open up over time in terms of combat and navigating the game world.

However, Guacamelee is admittedly a bit lacking when it comes to the pacing and environmental intricacy that are so key to the best titles in the “Metroidvania” genre. For instance, the map is segmented in such a way that environments feel set apart from each other, and there are loading screens separating the individual areas. The maps can be quite well interwoven within these discrete zones, but they don’t overlap with each other in significant ways. Also, the color-coded barriers that gate off areas until the acquisition of the proper abilities seem a bit paint-by-numbers and inorganic. All these elements dissolve a much-desired sense of seamlessness.

Fortunately, other aspects make up for these small deficiencies. Combat in particular improves significantly once more moves are unlocked. In the beginning, battles feel stilted, samey, and very chore-like. In the late game, when enemy types are more varied and the player has a wider array of super-powered moves available, combos become far more creative and stylish. The design structure still tends to rely too much on kill rooms, but the surprisingly deep and fun combat system that emerges over the course of the game mostly mitigates this flaw.

The way new attack moves also increase mobility (e.g., a Dragon Punch-style uppercut allows one to make it to previously out-of-reach platforms) is a nice touch that makes gaining new abilities feel more meaningful and adds extra texture to the game’s solidly-designed gauntlet of platforming challenges.

The only issues with Guacamelee are simply minor quibbles that keep it from true masterpiece status. It’s hard to worry too much about these slight imperfections when the game hits so many right notes, ranging from the lavish presentation to the deep combat and platforming. On the whole, it’s a brisk and refreshing joy to play, with a lively personality that's eminently endearing. Guacamelee is a fantastic Metroid-inspired platformer that shouldn’t be missed.
Summary
Pros

    Exploration is a joy
    Fun presentation and personality
    Nice ability progression
    Outstanding art style and graphics
    Surprisingly deep combat

Cons

    Imperfect implementation of Metroidvania structure
    Overreliance on kill rooms

23007788.review:
Wow! Bought this game on a steam sale years ago and just finally got bored enough to play it and with my little expectations I was BLOWN AWAY.

Everything from the art style, to the humor, to the gameplay, even the narrative left a very postive taste in my mouth. It's like a 2d version of my favorite game of all time ocarina of time. You go to a new place get a new power to help you solve incresingly diffacult puzzles just like a zelda, but this game adds in interesting challenges by adding moderately difficult platforming while fighting against hordes of baddies.

The action is everywhere, if I had to nitpick i'd say there are too many enemies, but a large portion of the enemies are optional battles. That being said combat is very fun. Its easy to string hits but you can do some pretty narly combos. And I love how baddies scale in this game, instead of taking a billion hits to kill late game they just start to dodge and become pseudo boss attack patterns.

And each area concludes with a boss battle. The inner sadist in me wishes they were harder, but they are epic feeling. Every boss is unique, has a progression to how they attack, and once you figure out their patterns are very rewarding to kill.

The narrative is pretty moving. The plot is pretty straightfoward but the combination of the art style and the unique setting of the game really helps disguise the fact that it is basically dude rescues the princess platformer. The characters are memorable, the dialog is good and the cutscenes are powerful.

The comedy style of this game is gold for me I could see it being a detterant for someone who wants their game to be taken seriously, but its an indie game. At one point the devs run out of new ability names so they litterally say sorry we ran out of names and give you a move called "Dashing Derpderp".

I just beat the game on regular mode, but in order to get the complete narrative I have to go back and play on a new game plus type deal and I'm ECSTATIC. I wanted to replay the original game almost immediately after beating it it was so good, but now I have a reason to continue gaming.

10/10

También consiguió frustarme algún que otro mapa extra-complejo de plataformas que tuve que abandonar, o retos del infierno de hacer super combazos... Ni de coña lo he completado al 100%, requiere tiempo y skills, no me parece un juego fácil. Al menos para hacérselo entero. 

Jugabilidad, apartado artístico, diseño de niveles y música sobresalientes, tengo varias melodías de trompeta grabadas a fuego en el tímpano desde que lo jugué! 

Tiene multijugador local de hasta 4 jugadores, lo que es un auténtico puntazo. 

Juégalo! Por el amor del Pollo!!! Ah! y dale recuerdos a Error  :D

Gold Edition is good, but the Super Turbo Championship Edition is far superior!

This game let's you play as "Bad Ass" Danny Trejo in a gimp mask & apparently all the women (in this game) love themselves a side order of burly tattoo chested gimp mask wearing Danny Trejo.

Do I recommend this game? [i]¡por supuesto![/i] - of course.
Why? Because it's a [i]hell-of-a-lot-o-fun![/i]

22582891.review:
[h1]Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition——墨西哥超级英雄大混战超级冠军版
                                                              拆.EP1[/h1]

墨西哥超级英雄大混战已经是一款较为久远的游戏了，但即便将其放到现在的市场，也绝对会是一颗耀眼的明星作品。前段时间看到Drinkbox今年将会推出新作，就想起来还可以写一篇庆祝一下。
就让我们来看看这款优质银河战士恶魔城游戏的要素，特点以及先来一点购买建议吧。

Warning：全文建立在单独观察该作体验的情况和对该类游戏的浅薄理解下，并不因为其游戏的某些致敬成分就认为是故意模仿，若有问题恳请指出。

TL；DR：墨西哥超级英雄大混战的背景，音乐，艺术风格都与当地的“死人节”文化息息相关，水平相当优良，游戏本身内容丰满，可以提供5~10小时的一周目体验，后续还有挑战和Hard mode等追加，但是在关卡设计上有可以商榷的地方。
        打击感较强（主要依赖于人物速度的强烈变化），但是在操作上偶尔会有一些失灵感觉。BOSS设计上有那么点缺乏魄力，整体来说战斗在游戏中的表现欠佳。但在能力与关卡的结合上做的不错，却也有过犹不及的嫌疑。总体来说是一款远超及格线，
        但是也有缺陷的作品。

        8/10 +整体艺术水平和执行力 +别出心裁的打击感设计 +能力构造出的连击系统丰富
             -BOSS设计 -关卡设计
       建议购买人士：银河战士恶魔城类游戏玩家（不过相信你们应该都有了！）Platform类爱好者
      不建议购买人士：路痴
[h1]--------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/h1]
1：游戏结构
   作品与传统的该类游戏略有不同，因为时代和机能的不同，作品在推出了主题化关卡的同时将其联系起来，形成了一个闭环。每个关卡相对而言有其内蕴的与背景有关的跳台特色，这也是这个作品相对于大部分该类游戏其实更偏向于一个平台游戏的原因。游戏的流程基本就是跳台，强制的小范围战斗，跳台。因为怪物掉落的不稀有，使得大部分的战斗环节可以略过。小规模的强制战斗一般只是给予生命值或体力值升级的1/3，或者是用来购买服装（有特定加成和DEBUFF）的骷髅币，作者在装备系统上的不制作使得游戏战斗的反馈感下降了很多。大部分游戏使用的是以战养战（材料式的成长曲线较缓，掉宝式则更有抖动感也升级更快）而让战斗有效的融入流程，甚至完全指导流程，而墨西哥超级英雄大混战则选择将升级系统扁平化，同时让山羊老爷爷提供的多种多样的能力来开拓游戏流程。在没有足够剧本的情况下，支撑一个短小的游戏是足够的，但是这款游戏已经超过了5h，尤其在后期能力本身因为需要被束缚在体系内而不能拥有更多表现力的时候，会出现一定的枯燥感。

2：战斗系统——释放的潜力和自由的代价。
   战斗系统值得大书特书的就是通过延长滞空，硬直，和前置动画带来的速度感。力量感与敏捷感不同，不是来自于行云流水，而是一拳力震山河的爆发。作为搏击手的luchador，每个动作都是瞬间提速瞬间减速，这种另类的爽快感构建方式在我看来是比无双类更为聪明的，我打人如果我很用劲对方不动，显得我很傻，而如果突出对方被打飞这一感觉才真正能有反馈。无双则选择吸住，用堆人放大效应，具体的以后再聊。但是与此同时，游戏的战斗系统可以说因为一些硬直的放大变得非常简单了（？）想要构建Combo,没有太多的门槛，Combo的极为轻松使得玩家所以为了平衡作者给后期的怪物加上了两层防护，维度切换和需要特定技能才能爆破的防护罩。再用恶心的配组去麻烦你。而这也使得游戏的战斗难度变得非常的浮动。不同技能的防护罩虽然看起来权值是一样的，但在实际战斗中完全不同。因为游戏流程本身关卡数量并不少，在游玩中总会有“这关这个地方比后面难多了“的感觉。每个技能为了完成其预定的位移效果，实际上的使用权重也不同，并不是按获得次序上升的，这其实某种意义上很糟糕，但是在硬核玩家那里无所谓（硬核玩家一般会更重视一些去切合定义的内容，为了这个舍弃反馈曲线都在所不惜，这也是"Retro"的来源。因为这种“文化”的重现比基本的反馈会更让他们开心）。设计上更加奔放，就自然而然会影响到整个体验。

3：游戏地图的构造疑问
   游戏为了拥有大量可探索地点并在同时合理的引导玩家去探索，设置了用特定技能才能破坏的石头。在同时，游戏经常会在主路上设置一些很明显的半裸露的石头，告诉你“这块有个密道可以出来哦”，或者是在一道坑左右设置三个不同的支路，但你进去一看发现全是老三样掉落，这种强行加入的跳台解谜段落就像给老玩家那些甜食主义者的甜点（问题是根本就不抱），却也与现代的流程有很大的龃龉感。游戏用维度切换构造的一些跳台机关确实是颇具匠心，
[h1]下段讨论的设计其实是银河战士的致敬向，暴露我太年轻了...[/h1]
[spoiler]但其实游戏的流程基本也就耗费在跑路上，走到一条路的头，发现有块石头，然后就要回头找支路，找山羊头，然后过去。问题就在于 石头的提示性过大。一般的游戏有的时候也会设计能力门槛，但那大多不会给提示，而是让玩家先尝试，发现做不到之后再找其他思路，在拿到能力之后就会有恍然大悟之感，在调动玩家情绪方面会聪明的多，因为这是玩家“自己想到的”，而不是你像交警一样立一块牌子告诉你禁止通行的。[/spoiler]
 
[h1]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/h1]

尾言：如今游戏市场，尤其是独立游戏市场正在一个巨变期。过去被我们视为稀有的种种力图带来复古游戏感觉的游戏变得非常多了，很多概念，先是本来硬核却在实际意义上越来越休闲的Roguelike，再是越来越现代化的Couch-Coop,甚至还有Pixel这种Art Style，从几年前的刚刚复活，已经隐隐有炒作过头之嫌。但是凡是扎实的作品，只要你的游戏不反逻辑，不反商业（除非你是Jonathan Blow)，一般都还能卖得不错。

     无论是哪里的读者可能都会问，你喷了这么多为什么给他打8分？请看上面的+后面的内容。其实最主要是第一条。这也是我个人的建议。拼Concept的转化力，国内的理论水平还早着呢。相对来说可能这个第一条，还要好做一点。

22575125.review:
本来以为是个爽快的ACT，没想到是手残勿入的跳平台游戏。

作者把智慧都用在了关卡如何跳过，还有两个世界的切换，这和DMC如出一辙，完全破坏了游戏的乐趣，是完全破坏。

敌人弱智突突突就可以死了，你学到的所有招数，都是用来跳平台过密道的。

游戏的音乐太差了，本以为是热血的游戏，哪怕是快节奏的幽默感，应该配上令人热血沸腾的音乐，但是非也。这个游戏的音乐让你昏昏欲睡，这是ACT大忌。

最最差评的，就是语音，没有语音。没有任何语音，而你又在跳来跳去，打怪也不过啪啪啪，那么你就只能听到一些轻松催眠的BGM。

最后，剧情行进方面，是类似RPG一样你一个个去找NPC点，简直闷到家了，你会有种感觉是，看游戏介绍似乎是很激情很炸裂的妹子啊！然后上了床发现是咸鱼，有事没事翻一翻。

你玩的时候觉得世界好乱，路好乱，晕死了，一阵子就找不到北。此时你会发现，对啊！我可以看MAP！打开MAP你会发现你更迷路了！！！！

而对于这种迷宫一样，多层次、多入口甚至有两个次元切换的游戏，想不迷路最好的办法是什么？——就是你遇到一个地方过不去，你就一定要过去！否则以后你就不知道你卡关是因为哪一个门没通过了！

而问题是这游戏就是有些地方你一开始过不去的！你必须通过后面的剧情拿到一些能力才能过！卧槽谁记得啊！就算记得！辛苦通过的一段平台又要重新跳一次才能到达那个卡位，我去你大爷的老子不是来玩这种乐色的！



怎么说呢，美工非常出色，可是美工展现出来的热情，完全被其他方面浇熄了。有些游戏是败絮其外金玉其中，而有些游戏是金玉其外败絮其中，这个游戏是后者。


这个游戏大失所望，已退款。

22465739.review:
[quote=][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/12146432-La-Cruceta-Inquieta/][b]La Cruceta Inquieta[/b][/url], mentor de Steam[/quote]

Tras el limitado ciclo de vida de un videojuego, el paso de los años y, con suerte, alguna que otra reedición, al final, y de forma natural, otros nuevos ocuparán su lugar y superarán los conceptos que en él y en su día fueron exitosos y rompedores. No obstante, como en todo, un selecto grupo logrará resistir el embate del tiempo, permaneciendo en nuestra memoria e inspirando futuras creaciones. Esto es lo que me atrevo a aventurar que ocurrirá (y puede que ya esté ocurriendo) con Guacamelee!, que aún no ha perdido, y dudo que lo haga, nada de la frescura que en su momento lo llevó a convertirse en uno de los "indies" más apreciados desde la popularización y el asiento de esta forma de crear o entender los videojuegos. Y es que el mundo indie permite rebuscar en lo ya ensayado (y muchas veces ya olvidado o, aparentemente, ya superado) para encontrar sus puntos fuertes y actualizarlos en su aplicación en nuevos productos adaptados a los nuevos tiempos.  Así, Guacamelee! no oculta sus influencias e incluso las homenajea en lo que muy posiblemente sea un gesto de gratitud a la obra de otros diseñadores y programadores que dejaron su huella con anterioridad. Guacamelee llegó rescatando viejas fórmulas para actualizarlas y aportar su granito de arena en la perpetuación de ese género tan acertadamente denominado "metroidvania".

El videojuego que nos ocupa nos cuenta la historia de Juan, un mexicano de a pie que ve cómo su tranquila y apacible vida se transforma repentinamente en una aventura para rescatar a su amiga de la infancia de las garras de la mismísima Muerte. Tan "prometedora" puesta en escena no llega en realidad a mucho más, ni a nada trascendental, puesto que lo verdaderamente importante de Guacamelee! es su jugabilidad. No obstante, la ingente cantidad de guiños que nos harán rememorar viejos tiempos y otras sagas y situaciones, así como el carisma de sus personajes y el cuidado con el que todo se ha llevado a cabo, consiguen hacernos mantener el interés y la empatía hacia el devenir de sus protagonistas, logrando que sí percibamos la aventura como una progresión de eventos memorables. Además, el hecho de que aun siendo una historia fantástica tome como base la cultura e historia (desde los mayas hasta la actualidad) de un país real (México, aunque no se haga mención explícita), hace que en cierta medida podamos reconocer costumbres, expresiones artísticas, atuendos, creencias, maneras de hablar y de ser que, pese a estar estereotipados con humor, acercan la trama a la realidad y, por tanto, la hacen más reconocible y capaz de captar nuestro interés.
Para concluir este apartado con una pequeña nota al respecto de esta edición en concreto, "Super Turbo Championship Edition" cuenta con puntuales añadidos en su argumento (y que afectan a su jugabilidad y duración) y que, al contrario de lo que pudiera parecer, se encuentran completamente integrados dentro del videojuego original hasta el punto de que no nos percataremos de ello a no ser que consultemos el contenido de las primeras versiones del mismo, si no las hemos jugado ya.

Su diseño gráfico y artístico es fantástico, original y posee una personalidad propia. Pocos juegos tienen un despliegue tan colorido y a la vez tan sólido como el del que hace gala Guacamelee! Todo está diseñado con un estilo "cartoon" que logra plasmar con acierto ciertos aspectos de un país tan lleno de contrastes como México, donde lo colorido puede convivir con la, para otras culturas, oscuridad de la muerte. Así, ya sea en el caso de los personajes o en el de los escenarios, el estilo de dibujos animados se mezcla con los estilos inspirados en la cultura más o menos reciente o en la histórica (maya) de dicho país para crear un mundo fantástico en el que a cada paso reconoceremos elementos o situaciones propias del mismo o, en el caso de estar estereotipados, de la imagen que el resto del mundo, seguramente sin mucho acierto, tiene de él. Los efectos gráficos, al igual que el resto de elementos, apoyan y están a la altura del "festival de colores".

El apartado sonoro nos presenta animadas composiciones que, si bien no estoy muy seguro de que tengan algo que ver con la cultura musical de México, logran amenizar los combates con ritmos en el que las notas aportan el correspondiente toque de color como ocurre en los apartados gráfico y artístico. De igual forma, los efectos sonoros son igual de contundentes que sus correspondientes en el apartado gráfico, generando un ambiente en el que los combates se suceden con absoluta naturalidad y fluidez dentro del "gameplay" general. 

Llegados a este punto, restaría hablar de la jugabilidad, aspecto no marginal en Guacamelee! puesto que en realidad se trata del pilar principal de su éxito. Tal y como se ha comentado al principio, Juan, el protagonista, se embarca en un aventura en la que muy pronto dejará de ser un tranquilo hombre rural para convertirse en un luchador de ese deporte también tan mexicano como es la lucha libre. Por tanto, ésta se convertirá en el pilar principal del que se ha hablado y lo hará en base al género popularmente conocido como "metroidvania" por contar como precursores a las sagas Metroid de Nintendo y Castlevania de Konami. Así, los continuos y enormemente variados combates (esto último gracias a sus múltiples mecánicas en reflejo a la progresión de los poderes de nuestro personaje) se suceden entre segmentos de juego "plataformero" aderezado con un trasfondo de exploración y aventura que no podremos abandonar hasta haber completado en su totalidad. Además, si algo también es característico de este tipo de juegos es su dificultad, algo en lo que Guacamelee! no se queda atrás y es capaz de ofrecer una curva de aprendizaje bien ajustada para cualquier jugador, pero sin dejar de proporcionar determinados retos que pueden llegar a convertirse en una pesadilla para jugadores menos experimentados pero que satisfarán las ansias de dificultad de los más exigentes. Respecto a esto, cabe recomendar una segunda partida en el modo difícil para disfrutar de Guacamelee en todo su esplendor. Como puede verse, ya sea por la dificultad, los retos o la posibilidad de enfrentarnos a una segunda ronda más exigente, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition posee una duración considerable y de la cual, con total seguridad, disfrutaremos de principio a fin.  

Una vez más, se hace obligatorio comentar que la edición "Super Turbo Championship Edition" incluye nuevos poderes y enfrentamientos contra nuevos jefes perfectamente integrados en el total y que harán de Guacamelee! un videojuego, si cabe, más disfrutable. No obstante, y para quien pueda interesarle, también es cierto que esta edición posee un menor número de logros desbloqueables que la "Gold Edition".

Para concluir, no cabe sino recomendar Guacamelee! en cualquiera de sus versiones puesto que, independientemente de  los elementos exclusivos de cada una de ellas, es uno de los "indies" y "metroidvania" más sólidos y disfrutables hoy día y que muy posiblemente siga siéndolo hasta que le llegue el momento de formar parte de ese selecto grupo de videojuegos atemporales del cual en un principio recibió la inspiración.

22244376.review:
Guacamelee! STCE is the definitive edition of the Guacamelee game, If you're a new player, you should buy this edition.

But should you buy this game?

I like the game's colourful existence with its stunning 2D graphics and detailed art.Its combat system, while limited in moves, has real depth in how you utilise the moves to create combos. Punching an enemy till it's grappeable, throwing it up in the air, uppercutting it again, and then jumping  above it to belly splash is fun to do , never gets old and you get rewarded for it. 
This is a game that loves its combat but there's another thing that it loves. Platforming.

See, this particular Metroid/Castlevania hybrid just loves platforming. Whilst the two games mentioned in the previous sentence aren't too too heavy on platforming, Guacamelee revels in mixing platforming in a 2D space and combat. While you rarely have to platform and fight at the same time, you will be doing a lot of both throughout this 10-12 hr game. I'm not the biggest platforming fan, myself and if you're not a platforming fan, be wary that this game as a lot and some of it is quite tough. The game is lenient in the main path , giving you plenty of checkpoints but sometimes the platforming gets a bit much.

However, the worst part of the game is the music. It's awful. Made with a Latin American style (lots of Mexican type instruments which escape the mind), most tracks are dull, repititive and just boring.There isn't even a boss theme for the myriad of bosses you fight! I recommend putting on your own tunes or podcasts when playing the game, The meme humour in the game also gets a bit much as well. Memes usually are outdated in minutes and while there are numerous nods to many different franchises and games, it might elicit a groan every now and then,

In the end, decide if you want a 2D action/exploration game with a focus on combat and platforming. It's an OK ride but be wary of the music. It's terrible.

22178571.review:
Well, I got this game for just a dollar and then some, but now it's my favorite platformer; I haven't played a lot of them (only Mega Man Powered Up, Ultimate Ghosts 'n' Goblins, and Castlevania 1 come to mind), but I can definitely say that this is the most fun I've had out of the genre.

Visually it's super stylish. The music is fantastic (lalalai lalalai lala~, and the switching soundtracks across the World of the Living and the World of the Dead is amazing), and there are soundbites that I can't help but shout when they play (INTENSO!!!). It's also occasionally hilarious (the power-up cutscenes are gut-bustingly funny). The combat is a lot deeper than it looks - not only are your special moves important for keeping up your spectacular juggle combos, they are also necessary to break certain shields later into the game that makes battles a little more strategic. While most enemies are complete chicken feed, the bosses are most definitely not. Still, none of the combat sections are frustratingly difficult, so no need to worry about being discouraged.

EDIT: I just 100% all achievements and finished the game on Hard mode - I retract my statement regarding the combat sections since I had a difficult time in several fights, particularly Flame Face, as well certain Intenso-dependent sections. I was surprised by the X'Tabay difficulty spike, so...yeah. It gets way harder. I've seen some videos of pre-STCE Jaguar Javier, and it's insanity. Thank God they turned it down here. Having Intenso really helped with the difficulty spike, which is why I recommend you get the Intenso boosts (ESPECIALLY THE SHIELD BREAKER OR YOU'RE GONNA HAVE A BAD TIME) immediately, but only after getting the stun boost first.

What I think what makes this a very notable platformer for me is the difficulty of the platforming puzzles - the last time I was so close to giving up was the Grim Reaper stages in Castlevania, and Guacamelee's Tree Tops brought back all that rage and frustration. Actually, you can opt to ignore in my opinion the hardest sections in the game (Tree Tops and Cueva de la Locura) and still finish the game (albeit the bad ending), but I wasn't having any of that.

It's an amazing game with a lot of mileage for its price, highly recommended! You get the soundtrack too, which is pretty sweet (love Deserto Caliente)!

EDIT: GUACAMELEE 2 IS COMING BABY

21858973.review:
Guacamelee! 
Visto alle apparenze potrebbe sembrare un semplice gioco platform, ma questo titolo si è rivelato essere una piacevolissima sorpresa !
Vestirete i panni di un Luchadore, Juan, che cercherà di salvare la bella fanciulla rapita dal malvagio Calaca, necessaria per il compimento del suo piano, cioè quello di rendere univoci il regno dei morti con quello dei vivi. 
La struttura del gioco è in sè semplice : abbiamo vari scenari con nemici, zone accessibili solo attraverso alcune abilità che sbloccherete man mano durante il gioco e che vi toccherà quindi ripercorrere, boss di turno e piccole quest facoltative.
Nulla di nuovo da un normale platform insomma, eppure in Guacamelee ho trovato qualcosa in più !
 Innanzitutto gli scenari incredibilmente variopinti, con moltissimi riferimenti videoludici, rendono l'atmosfera coinvolgente e oltre a ciò una nota di merito vanno sicuramente alle musiche e allo stile puramente messicano !
I dialoghi vi strapperanno sicuramente qualche risata e il gioco risulta essere fluido.
Discreto livello di difficoltà (devo vedere ora in modalità difficile) con zone rompicapo ben fatte e non snervanti.
Il gioco insomma è piacevole e me lo sono goduto dall'inizio alla fine, assolutamente coinvolgente e senza difetti da sottolineare.
Da avere se siete amanti dei platform ma tranquillamente giocabile e godibile da tutti i videogiocatori.

-Al

21777526.review: Que tal um metroidvania que foge das temáticas comuns do gênero e resolve construir um mundo que respira o México? Este é Guacamelee, uma fórmula que deu muito certo e casou tudo muito bem tudo, nos mínimos detalhes. A música e o visual lembram bem este país, bem como o enredo, que trata da morte de uma maneira bem festiva, já que o Dia de Los Muertos é uma data a ser celebrada por lá. Juan, um homem simples do campo, vai ao encontro da filha do presidente, que é sua amiga de infância, para que juntos fossem às festividades deste feriado. Contudo, surge Calaca, um vilão poderoso que captura a jovem e acaba com a vida do protagonista, mas este consegue voltar com uma máscara, tornando-o um Luchador. Como um típico metroidvania, você consegue poderes novos à medida que avança e poderá retornar em cenários já explorados para descobrir segredos. Aventure-se com até mais três pessoas, mas duas no total já faz as coisas ficarem interessantes sem muita zueira, ou pode ir sozinho, que fica até mais difícil. Ele possui dois finais, sendo que o verdadeiro é possível desde que você consiga as seis partes de máscara espalhadas em diversos desafios. Ainda, o jogo faz um ótimo trabalho nos quesitos plataforma e golpes, além de usar de maneira inteligente da mecânica de viagem entre o mundo dos vivos e dos mortos para resolver as mais variadas situações. E pare para notar as numerosas referências, principalmente a outros jogos, espalhadas. Vai lá e... hasta la vista!

21604259.review:
[h1]来自墨西哥的超级大杂烩，绝对的美味佳肴[/h1]

浓郁的墨西哥风情充斥着这款游戏的每一个角落，这款游戏带给我如此多的惊喜与满足，感觉就像品尝了一道地道的墨西哥盆菜--美味，新鲜，口感丰富。完美！我甚至觉得这款游戏的水准和表现出来的素养值得墨西哥政府为他拨款以示支持。作为一款游戏，在愉悦玩家的同时还用栩栩如生的方式展现了一个风情万种的墨西哥，引人入胜，甚至不由得对墨西哥这个国度产生好奇与向往。这款游戏的亮点和优点如此之多，还请让我慢慢道来。

首先，我觉得这是目前我在steam平台玩到最优秀的类恶魔城游戏，我觉得这款游戏才能真正的称为一款墨西哥版本的恶魔城，甚至在许多地方还要超越恶魔城，作为无数恶魔城的模仿者的一员，Guacamelee真正做到了青出于蓝而胜于蓝。

画面-10/10

剪纸风格的画面，色彩绚丽，缤纷夺目。从茂密幽静的森林，到热闹繁华的都市；从寒冷凛冽的雪山，到炎热难耐的沙漠；从玛雅的肃穆神庙，到本土的热闹节日。这款游戏从头到尾不会让你有一丝一毫的视觉疲劳感，到达新的地图，就能看到一个用剪纸风格展现的不同世界。永远在给予玩家不同的视觉感受，整个游玩过程中，很少有重复感。

更值得一提的还有整体美术风格[strike]抱歉[/strike]，下面这个词可能要出现许多次：[i]浓郁的墨西哥风情[/i]扑面而来。敌人到boss到主角，甚至场景中的存档点，都带有明显的墨西哥特色。比如斗鸡，比如亡灵节，比如墨西哥摔跤。漂亮的sugar skulls，墨西哥特色的服饰等等等等.....

[b]是的，你就是在看一个剪纸风格的墨西哥。[/b]


音乐-9/10

[i]浓郁的墨西哥风情[/i]又来啦！
音乐整体都带有明显的拉丁音乐风格，热情，奔放。同时也很好的表现了墨西哥音乐的特色，让你一耳朵就能辨别出来不同。
每一个不同的场景都配有相应的bgm来一起帮助营造氛围。虽然没有好听到让人过耳不忘，郎朗上口，也远不如ori中的配乐大气恢弘令人战栗。但是作为一款游戏的背景音乐，Guacamelee的表现已经令人挑不出刺来。永远不会需要你自配bgm，更不会重复到令人产生审美疲劳。你只需要在游玩的同时，被游戏恰到好处的墨西哥音乐感染就好了~


剧情--9/10

剧情整体只是中规中矩，台词的撰写倒是透出一股子幽默的味道。[spoiler]隐藏结局的设定为游戏增色不少[/spoiler]
但是在剧情外，被我个人认为和剧情相关一些内容却非常值得称道。

首先就是反派的塑造，这款游戏的反派不仅仅是恶人那么简单，他们有自己的故事，有自己的性格，有自己的理。虽然台词不能算多，但是仅仅寥寥几段话，加上丰富的肢体语言，已然把一个生动的角色形象呈现在了玩家的眼前。

支线任务和npc的设计水准虽然仅仅是普通rpg的水准，但是作为一款类恶魔城游戏能想到并愿意花时间和笔墨设计一些无关紧要的npc、编出一些有趣的台词、弄一些找东西的小任务供玩家消遣休闲一下，我觉得已经算是难能可贵了。在紧张的战斗之后，兜一兜逛一逛墨西哥小城，看看他们的生活，听听他们的牢骚，也挺有趣的不是么？

最后不得不提的是这款游戏充斥着各类恶搞和彩蛋，游戏制作者绝对是一个铁杆游戏粉，太多经典形象了，从塞尔达到瓦里奥再到银河战士，都能看到他们的影子。让我感受到的就是满满的诚意。

游戏性--9.5/10
流畅爽快的操作手感，某些场景的强制战斗，注重连招的同时也不忘强调回避，还有多样的投技作为连招的终结技。在战斗系统上比起恶魔城和银河战士的run&hit，有更强的操作性。称他为2D的墨西哥[i]战神[/i]，一点也不为过。更难能可贵的是打击手感优秀得令人起疑，完全不像是传统的注重真实而忽略打击感的欧美游戏。

地图探索率，和隐藏的宝箱延续了恶魔城的优秀血统，[strike]简直就是强迫症患者的噩梦啊！[/strike]笑

地图和关卡的设计也很好的利用了能力系统。虽然充斥着老前辈们的影子，但是经过[i]浓郁的墨西哥风情[/i]的包装，完全不会令人觉得无聊或是厌烦。

然而扣分点在于：Guacamelee虽然令人欲罢不能，但是却让人难以满足。经过如此长时间的等待，终于发现一款类恶魔城佳作。但是他却没有丰富的武器系统，也没有丰富的收集要素。敌人到最后有些换汤不换药的感觉，多少有了一些重复感。虽然敌人的招数设计简练，也各有特色，但比起恶魔城中姿态各异的多种多样的恶魔，的确是差了许多。因为这些，实在是有点美中不足。
[spoiler]宝箱多是能力提升的道具和金币，然而金币在后期能力买满的情况下并没有什么用[/spoiler]

综合评价--9.5/10

不可多得的神作，一道真正的为横版动作类游戏爱好者精心烹制的佳肴。
只要你可以接受并感兴趣，从Guacamelee开始接触类恶魔城或者是墨西哥，都是不二之选~
[spoiler]我才不会说我是BAD ENDING通关呢，GE要求道具的最后两个碎片太虐手残了QAQ[/spoiler]

21597315.review:
A solid Metroidvania and a light character action game wrapped in a slick Lucha libre Flash animation-style presentation. Exudes style and confidence, with great level design and the brilliant use of its special attacks both for combat roles and for platforming and puzzle-solving purposes.

Unlike most Metroidvania games, there is minimal backtracking, with each area being mostly its own self-contained "Zelda dungeon" of sorts. This is neither a good or bad thing, as backtracking and no backtracking can both have their advantages (one to familiarize the player with the game world, and the other to focus on progression)—but unlike, for example, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, the moments when you [i]do[/i] have to backtrack aren't exceedingly terrible. Of course, there are plenty of opportunities to return to areas to find secrets and upgrades.

If I had to complain, there's too many memes awkwardly crammed onto billboards in the game's backgrounds. And buyers beware: the discount for owning the original Gold edition of Gaucamelee no longer applies.

21501637.review:
The first thing that surprised me in Guacamelee was obviously the setting. The mexican theme is great. Although i don't know much about mexican culture to know if the game is respectful of it, i appreciate how colorful the game is. Even the "World of the Dead" is full of bright colors. Every single environment is just a joy to discover, because it's all so different than most games.

The second thing that surprised me was the gameplay. Based on the trailers, I was expecting a pure beat them all, but it's actually a fairly original mix of a beat them all and metroidvania (a platformer with a huge map where you acquire new powers to unlock new parts of the map). The two genres are well implemented, and complements each other very well. 

On the beat them all side, you've got an array of attacks available, and it's fairly easy to chain them together, which makes it easy to get huge combos. It's always satisfying to reach 50, 100, or even more than 100 hits combo. Every few screens, you will enter an "arena", where you need to be able to beat a serie of enemies before the exits are unlocked.

On the metroidvania side, you've got lots of platforming, and your beat them all attacks also serves as ways to reach platformers. An uppercut to reach higher ground, a dash to go farther away, etc. As with any metroidvania there is a fair bit of backtracking to do to uncover all secrets, but all secrets are "fair": the game give you tons of hints as to where they are, there is no random guessing to do, and the game gives you a completion rate on each map so you know if you've missed something or not.

Another aspect where the game is fair and fun, is the platforming. Like any metroidvania, there is a fair bit of jumping around, and combining your powers to reach the hardest parts of a level. However, the great thing about Guacamelee is that if you fail a jump, the game will teleport you right back to the last platform you were on rather than throwing you at the previous checkpoint, which might be quite far away. So even though they are some fairly difficult parts, you're never forced to play huge sections again and again, you just need to retry the last bit that you failed. That's very nice for players, it avoids needless repetitions or raging.

However, despite theses mechanisms intended to make the game more accessible, Guacamelee remains a tough game. It's not a hardcore platformer like Super Meat Boy, but it's definitely more difficult than your average platformer. If you like challenging games, you should definitely feels at ease in Guacamelee, which has the added bonus that many of it's more tricky challenges are optional, so it's up to you to decide how much you want to push yourself. 100% completion is totally doable, but will requires some patience.

On the same point, it's fairly obvious the game is aimed at long time gamers. Beside the difficulty, it also packs a ton of references to other video games. Billboards in the backgrounds, specific piece of dialogs, characters...there are so many references spread across the game that I'm not sure anyone has ever been able to spot them all.

At the other end of the spectrum, people who are not familiar with platformers should stay away from the game. Though the mechanisms are fair, it definitely requires you to be familiar with some platformers tropes, and be used to chain powers together to fling yourself into the air. 

Moreover, if you want a relaxed experience, where you're just enjoying the story, the game is not for you, because the story is barebones. Though it introduces some interesting characters, the dialogs are basic, and the story is a stereotypical "knight saves princess" kind of thing. 

All of that means that the pleasure of Guacamelee lies in its travel (the screen to screen gameplay) rather than its destination (furthering the story). With its many references, it's an ode to video games and is aimed at long time gamers. It indeniably succeeds at that task. However you should only try if if you're think that would be the sort of things you would enjoy. Otherwise, you're just gonna set yourself up for frustration.

21354083.review:
Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition... io non so veramente se esistono parole in grado di poter descrivere questo gioco! Devo essere onesto: con tutti questi metroidvania che girano su Steam (praticamente più del 70% indie) ero diffidente nel comprare questo titolo. Forse ancora un metroidvania troppo Metroid o troppo Castlevania... o forse addirittura troppo Shantae visto che, secondo me, sta dettando nuovi canoni per questo tipo di giochi. Ebbene mi sbagliavo totalmente!

Guacamelee rispetta quelle meccaniche tipiche di questi giochi rinnovandole e creando allo stesso tempo qualcosa di mai visto e totalmente originale. Meravigliose le ambientazioni e le (veramente) infinite citazioni ad altri giochi. Uno può stare giorni a cercare riferimenti ad altri giochi nascosti nei fondali. Molte volte non risultano propriamente ovvie e Guacamelee omaggia questi giochi in maniera magistrale (e senza infrangere le leggi sul copyright). I personaggi sono tutti molto simpatici, ben caratterizzati e divertenti. La storia è bella, molto semplice ma è raccontata molto bene fra i vari dialoghi e le cutscenes veramente graziose.
Il gameplay è qualcosa di già visto ma le miriadi di combo, mosse, prese e strategie rendono questo territorio quasi infinito! Il punto forte di Guacamelee sono proprio i combattimenti che si incentrano molto sul sistema di combo che aumenta colpendo più nemici in successione senza essere colpiti. Un po' scarno forse il roster dei nemici (esclusi i boss) ma il sistema di combattimento non rende noiosa nessuna di queste battaglie e inoltre nessun nemico è mai troppo fastidioso da affrontare. Il sistema light world-dark world è grazioso però a volte il gioco punta troppo su questa caratteristica tanto che a volte, nel avanzare in alcuni punti o tentando di prendere qualche cesta, risulta solamente una questione di timing corretto e non una sfida equa. Inoltre non capisco perchè in questi nuovi metroidvania NESSUNO utilizza un semplice sistema di level up! Ad un certo punto in questi giochi il personaggio dovrebbe abbattere con più facilità i vecchi nemici e incontrare successivamente nuovi nemici più forti e difficili da abbattere. Guacamelee sfortunatamente, nonostante la progressiva acquisizione di abilità (sia comprate che imparate), non permette tutto ciò. Spesso le abilità acquisite permettono di accedere, come è giusto che sia in questi giochi, a zone inaccessibili in precedenza ma nulla a che vedere con la potenza e la crescita del personaggio (che in questo senso non cresce). Magari sotto una diversa luce è possibile vedere il level up tramite l'acquisto dei vestiti ma questi hanno sia caratteristiche positive sia caratteristiche negative e difficilmente il giocatore è tentato a comprarli tutti. Ho comprato in totale solamente 4 abiti ed avrei tanto desiderato di acquistarli tutti anche perchè questi si comprano con l'argento, più difficile da ottenere, e non con le semplici monete d'oro. Purtroppo l'acquisto di questi alla fine risulta molto macchinoso ed ogni giocatore deve scegliere con cura questi vestiti, sopratutto se si vuole acquistare l'abito del diavolo. Altra piccola pecca è il multiplayer esclusivamente locale... sarebbe stato grazioso un multiplayer in rete ma probabilmente mi rendo conto di quanto possa essere difficile sincronizzare due giocatori in un gioco del genere. Forse un online avrebbe rovinato l'esperienza... chissà!

Nonostante qualche microscopico difetto Guacamele è veramente uno dei migliori giochi indie alla quale abbia mai giocato, probabilmente uno dei migliori giochi di questa generazione di videogiochi! è veramente incredibile pensare che questo gioco è stato programmato da una casa indipendente! Spero tanto che la Drink Box Studios possa consegnarci un nuovo episodio di Guacamelee molto presto. Questo gioco è stato decisamente un successo!

9.5/10

21245043.review:
[h1]总评[/h1]
这款本质上的银河战士恶魔城式ACT游戏，其实是由无数游戏所组成，其中海量的游戏元素与游戏文化甚至网络文化的巧妙引用，就像自由摔角手的面具一样，既寄托着远古神灵的护佑，又彰显着作品的无穷生命力。更为重要的是，本作最核心的部分，又是如此独一无二而灿烂夺目，让谁都无法否认制作人赋予作品的丰富内涵，有理由相信，它将复又作为一个优秀的参照，启发着潜在的后继者。最终，我们看到了一个既博采众多经典游戏之精华，又将它们经过精心搭配，从而犹如众星捧月般烘托着其中自有文化内核的平衡亦完美的作品。

[h1]优点[/h1]
*“游戏迷”式的精美大杂烩
*海量且绝妙的关卡设计
*令人着迷的墨西哥元素
*兼具怀旧和创新精神的幽默情节
*极高的重玩价值
*两次打磨使游戏品质趋于完美

[h1]“缺点”[/h1]
*手残党的噩梦

[h1][b]10/10[/b][/h1]

21213851.review: I'm sorry, I just don't like it. It's like the devolpers did the best part of other games mediocre. It has the Mexican Culture aspect of Grim Fandango, done so it feels plastic and fake. It has the battle system of any good beat-em-up, like Castle Crashers, but repetative and annoying. The whole "Press colored button to make colored platforms appear" makes the game more puzzley, but in a aggravating way that clashes with it's high action beat-em-up atmosphere. And all through this I wandering through confusing level design doing the same annoying parts over and over again. The only thing I really liked was the art style and music; the colors popped, and the music like something you really could hear on Mexican Radio. if the DJ had died and the music never stopped repeating itself. Maybe I'm being to harsh, because my entire experience was ruined due to the fact the it didn't register my controller and playing with a keyboard was agonizing. In all, I really, really wanted to like Guacamelee, but when I was honest with myself, I found I really, really disliked the whole experience. 21146118.review:
Fala meu caro amigo, beleza?

Guacamelee é um jogo interessante, cheio de referências, e que se trata de um jogo no estilo "metroidvânia", que é um estilo que eu realmente me interesso, pois tem um bom desafio e sempre novas formas de avançar os locais.

O jogo tem uma temática mexicana, onde existe uma cultura, templos, e um outro mundo, que se trata do mundo dos mortos. iremos por partes.

O jogo fala sobre juan, um fazendeiro que ajuda em várias coisas em sua vila. Um dia, juan é chamado pelo padre para ajudar a preparar as coisas para o festival de comemoração a uma data especial, o dia de los muertos. Enquanto isso, a filha do presidente da vila chega e fala com o padre, e então vê juan e comenta sobre que ele era um grande amigo dela de infância, e então o chama para a mansão do presidente. logo quando ele vai até a mansão, ela pega fogo e então juan entra heroicamente. justo quando ele chega, percebe um homem, com roupa de toureiro, chamado carlos calaca, que capturou a filha do presidente. As intenções de calaca você descobre ao decorrer do jogo, assim como sua história. Juan tenta impedi-lo, mas carlos o mata rapidamente. Como você morreu, acaba indo para o mundo dos mortos. seguindo um caminho, você chega a uma estátua e uma máscara se revela a você. uma guardiã que guarda a máscara fala que ele deve coloca-la, e que deveria impedir calaca, e colocando-a, você se transforma em um "luchador", e é aí que o jogo começa.

Sendo um metroidvânia, o início do jogo é bem limitado, pois você só consegue ir á certos locais, mas você evolui através de itens e vai liberando parte por parte do mapa, fazendo a exploração escencial para completar o jogo. as trilhas sonoras são temas mexicanos, assim como o jogo. talvez você se enjoe por revisitar uma parte e ficar ouvindo um looping por um certo tempo, ele não é curto, mas cada um tem sua paciência. mesmo assim, são bem feitas e cada local tem uma música diferente. As vezes tu pode entrar numa sala, ouvir uma música e mais pra frente no jogo, entra numa outra e tem a mesma. Mas calma, isso não acontece com frequência. a jogabilidade é ótima, é possível realizar múltiplos combos que vão melhorando a medida das abilidades que tu ganha. a arte do jogo é ótima, e o melhor de tudo, é bem leve. mesmo se o seu pc for meio ruim, ele pode rodar de boas.

A jogabilidade é incrível, é possível fazer diversos combos logo no início e com as abilidades novas, tu pode chegar ao ponto de esmagar os inimigos em 3 segundos, além de poder fazer técnicas de arremesso fodas que tu fica de boca aberta perguntando como tu conseguiu fazer aquilo.

A história pode parecer genérica no início, mas fica bem interessante a medida que tu avança. Ah, o jogo tem 2 finais, sendo o que eu peguei antes de fazer essa análise me fez suar pelos olhos de certa forma, mas trate de fazer os dois.

E essa foi minha análise de Guacamelee ( no caso, o Super Turbo Championship Edition).

Tenha um bom jogo, e até outro dia!
