Má totiž srdce na správném místě, a když je potřeba, pak neváhá ochotně přiložit ruku k dílu. Stejně jako dnes, kdy ho místní farář požádal, zda by jim nepomohl s přípravou oslav Dne mrtvých. Kdyby jen dobrák Juan tušil, co se mu zanedlouho přihodí...

Následující události již ponechám v tajnosti, mohu vám ale prozradit, že se z vás stane luchador – neohrožený zápasník, ukrývající svou tvář pod pestrobarevnou maskou. Samotný příběh pak není nic objevného, celé tohle mexické dobrodružství, by se dalo shrnout jako „cesta za záchranou světa a princezny“. Co ovšem vyprávění ztrácí na originalitě, to bohatě vynahrazuje svým vtipem a odlehčenou atmosférou. Narazíte totiž na spoustu praštěných postav, které vám svými zábavnými průpovídkami, zaručeně vykouzlí úsměv na tváři. Ten si ale v pozdějších částech hry, možná budete skrápět slzami zoufalství.

Některé přeskakovací pasáže, jsou totiž až nečekaně obtížné, kdy vám nedovolí ani sebemenší zaváhání. Naštěstí to zachraňují všudypřítomné záchytné body, díky kterým to bude pořád víc výzva než čirá frustrace. Kromě skákání, se můžete těšit i na časté souboje s nepřáteli. Ty jsou velice zábavné, protože na každého platí trochu jiná taktika, takže nikdy neupadnou do nudného stereotypu. Pomáhá tomu také postupné získávání nových schopností, sloužící k efektivnějšímu boji, stejně jako k odemykání dříve nepřístupných lokací. Jestli vlastníte více ovladačů, pak můžete navíc hrát až ve čtyřech lidech na jednom počítači.

Pokud si tedy chcete zkusit zábavnou plošinovku, a nebojíte se výzev, pak máte mé doporučení.

This game is AWESOME. Not perfect, that would be silly, but super fun, super well made, and it fits many kinds of players.
Casual? This game can be brute-forced relatively easily, and give you tools to cheese it.
Hardcore? This game has hard challenges, a hard mode, and tight fighting controls.

20596544.review:
Capolavoro assoluto in ambito metroidvania (esplorazione + segreti + upgrade + combattimenti), ma un gran titolo anche sotto l'aspetto puramente platform e persino come picchiaduro, seppure questi ultimi due aspetti vadano considerati nel contesto generale (presi singolarmente faticherebbero, ovviamente, a competere con i massimi specialisti dei rispettivi settori).

Guacamele rasenta la perfezione praticamente sotto ogni punto di vista. L'art design è di prim'ordine: grafica semplice ma estremamente caratteristica e originale, coloratissima e ispirata alle ambientazioni messicane (anche con musiche tipiche molto ben fatte. Vestiremo infatti i panni di un luchador (lottatore) che dovrà salvare la sua amata. Per farlo, dovremo affrontare innumerevoli nemici, imparare un ampio numero di mosse speciali (sempre rigorosamente di lotta, quindi niente armi) e acquistare i potenziamenti disponibili per poter avanzare nell'esplorazione e sbloccare passaggi inizialmente ostruiti.

Come picchiaduro Guacamelee ha da offrire non poco: tutte le mosse apprese possono essere concatenate in potentissime combo (anche piuttosto lunghe), anche se la potenza di certe mosse rispetto ad altre vi spingerà probabilmente a non utilizzare tutto il repertorio. Gli avversari più impegnativi vi costringeranno a selezionare tattiche ben precise, penalizzando brutalmente un approccio disordinato e fracassone.

L'aspetto platform è estremamente curato ed offre un livello di difficoltà piuttosto elevato ma non troppo frustrante. In generale, dopo una manciata di tentativi spesi ad analizzare e comprendere un passaggio specifico, si riescono a superare anche i punti più ostici. E' molto importante imparare a padroneggiare tutte le mosse apprese e ad applicarle in ogni situazione.

I giudizi sintetici

+ Uno dei migliori rappresentanti del genere metroidvania
+ Meccaniche picchiaduro e platform molto curate e divertenti
+ Difficoltà ben bilanciata in un crescendo di mosse e di combo spettacolari
+ Art design semplice ma ispirato e di grande effetto
+ Ottime musiche caratteristiche
+ Longevo e rigiocabile, non solo per i completisti
+ Cutscene molto divertenti e autoironiche

-  Senza un gamepad vi impiccherete ben presto con la corda della tastiera

9/10 Da comprare senza se e senza ma, a qualsiasi prezzo, scontato oppure no

20585330.review:
Having played the Gold Edition of Guacamelee almost to the end I was hesitant about buying this edition that would require me to restart the whole game as each area was modified and so saves would not be compatible. I'm glad I took the plunge (with a major discount helping) as this is the definitive version of the game.

Guacamelee is one of the finest action-platformers ever made with outstanding level design and gameplay fusing superb and intelligently designed platforming with great beat-em-up mechanics all in a beautiful, colourful and musically pleasing setting. It has a metroidvania-style exploration system where new abilities enable exploring previously locked areas of the game and the map is filled with chests to find and interesting challenges to reach them. Each new move doubles as both a combat-ready combo-expanding ability while also enabling greater environment traversal. The level design smartly teaches you how to apply them while offering extremely creative ways of using them both individually and combined with previous abilities. The story and characters are fun and the music is fantastic and the traiditional Mexican art style is great too.

The gameplay in this version has been enhanced compared to the Gold Edition and the few areas that used to feel frustrating no longer do so, they feel challenging but fair and skill-based. The visual upgrades are a nice touch with enhanced lighting and generally more colour tastefully applied. The new areas are nice additions expanding the backstory and there are a few new secret chests to find with the new Pollo bomb ability. Technically the game engine seems to have been enhanced too as it feels smoother (although that is subjective and may just be an impression).

Just buy this game, it's one of the best games ever made, rarely has a game been so fun.

20388593.review:
Mother always said "If it walks like a duck, talks like a duck, but doesn't look like a duck, then it's some wierd guy trying to be a duck and failing." This is how I feel about this game. It plays like a Metroidvania, Sounds like a Metroidvania, but doesn't look like a Metroidvania. Not that that's a bad thing, but Instead It tries to look like something completely different. Something more interesting and fun, and then fails. 

This game is about an agave farmer who's in love with the daughter of "El Presidente" who you've been friends with since childhood and you secretly love each other and we're already off to a bad start. Your job is to take on the role of super powered masked luchador "Juan" and save the woman you love, who has been taken by a skeleton guy, who drags her into the afterlife to marry her, blah blah blah... prahpecy, blah blah blah... ultamate power. 

"Wait, What about the 'El Presidente' guy?" Who him? I dont know, he's dead or something. "But arent you trying to save his daughter from the afterlife? Cant you save him too?" is he the love interest? "No but..." Then there's no reason to pay any attention to him.

The story goes as you would expect it to go. Travel the world of "Mexican inspired world" and fight hoards of enemies while only going through certain doors at certain times with certain weapons cause Metroid to save her from Villan who wants Ultimate power. you know, the world that has refferences to other, more entertaining video games, except they're all luchadors cause Mexican inspired world.

The gameplay is decent because, well it's Metroid and Castlevania except instead of whips and plasma beams, it's punching and kicking. they didn't even try to hide it, you find a chozo statue and you think "Oh, what a clever easter egg" and turns out that's how you get power ups. certain monsters can only be killed with certain super mover, which you can only use if you have energy in your special meter, and only if your in a specific plain of existance, in a specific place on weekdays, unless it's a holiday.

There's nothing more to say, it's a sub-par Metroidvania that will keep you going only if you REALLY want to play a Metroidvania game. so to refferecne back to the beginning of this. This game is most certainly not a duck. It's more like a cow trying to swim.

20369461.review:
Este juego en realidad resulta ser una gran sorpresa en un paquete pequeño, pues a primera vista tal vez solo parezca "un Metroidvania mas" o un Indie del montón, pero no es así.
Guacamelee sabe ganarse su posición a pulso, pues es un gran plataformero, con un gran apartado y dirección artística, banda sonora de lo mejor, un impresionante gameplay muy intuitivo, e inclusive una historia no muy grandiosa, pero si divertida e interesante para seguirla.
Sus diversas referencias a videojuegos y por supuesto a la cultura mexicana, hacen de este juego una gran caja de risas en el mejor sentido de la palabra, su música tan mexicana junto con esos remixes del juego, son demasiado buenos, un soundtrack digno de escuchar y su principal maravilla, el gran gameplay, ya que mientras se avanza en la aventura, se va haciendo mas completo, pasando desde un Juan débil, hasta un completo héroe luchador.
El sentimiento de progresión es enorme, pues siempre se siente como tu habilidad crece y la curva de dificultad es excelente, ya que a pesar de que al inicio las cosas pueden parecer difíciles, mientras se avanza puede llegar ese sentimiento de que puedes ganarle a todos.

En resumen, un gran juego que ningún fan de los plataformeros se puede perder.

20309099.review:
Before buying this game I was originally put off by it's over-the-top luchador aesthetic for some reason. I was lucky enough to have gotten the Gold Edition as part of a bundle a few years back though and I've been a raving fan ever since. You don't have to be a particular fan of the culture to enjoy the charm, colors, and wit of Guacamelee! You just need to like playing video games.
  Any version of Guacamelee! is an absolute joy to play. The characters and writing are all pretty funny. The platforming is challenging but not sadistic. The combat is... so satisfying; such amazingly big combos can be pulled off. The bosses are all tough but learnable; I've never beat a boss without getting hit but I've gotten pretty darn close after several hours.
  The game can be 100% in about 10-20hrs for even new players I expect. The STC Edition adds two more levels to the Gold Edition. I thought that these would be optional bonus style levels but actually it's integrated into the main playthrough. The levels maybe add an additional hour or two if you are already familiar with playing through GE. There's a few other minor additions as well and as an owner of GE I still felt like I got my money's worth. This is coming from the guy who played Guacamelee! GE five times though and is well into a second playthrough of STCE on hard mode.
  The gameplay is just so fun, charming, and addictive in Guacamelee! Buy yourself a 360 controller if you don't have one and buy this game.

20115949.review:
[Normal Difficulty]
This game is really straightforward when it comes to progression; but there is simply a lot to do, and a lot to challenge you.  The game isn't as open to explore as Castlevania SOTN since it's holden to the dreaded power-up curse stopping many explorers from breaking the sequence of the game. You will run into many challenging Scenarios to collect bonuses that are too plentiful to be well hidden. It doesn't take long until you stat running into rather difficult enemies that force you to acclimate to their own attack patter, rather than keeping the rhythm of your combo. You will have many tools to dealing with the enemies including a Suplex with long range AOE effect, a Piledriver with Midrange AOE effect, a Standard Throw, and Da Boot (Stronger standard Throw). 

There are times when this can cause the game to glitch, such as a scenario later in the game that causes the enemy too fall into the pipes in a room filled with a pipe floor making the game itself softlock. You are forced to reload the savefile and try the room again if this happens, good thing the save point is only one room back. I can recommend this game to people looking for a game like the many Metroidvanias out there.

19966959.review:
*I'm evolving this review over time

While the game has a few more minor things that could use improving, the overall construction of the game is well though out and well executed. 

+ The music complements the theme and pace of the gameplay nicely and has a enough variety for the size of the game. It's also good, well composed music to boot
+ Solid animations and sounds that make you feel every hit you give/take 
+ Great visuals. Has real attention to detail with the Mexican art style and borrows a little from GRim Fandango, while remaining its own style
+ Level design is excellent and Guacamelee STCE should be used as a showcase for great level design to anyone aspiring to build platformers. Each new mechanic is introduced to the player beautifully, then combined with other previously learned mechanics, which provides a progressively tougher environment to fight through. There is also an almost perfect mix of player versus environment and player versus AI and this also gets more challenging at a good pace throughout the game 
+ Fast paced combat
+ Funny
+ Seeds other game art and pop culture art into the game with it's own style e.g. [spoiler] Manny Calavera skulls can be found on posters throughout the game [/spoiler]
+ Cool game mechanics with things like [spoiler] INTENSO (my favourite thing in the game and what an awesome name for it too!), Dimensional Shifting, Playing as a Chicken, etc. [/spoiler]
+ Moddable
+ [spoiler]Has the land of the dead![/spoiler]
+ RPG mechanic is well executed
+ LOTS of save points that are very well spaced out




- Mini map needs level detail, not just room shape
- No quest log for side quests or clues on where to go to finish these
- Enemies can interrupt special moves
- Knockback is more frustrating than it needs to be. You get knocked back too far and it takes too long to recover, which really breaks game flow
- If you die, you have to re-open all treasure chests you opened before dying after last savepoint. This is a minor one, but I feel it breaks game flow a bit
- There need to be more teleportation spots in the game. When revisiting areas to get the extras with new skills, not being able to teleport to the next area without having to traverse a huge amount of ground, becomes very tedious


- Controls while feeling fairly solid, could be better
- The stick controls could handle player intention a bit better e.g. if player is pushing the left stick predominantly up but not perfectly, then the game should still take it as up, not sideways
- If you fight a boss and die, when you respawn your intenso meter doesn't return to the fullness level it had before the fight
- Throws often don't go where the arrow is pointing
- Pushing off a wall for Goat Fly often ends up with Juan just dropping off the wall
- Platform clipping is unforgiving and it gets annoying fast when you're jumping around on floating platforms

- Double jump doesnt work if you jump from holding onto a wall
- The throwing mechanic is broken. Objects will often not be thrown in the direction of the arrow and this is infinitely frustrating during sequences in the game where this is necessary to move on to the next bit
- Intenso meter doesn't return to original state of fullness when you respawn if you die in a boss battle


+- I'm in 2 minds about the wall jumping mechanic in the game. It's one of the biggest, if not the biggest mechanic in the game and the levels are clearly designed to take full advantage of it works with jumping from wall to wall and not being able to jump up the same wall in consecutive jumps. While this presents the player with a challenging mechanic, it's also very frustrating to use while traversing areas because it leaves no room for recovery from slight mistakes. This is really evident in the beginning of the game before Juan gets his dash skills. 
Personally, I would have made the early design decision to go with a consecutive wall jump up the same wall and used a limiter like jump stamina. This way, most of the challenges would still work and the level design wouldn't need to be any more involved for developers to prevent player out of bounds issues.

19785163.review:
Guacamelee has many elements that make it a great game. The combat is engaging and satisfying, because it ramps up at a moderate pace, and the sound design and art give weight to each attack. The environments and enemies are different enough that the game doesn't become stale, especially if you're not a completionist. For those who are completionists, even though some of the backtracking can be tedious, the challenges are reasonable but not too easy, so they present a roadblock that will be fun to overcome.   Also for completionists, the map gives you % complete for each area, so you won't be frustrated that you're at 98% and don't know where to find that last item you missed.

The pace, sound, and art are all things that drew me in, and kept me playing with Guacamelee.  Chances are if you like Metroid or Mark of the Ninja, you're going to get drawn in too.

此版本是 Gold Edition 的強化版，想玩的玩家直接購買這一版即可


遊戲中到處都有墨西哥元素
像是劇情正好在亡靈節舉辦期間，城內可以看見剪紙，森林裡則有祭祀的貢品
為了拯救心愛的女孩，戴上藍色面具成為摔角手 (Luchador) 的主角 
捉走女主角，還把惡魔變成雞的大魔王則穿得像個馬術師 (Charro)

主角剛開始只會打拳與摔跤，隨著劇情的推進會學到更多的特技
特技不只能讓主角到更多地區探索，多數特技也能用來攻擊敵人

19551230.review:
First of all i haven't played the original. Just to clarify.

Despite being a Metroidvania-like game, Guacamelee is actually quite straightforward. Sure that areas are pretty much mazes, but aside of a pair of sections which were disorienting on purpose due some secrets the game is actually quite linear. Later on you can obviously backtrack with upgrades to unlock new paths, but most of them is to obtain even more upgrades. This might seem as a flaw, but actually keeps the game going yet still giving you breaks to get some new items before progressing further.

The mechanics of Metroidvania still applies however. You get a limited path, but as soon you get more power-ups you'll discover new paths. Most of the areas are challenges to use such powerups so you'll be constantly using them. Otherwise they'll be used in battleto execute long combos and stay in a safe position.

If i have a complain it goes towards the bosses. They constantly appear and harass you during the story as this big group of menacing foes you have to fight at the end of some areas. But when you actually encounter them they are just a lesson of what you learned in their respective area. Unless in hard diffuclty they aren't a challenge and quite underwhelming for the role they have in the story, making common enemies more threatening than them.

Overall Guacamelee is actually quite linear, but the Metroidvania part of the game goes mainly to exploration and get upgrades. That's not a bad thing as is a game you'll feel progress wherever you go.

19537311.review:
Guacamelee es un hack and slash (O cómo coño se escriba), plataformas de scroll lateral y gráficos 2D.

Pues bien, la premisa es simple, varios malos, raptan a "La chica" consigues poderes mágicos y vas a por ella derrotando a cada uno de ellos, y de paso, salvas el mundo y compras pan y leche, que no queda.

Simplemente ver el juego por encima ya te enamora, con esa estilo artístico que bebe tanto de la cultura mexicana, y que decir del humor del juego, siempre sacandote una sonrisa con cosas ridículas y estereotipos hispanos.

¡Y las refrencias! ¡Que decir de las referencias! Os juro que en cada zona de este juego encontrareis una referencia u otra a un videojuego. Hasta hay una a goat simulator.

Y lo digo en serio eh, yo me rendí con el del árbol Telue, creo que ese día mi paciencia murió.

Recomiendo encarecidamente comprar este juego, cuándo esté en oferta claro, y no lo digo porque no se merezca esos jugosos 13.99 €, si no porque ni tú, ni yo, somos asquerosamente ricos.

9/10.

19468802.review:
Every once in a rare while you come across a game that feels so refined, so polished that there's nothing left to complain about. Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition is such a game. The visual style is unique, captivating, and still coherent. Each objective, and the motivation for reaching it, is always clear, but you're still free to explore along the way or in the opposite direction as you so choose. The collectables scattered about the relatively open world are hidden well enough to require some exploration but not so well that you're inclined to seek out a guide - exempting a select few of course. The ever-growing inventory of new special moves are explained fully, used immediately, and are as useful for regular platforming as they are for fighting. Misjudging a jump and falling into a bottomless pit or a pool of green slime sends you right back to where you jumped from, letting you try again without even the frustration of returning to the last well-placed checkpoint. And if all that sounds too easy for you, there is plenty of post-ending secrets and challenges to test your skills on, including a second, more punishing difficulty. 
Every part of this game just works so smoothly and is so enjoyable that I had a hard time putting it down. But the thing that really caught me off guard is that amongst all the joking and all the delightful silliness, there's still something dramatic and engaging here. There's a damsel in distress that remains defiant and selfless despite being helpless. There's a hero that remains focused and grounded despite apocalyptic consequences and dying himself. There's villains with their own tragic, narcissistic, or trivial reasons for acting as they do. And there's a climax that ties it all together into something more meaningful than it seemed to be along the way. There is truly nothing missing here and no reason to avoid playing this game.

19451343.review:
Metroidvanias are one of my favorite genres, but I really didn't enjoy Guacamelee. 

Combat
-Guacamelee's style of melee combat just doesn't really work for this genre of game. Attacking consists of button mashing, and dodging is as simple as rolling through any attack. In most metroidvanias, dodging is the main skill element. Learning and anticipating a enemy's attack pattern in Metroid or Cave Story is what makes them fun, and timing a roll negates any attack just as much fun.

Platforming
-These segments are just pretty lackluster. It's the same running and walljumping you've seen a million times before.

Come classico dei Metroidvania, Guacamelee presenta una varietà di poteri sbloccabili durante l'avventura utili ai fini dell'esplorazione dei livelli, che vi aiuteranno a raggiungere aree in precedenza inaccessibili, il tutto condito da un combat system veramente ben fatto che restituisce un ottimo feeling "luchadoresco" quando vengono sbloccate tutte le combo.

18813569.review:
通关撒花：墨西哥英雄大混战超级涡轮冠军版，另外还有一个黄金版，本作与之相比内容基本一致略有改动，如果都没有建议买本作，如果已有其中一作无需再买另外一作。

特别提醒：本作没有网络联机，只有本地合作。

游戏操作比较多样，由于可以切换人物和世界的虚实，所以无形中增加了难度。

虽然没有中文，但影响不大，任务地点在地图上都有显示，直接过去即可触发下一步剧情。有时需要和伪装成山羊的老巫师学习新的技能，然后才能去一些被各种颜色的石头挡住的路线。

有解谜要素，但是无一不考验操作，游戏容错率非常低。空中连续操作很常见，掉下去重新再来，但好在路上存档点比较多。

关于最终BOSS的几点注意事项：
1、一阶段攻击速度比较快，不要靠近墙角，在中间来回二段跳躲避攻击，用特殊攻击破防的同时可造成有效伤害。
2、注意观察二阶段不同大招的起手式，利用蹲下、二段跳和翻滚来躲避攻击。
3、天上掉下来的石头是无害的，可以用它们攻击，但伤害很低。这里注意先用特殊攻击破防然后慢慢磨血即可，不要急。

单机通关难度有点高，可能会导致在最后关头没有耐心继续玩下去。虽然没有网络联机，但本地合作最多支持四人，玩家之间可以互相救，其他玩家按手柄可直接在中途加入游戏。死亡等待15秒，攻击灵魂球即可复活，还可以买道具缩短复活时间，打BOSS必备利器。

很好玩的合作闯关游戏，推荐。

18670598.review:
While Guacamelee doesn't innovate the Metroidvania genre, it uses its brawler/lucha-libre fighting system to make a well-crafted experience. The polished mechanics for both fighting and platforming are worth your time.

My only complaint is that so much of the game (and gameplay) are call-backs to other games that the game lacks an identity. (Definitely not for the visual department). On the other hand, the similar mechanics could benefit newcomers who are not familiar with the games it works off of.

For die-hards of Metroidvanias, there is something worthwhile for you too.

The game starts off simple, but quickly ups the challenge and the world becomes more open. (There is no sequence-breaking, but you can earn certain collectables early with enough determination.) Then there are mini-challenges for completionists that will truly test your mastery.

[h1]What's so Super, Turbo and Championed?[/h1]

[list]
[*]You get expanded areas and more challenges. (Every level was reworked.)
[*] More enemy variety and a new boss. 
[*] Rebalancing of enemies' and player's attacks.
[*] New mechanics: Player-controlled dimensional swapping (switching between worlds on the fly) and Chicken Bombing (not often used or needed except for 100% completion).  
[*] Upgraded local coop: From 2 players to 4.
[*] Multiple save-slots (so you dont' have to strangle your friend when he overrides your progress).
[*] DLC of Gold Edition included for free.
[*] Costumes can now be permanetly unlocked.
[*] INTENSO Mode (a fury mode for extra damage and other benefits that you can unlock).
[/list]

Basically, the whole game was redone from the ground-up that buying the standard game is moot. (I got the Complete collection at a discount, and previous owners got a loyalty discount.)

 It definitely plays like a game fine-tuned from the ground up, and it is better for it.

[h1]WARNING FOR EPILEPTIC GAMERS![/h1]

The one change that I think needs more polish is the toned down epileptic screens and visuals. They are much better than what they used to be, and I'm glad they were changed because they made me sick.

However, the Intenso medallion eyes and the names on the boss-screens might still be a strain on the eyes. 

Also, the player-controlled dimension swapping is something I think the devs cannot fix for elipeptic gamers; the visuals are bright and colorful, and the platforming challenges for the harder areas will require lots of swapping between bright colors and a white-circle around the character.

 I think you'll be able to play the majority of the game without much trouble. But like I said, the more difficult platforming areas require you to shift on the fly, so be careful.

[h1]Let's Get Ready to Lucha-Libre![/h1]

With all that being out of the way, let's talk about gameplay. The combat of Gucamelee has a careful synergy between your abilities and attacks, making your progression on platforming and combat obstacles both challenging.

All the abilities you unlock can be used as attacks: The Rooster Uppercut (a saving jump), the Frog Slam (dive-attack), the Goat Run (vertical scaling), the Dashing Derp Derp (yes, it's called that; a forward lunge) and the Goat Fly (Shinespark) are all new abilities that expand your combo potential. And the animation quality is so smooth that it feels energetic.

The dojo in the game can help you learn the intricaces of your abilities. Or you can experiment on your own.

For example, if you use the Dashing Derp Derp, and you want to keep the combo going, you'll have to roll to continue the offense (the DDD knocks the enemy too far away). You can then send the enemy flying with the Rooster Uppercut or wait after sending the enemy in the air normally, and then use a Frog Slam or continue with another DDD or a headbutt. 

Combine all those abilities with the grapple-based moves (throwing and doing some lucha-libre manuevers), and you will find yourself enjoying every single combat encounter you come across. The boss-fights don't feel special, but they're entertaining to say the least.

The platforming is no different; the careful attention to details of your surroundings can let you know of alternative routes or other means to unlock certain collectables. Health, stamina--for the special moves--and the INTENSO meter need three pieces for an upgrade, which you can purchase some pieces but you'll have to find a lot more on your own.

To compensate for giving your character a ton of versatility, the rule is you can use every ability once before you land on the ground again. I have found one or two screens where that didn't seem the case--maybe a bug--where the game forced me to do the platforming one way when I should've been able to use my Rooster Uppercut.  

The Inferno challenges are the best platforming aspects because they're so short, while also very brutal on you mastering your fighting and platforming skills. The same goes for the Mask Pieces, which are all platforming-based; you need to find them (six out of seven before Callaca) to get the good ending.

[h1]The Game's Blemishes[/h1]

For all the game does get right, I think some aspects of the game are lacking or not as finely executed as the gameplay itself.

I already mentioned how the game lacks an identity because it borrows heavily from its sources. Choozo Statues, the memes of indie games and other video-games (from Grim Fandango to VVVVV), the Shinespark ability, the Metroid Bomb eggs--did I mention this was inspired by Metroid?--and tons of other references. But the story is forgettable too.

Essentially, it's two young lovers who haven't seen each other since children now are a part of some demonic villian's plot for taking over the world. I like it 'cause the game reminded me of Mucha Lucha in its art-style and gameplay. But I'm not really given much of a reason to care about "El Presidente's Hija/Daughter" (that's her name), but the game spends a lot of time forcibly supplying plot points to sudden narrative moments.

And speaking of forced, those innuendos. I gotta say, I never really played a game before where I thought the sexual tension in the dialogue was a bit too much. (And I played Conker as a kid). Maybe it was because it was so forced that I thought it was cringe-worthy.

Dying is perhaps the one drawback that improves towards the end. At every checkpoint, you get your health refilled. and when you die you restart at the last one. Thankfully, falling just teleports you to where you last stood safely.

But the biggest complaint I have about its gameplay is what you need to do to 100% the game. You have to collect everything; not just the upgrade-stuff, mask pieces, and side-quests, but also the health-orbs, INFERNO orbs and other stuff you might not want to break in order to save it for later. As a result, I don't see a reason to beat this game for 100% completion.

All you should do for a complete playthrough (around 8 to 10 hours) is collect as many upgrade pieces as you want, then collect all the mask pieces and get Gold raitings for the Inferno challenges. Then, when you're done, you can play hard mode and enjoy the game however you want.

Thankfully, you will want to play again because the gender-swap characters (Juanita or Tostalla) have a different playstyle to Juan. Juanita is much faster and does more damage, but her throws are much weaker. The other costumes have some passive-changes, but none that I would consider worthy for replaying the game like with Shovel Knight.

[h1]Gucamelee: Great as Junk-Food Or for Spicing Up Your Life[/h1]

You can't go wrong with this game whether you've fallen in love with Metroidvanias before or if you've never played one.  You can be guaranteed that you will have a good time, especially if you are able to play with friends (respawns are available).

18648285.review:
A really fun and addicting metroidvania game. Full of humour and action, with well thought mechanics and level design,  but also a good level of challenge. This is really one game you will enjoy a lot playing replaying if you like metroidvanias.

Story: you play Juan, a luchador that has save his love one from the evil claws of Calaca, and stop his plan to bring the wolrd of the livings and th dead together! you will face many challenges, meet friends and combat foes to reach your goal and become the greatest luchador of Publuecho!
Well, as you can see nothing blowing the doors off scenario wise,you won't play the game specifically for its super elaborated story, but it does the trick to accompany the game.
The game is however full of humour and references, and characters are endearing, which do make the game/story very nice to follow.

Art: hand-drawn squarish and super colorful graphics that fits very well the theme of the game. It might not be to everyone's taste but as far as I am concerned find them pretty gorgeous.
Animation are very fluid and no slowing down comes to hinder the experience. Overall this is a very nice looking game.
But this is also a very nice sounding game: the soundtrack is very cheerful and accompany perfectly the game. Very good soundtrack I recommend to anyone.

Gameplay: now for the most important part, Guacamelee gets a very good grade here. A mix of combat a and platforming wroking well together. Controls are tights and very responsive, there is a good variety of movements to allow you to create very nice combos on the enemy. Those movements are also well thouth-out as they will also be used to solve platform puzzles/challenges throughout the game. Puzzles and challenges that are well designed, not too difficult but not too simple either, just the right amount of complexity and originality that makes it overal a good level design.
The game will occupy you a good amount of time if you wish to finish it at 100%  aroudn 12 to 15 hours the first time, and extra challenges are available for those who wish a bit more challenges. it also provides rankings for speedruns for those who like that!

Overall this is a very good, fun and cheerful game that I would recommend to anyone. I ended up liking it surprisingly more than I thought I would. This is definitely a game that is high up in the list of good metroidvanias.

18504300.review:
This is a really awesome metroidvania beat-em-up indie title with really smooth controls and great gameplay. As a big fan of the genre, this game doesn't dissapoint in the slightest, with plenty of power-ups and interesting mechanics added to the game. What's the best part of the game though, for me, is hands down the platforming. It's innovative, and uses mechanics I haven't seen been used in metroidvanias all that often, so it's a nice breath of fresh air from what Nintendo has given us over the years. The combat system is fairly interesting as well, being a beat-em-up like game with a suprising amount of depth to it, which I approve of. The Keyboard controls work just fine, but if you have a controller, it's best played with one, although I made it through 90% of the game with just the keyboard, so if you don't have one, don't sweat it.

The Super Turbo Championship edition expands on the already great base game with a co-op feature which I wish more games in this genre took advantage of. Sadly, it's local multiplayer, meaning that controllers are a must-have for it, but on the upside, you can play with four people all at once, which is nice. The added areas and bosses are interesting as well, giving you veterans out there something new to mess around with. A fair warning though, this game is hard. Both in platforming and combat, but it almost never feels cheap and unpolished (Although, it's not a game without it's blemishes.) It's a blast to play and the soundtrack is something I can't get enough of, with Canal De Las Flores being my favorite track in the game, which was added STCE. The Addition of Intensio is also a really cool feature, something I wish was a part of the main game, instead of being added on as an afterthought, but eh, I can't complain too much, it's a neat mechanic, although a bit cliché for action games nowadays. It's more centered around combat and platforming challenges rather than exploration, but there's still a fair amount of things to be found here for everyone to like.

Needless to say, I warmly recommend this game to anyone, and I'm hoping Drinkbox Studios makes more Metroidvanias in the future, as from what I've seen, they have a knack for it. Keep up the good work, guys. It's a really cool game you've made here. Well done.

18351743.review:
An indie game at its finest.

I bought Super Turbo Championship Edition even though I already had the original Guacamelee! and to be honest I didn't even notice any significant difference gameplay-wise. There's been quite a time gap between I played both version, so I was unable to notice anything. But, bro - we're on Steam so I ain't even mad as I got both for pennies.

The theme grabs handfulls from Mexican folklore and is decorating it with lots of humor, which makes the game fun for everyone. Graphics are nice, colourfull, swift and slick with smooth animation.  A cool mexican-themed soundtrack is playing in the background and I discovered it is ear-catchy enough, that developers decided to release the soundtrack separately (available on Steam).

Doesn't matter what version you're playing - Gold or STCE, it's a very solid game. I believe "metroidvania" is a popular term to use on such titles as it is 2D platformer with lots of backtracking, as you will be unable to reach some areas until you'll get powers requied to do so.

I am hardened PC player, but let's be honest - keyboard is a device designed for typing, not for gaming. It's been a long time since I ever attempted to play a game using keyboard instead of my X360 controller. And I'm happy to have one, because - oh, boy - I can't even imagine playing Guacamelee! with a keyboard without breaking a finger. This platformer requies a lot from your reflexes and thank god the controls are tight and well responding.

When you start the game fights are just simple button mashing and platforming is not a big deal. But of course as you progress you get new abilities like double jump, wall-jump, etc., you learn new attacks and also you get to switch between dimensions. So, Guacamelee! is not inventive platforming wise, but isn't it fun if the game is so well made? And it is actually one of the rare games, where all your abilities are not just useful, but they are mandatory to master, so you'll be able to use them in-game. You will have to train your fingers to respond quickly. Simple button mashing to fight enemies at the beginning quickly won't be any effective as you will encounter a lot of enemies that will require certain tactics to down them. As there may be a lot of enemies onscreen sometimes I never felt the fights are chaotic. They just require quick eye-to-finger response as they are challenging, but thanks to the wise use of colour palette it comes with ease to get used to some tactics. (Unless you are using a keyboard).

And mind, that your abilities are useful not only for battling the enemies, but also during platforming. There will be a lot of trial and error, especially when you'll attempt to get some hard to reach collectible.

Sometimes I really missed good old days, when side-scrolling platformers were real deal. It was actually a while since indie game developers could get to the level that was available last time on SNES (I'm not counting Gameboy). Because there's actually plenty of games in that category, but very few of them are good and even less of them are great. Thanks to Steam, we can play a lot of them on PC, as Guacamelee! was previously available only for the consoles. Guacamelee! may not be great. As I said, it is not very inventive. But there is something fresh about it and it is so damn well made, that it's just plain fun. Of course it's a modern game, so it's more forgiving than the SNES era - there are save points and lifes are unlimited. Which I consider a good thing, since the era of memorizing the whole levels is long gone, so it will keep you away from frustration. 

It is helluva fan, folks.

8/10

18191382.review:
Two words: Great game. 

That alone should be enough for any gamer to at least consider playing it. But Guacamelee is so much more than that.

Nowadays platforming games are scarce, a sad thing to say but true nonetheless. Guacamelee comes in that front as a refreshingly exciting new adventure where jumping is as important as fighting. 

At the beginning you won't be able to do much, simple button combinations are all you've got to beat the early enemies, but you learn more moves the further you advance in the game. Those moves are both fighting and platforming oriented and you need to use them constatly if you want to progress.

To make things easier, you can buy diffferent perks in the store in exchange for money you get from defeating enemies, crate smashing or treasure hunting. You can also buy different skins for your character, both male and female, that will
give you useful bonuses in exchange for silver coins that you get in some particular chests and once you beat an arena.

The dfficulty curve in this game is outstandingly well done.  Forcing you to give your best in combat and platforming as well. Guacamelee's got one of the most frustratng platforming track you'll ever get to play (yes I'm referring to the saw blades) but it also's got some of the most entertaining challenge fights you'll enjoy (in hell).

Although the theme of the game might not interest you, I can assure you that it doesn't become an annoyance. In fact you're gonna be so into the game that you're hardly gonna notice it. And after a while you may even start to like it as much as I did.

As for the queer design of the ingame drawing I can only say that it fits perfectly with the story and after the first fights is not going to bother you either.

It is precisely in the story where Guacamelee turns weakest. The overall plot is average at best but you're going to be so entertained with everything else that, honestly, you're not going to care.

Lastly, I'd like to say something about reaching 100% in the game, Most of the trophies are quite easy to get, but there are some that are not. Getting the gold medal in the challenges or finding all the treasure chests is going to take time. Getting the "good" ending is demanding too, you'll have to find all 7 parts of the mask and thet will require something else. In order to succeed though, the developers added two additional powers you can get. The first one you obtain in hell and the second one gets automatically unlocked once you find 6 parts of the mask. The latter is, by far, the most overpowered ability you get in the game but frankly, by the moment you get it, is kind of useless. It would have been nice to have these two abilities available in the new game from the beginning, or at least one of them, but the developers didn't see it that way. So you don't.

In short, Guacamelee is an absolutely worthy game to play that isn't too harsh, unless you want it to be, and will surely entertain you. Don't forget to purchase it if you liked it!

18060838.review:
太太太好玩的遊戲了
這是我在steam上玩過的平台遊戲中，最棒最好玩的一款了。
畫風與音樂非常有中南美拉丁風味
色彩艷麗音樂熱情，畫風劇情幽默可愛
風格是我個人非常喜歡的類型

遊戲操控非常的流暢 (建議使用搖桿)
combo很容易上手，行雲流水爽感十足。
學到的招式除了用在攻擊，也是在地圖中行進突破障礙的工具。

道具上有增強能力的道具，也有裝備: 遊戲中的裝備就是服裝，例如你可穿上雞裝，每種服裝有不同的屬性。

遊戲世界是由生跟死的兩個世界重疊組成。
必須要透過兩者之間的切換，才能不斷推進劇情闖關。
除了主線任務，也有一些支線任務。
遊戲的地圖雖然沒有很大，但是每個區域都有許多地方，需要你擁有不同的能力後才能進得去。
所以每學到一些新技巧，可以回到那些區域繼續挖掘新的秘密。遊戲中每個區域有傳輸點，所以你可以遠距傳輸節省時間。

遊戲的重生點設計，是非常佛心慈悲的設計，死掉後基本上幾乎等於就地重生，所以不會有死掉後又要重頭開始的情形。

招式、地圖設計與主線劇情間的配合，感覺的到作者們花了很大的心思去安排，
安排的非常有次第，讓人不知不覺中，循序地擴展整個故事、技巧、難度。

風格、音樂、操控、劇情、節奏、地圖的整提組合，實在是太棒了~~~ 以後若玩不到這樣的遊戲怎麼辦呢~~~~

17718375.review:
If you've ever wondered what Metroid would look like if you were a shirt-less man in an environment that isn't sci-fi inspired than Guacamelee might be for you.

Guacamelee captures all of the elements that one would expect to find in a game branded as 'Metroid-vania'. There is backtracking for hidden goodies, the environments are expansive, and progressing through the game greatly enhances your ability to explore the environment. Guacamelee also has fluid combat that feels good to use. The combo based combat system doesn't feel jagged or restricting, rather it allows you to smoothly flow as you execute combos. This makes fighting an enjoyable experience. The game also has a very vibrant art style and a great score.

All of that said, if you like Metroid or Castlevania (the 2D ones) you will probably enjoy this game.

Absolutely amazing game.  I got through the entire game in one playthrough.  For those of you familiar with Super Metroid on the SNES, this is pretty much like a love letter to the game.  The influence of that game on this one can be seen all the way from the abilities you earn from statues to the similarities in some of the platforming mechanics in how you use those abilities.  The only issue with the game is that it is fairly short.  However, the replay value is quite high as the fighting mechanics are simple to learn, but provide a high degree of complexity, making the game so much fun.

If you're a fan of Super Metroid, I wouldn't even think twice about purchasing this game.  It's well worth at least $20 if for nothing more than that nostalgic classic Super Metroid experience.

17451042.review:
¡Viva el Guacamelee!!

A los pocos minutos de comenzar a jugar, Guacamelee! se convirtió en uno de mis plataformers favoritos.

Tiene diversas mecánicas de lucha y movimiento típicas de juegos de plataforma, pero innova con la habilidad de cambiar del mundo de los vivos al de los muertos. Esta habilidad literalmente duplica el mundo a explorar y genera interesantes situaciones para el jugador. Además, cada nivel es interesante y posee una cantidad enorme de secretos y puzzles. Algunos son pruebas de ingenio, otros de destreza, y otros ejercicios de voluntad para quienes no tienen problema en intentar un nivel más de 100 veces. En definitiva: ofrece desafíos para todos los gustos. El gameplay es realmente muy complejo, pero se enseña paulatinamente a lo largo de todo el juego, entrenando al jugador hasta convertirlo en un experto y sin perder el tiempo en tutoriales.

La estética y la música son hermosas y el escenario es un gran homenaje a la cultura Mexicana. La historia es simple pero interesante, repleta de personajes divertidos y con un buen sentido del humor. Además, no deja de rendir culto a los mejores juegos del género, colocando montones de guiños para los entendidos. La ambientación está perfectamente ejecutada y cuida hasta el más mínimo detalle. Como latinoamericano, estuve particularmente atento a ver dónde se equivocaban con las referencias culturales, y me alegra no haber encontrado nada fuera de lugar.

Lo único negativo es el gameplay multiplayer, que no es malo, pero por momentos puede ser confuso. Cuantos más jugadores, más confusión. De todos modos, es perfectamente jugable de a dos e incluso las desventajas del gameplay pueden ser utiles para superar algunos puzzles y niveles particularmente difíciles.

En definitiva, Guacamelee! es todo lo que el nombre promete: Mexico + Plataformer de Combate + un enorme signo de exclamasión que implica (correctamente) que hay muchísimo más en este juego. ¡Totalmente recomendable!

游戏的故事剧情是老套的拯救公主类 总有闲着没事干的魔王绑架公主然后也不知道为了啥的就去毁灭一下世界 不过本里真正的魔王被变成了一只[b]鸡[/b] 真BOSS另有他人

本作的细节和彩蛋设定真的是十分到位 帮女孩找到玩偶后 可以看见死之世界里小女孩一直抱着玩偶 完成老奶奶美味的事物后 餐馆门口的食客也排起了长队 让人佩服制作组的用心 游戏完成度之高

17152601.review:
Es un buen juego, se caracteriza mayormente por las plataformas, puzzles y un poco de hack and slash, los graficos en 2D están muy bien logrados se ve bastante bien y es atractivo a la vista. En cuanto a la temática del juego es algo bastante inusual porque toma aspectos de la cultura mexicana y expresiones muy comunes de ese país lo cual para los latinoamericanos se nos hace muy familiar también.

La historia aunque es muy interesante por como se desarrolla es un tanto cliché por el hecho de tener que rescatar a la mujer de la cual el protagonista está enamorado(mario bross), pero eso es algo que el juego hace a propósito porque posee demasiadas referencias a otros títulos tanto retro como no tan viejos, el avance de la historia es fácil de comprender no posee una profundidad o reflexión muy alta sino que se preocupa más en cómo sortear los distintos niveles que se presentan.

En cuanto al gameplay es muy adictivo y entretenido, se nota que es en lo que más se enfocaron los desarrolladores, presenta retos bastante complejos y se puede decir que el juego también entra dentro de una categoría metroidvania ya que habrán zonas que no se pueden acceder hasta conseguir nuevos poderes o explorando todo el mapa.

Las habilidades que adquiere el personaje son muy interesantes tanto pra el combate como para avanzar en el mapa, éstas ayudan mucho cuando se debe pelear contra un número elevado de enemigos y cuando se presentan situaciones apremiantes, el juego posee una "tienda" donde se pueden comprar partes de salud, "magia" y aumento de poderes con dinero que se gana matando enemigos.

En sí para ser un juego indie está muy completo y bien trabajado, a mí me duró casi 8 horas explorando bastante y avanzando sin mucha prisa, lo recomiendo bastante tanto por el precio y todo lo que ofrece, si lo ven en una barata o rebaja no lo piensen dos veces y comprenlo.

Si le scénario se veut classique, la réalisation est irréprochable avec une difficulté bien dosée et une jouabilité sans faille. Le gros point fort de Guacamelee est son ambiance, on navigue dans les bons gros clichés, dans des décors sublimes et archi-colorés et sur une bande-son à tomber, un véritable voyage dépaysant au pays du WTF. This is a really enjoyable platformer. It is witty, funny, gorgeous, and feels great to play even on a keyboard (a bit of training required, and lots of missed keys).

The controls are smooth and the combos are neatly chained and impactful.

My only qualm is that the skins are tied to power-ups and disadvantages. Sometimes I just wanted to enjoy some look but its bonuses aren't as good or my playstyle as other skins, so I just used Diablo and the monster one, mainly.

Played 2 games, normal and hard:
1st playthrough, about 10 hours, 100% completion;
2nd playthrough, hard mode, about 4 hours, rushed. I really wish hard was available from the beginning, it added some needed challenge. I played a second time mainly for the achievement, but I would've enjoyed the game a lot more in one full hard mode playthrough.
100% achievements (second run in hard-mode required).

16826769.review:
No mames, está cabrón!

ÁNDALE!!!! PERO SI ES GUACAMELEE! la súper mezcla explosiva con todo lo bueno de los juegos de la vieja escuela:
Guacamelee! es Castlevania y Megaman con su acción sin descanso contra miles de enemigos.
Guacamelee! tiene alma de Metroid, por el diseño de sus niveles tan variado y puzles tan bien elaborados.
Guacamelee! posee la jugabilidad de Súper Mario Bros por sus buenísimas plataformas y carreras sin fin por todo el mapeado.
Guacamelee! además te recordará a "The legend of Zelda" por sus templos, corazones, mundo de las sombras y aventuras laterales.
Guacamelee! tiene el control sencillo e impecable de Súper Smash Bros en sus combos de combates cuerpo a cuerpo.

Todo el juego está hecho con la mejor receta Mexicana (y lleno de pollos), con muchísimo humor gracias a sus parodias referidas a los grandes juegos de todos los tiempos. (¿Qué hace aquí Manny Calavera de Grim Fandango?). No nos olvidemos de su soundtrack que es soberbia pues está compuesta por una larga lista de temas pegadizos que no pararás de escuchar.
Y si todo es bueno, puede ser mucho mejor porque se puede jugar comiendo nachos con 4 players a la vez desde un mismo PC. El juego es la polla (que pone huevos), mola más que la sal, el limón y el tequila! qué onda!

Lo mejor: música, acción, plataformas, mapeado, secretos, exploración, su lado cómico, su duración. No se le puede pedir más a la virgencita del santo chili !
Lo peor: a simple vista en un video o en una captura de pantalla puede que el juego no resulte atractivo, pero una vez que lo pruebas te preguntarás... "pinche huevón ¿por qué no lo jugué antes?"

16774326.review:
A fun platformer. You play as Juan an agave farmer made luchador thanks to a legendary luchador mask. He goes on an adventure to save his childhood love, the El Presidente's Daughter, from the evil Carlos Calaca. Yea it a strange story, but hey what are video games for if you can't have a strange story from time to time. The story is really entertaining and the game is constantly making references to other games. It help set up a fun atmosphere.

The game play like your standard 2D platformer, but what set it apart levels have 2 designs, a living and dead. Playing as Juan you'll find yourself having to switch between the land of the living and dead to get through areas and find their secrets. You'll also have to use you're wrestling abilities as you learn them to help you progress through the game. 

The combat involve punching your enemies enough to get them vunerable enough to throw them into other enemies or into environmental hazard. As you learn new abilities, enemies will start to spawn with barriers that can only be broken by using that ability. As you go through the game, you will encounter newer enemies that will put your new powers to the test. 

Honestly this is a fun game that knows how silly it is and it take pleasure in it. If you like luchadores, goats, chickens, skeletons, challenging platforming, and a fun "save the princess" story then this is the game for you.

16566570.review:
Pros:
-You're a Luchador
-Easter Eggs... tons of Easter Eggs
-Easy to understand mechanics
-Story isn't too deep, very linear and a wee bit predictable, but you will get immersed (well I did) and you will still get some feels.
-You're a fucking Luchador!

Cons:
-Unforgiving, like a good old 80-90's game: a few (or one) false move can destroy you or impede your progress - luckily this is still a modern day game, so they threw you a bone: infinite lives - when you die: you respawn at a checkpoint, your progress beyond the checkpoint is lost, but that's it. no "X4 lives left". -whew.
-Uncomfortable key mappings (this is for gamepad) that cannot be changed. Paired with the former cons, this makes the game more frustrating than it should.

9/10; not giving 'em a 10 not untill they fix the controller problem.

16234999.review:
If you are new to Guacamelee! in general, look further down for a general review. Following is a comparison of versions.

When I first saw this, I thought it was a moneygrab. It is absolutely not. The Super Turbo Championchip Edition improves so much on Gold Edition that they are almost incomperable. The most notable additions are:
- The chicken bomb
- Rebalancing of the enemies in just about every area and stat rebalancing of enemies
- The fighting system got rebuffed and everything feels much, much smoother
- A new 'super' type mode you can initiate after doing lots of combos
- New story additions and a new boss
All in all, the game feels much fuller.

Now for a general review of Guacamelee!
Guacamelee! is a metroidvania that really knows how to mix its genres. While the basic mechanics of platforming and fighting are both there, the fighting has a good amount of depth to it without becoming overly complex. After playing for a while, combos seemlessly stream out into an arena of destruction... and it feels really good. In Guacamelee! I can punch and upper cut an enemy into the air, headbut them, body slam them, and then grab them to suplex them into the ground to knock other enemies off balance only to start another combo. And it doesn't require dozens of hours to learn. On top of the fighting system, there are many, many upgrades to find and buy. Search a large world for upgrades, find the good ending, complete some challenges, unlock some sweet costumes, turn into a chicken! Okay, that last one was a little different than the rest, but you get the idea.

TL;DR
Guacamelee! STCE is the best edition. The game is a metroidvania with more depth to fighting. Lots of upgrades. Chickens. Worth every penny.

16138670.review:
Sidescrolling beat 'em up/platformer with Metroid style exploration. The game has a unique Mexican theme, with you playing as a Luchador Mexican wrestler dude, on a mission to rescue 'El Presidentes' daughter from skeletons, a guy with his head permenantly on fire and several other bad guys. The game doesn't take itself seriously and has a pretty funny story and set of characters.

The combat and exploration of this game is where it really shines though. If you know 2D Metroid or Castlevania, and even Dark Souls to an extent (with the shortcuts and linking world), its just like that in its exploration and level design. The combat is awesome, you can chain different style of attacks and throws together and its a lot of fun making huge combos, which happens often as the game regularly throws tonnes of enemies at you. I was really surprised how much I enjoyed the combat.

The game also has a really good looking and clean unique art style, that thankfully steps away from the common "pixelate everything" art style most indie games use. Animation is also pretty nice and feels responsive as fuck.

Overall I definitely recommend!

16091512.review:
I just finished this game on co-op and I gotta say it's some of the most fun I've had in a long time. It took us about 7 hours to beat even with the two of us. You pretty much play as a super-hero luchador in a beat-em-up style game trying to save your princess. There is tons of secrets, in which you don't unlock the 'true ending' unless you find them all. You can also unlock different costumes which gives you different benefits and you can upgrade your skills. I played most of the game with the Diablo suit which kind of made it like hard mode even on easy.

I gotta say this game really did remind me of the old-school games and some of the music even sounded alot like Mario and other games. Enemies were decently hard to beat without being too difficult, but keep in mind I did have another player helping me. Storyline is decent and there is tons of humor in the game also. It's kinda like they took everything people love about indie games and put it into this game.

Co-op design is fairly decent but the camera kinda sucks as it will only follow player one instead of expanding. Every time you die you have a timer to wait to come back and when you do you're a little orb that floats around until your teammate releases you. I felt this made the co-op fair without being too much struggle. Pretty much a fun co-op experience that adds mild difficulty to great teamwork gameplay. Coordinating certain platforming can be incredibly hectic though and we usually just let one person do all the platforming at the hard parts because it was too hard with two people to do.

Co-op is also somewhat buggy... I have a screenshot where instead of dying, me and my buddy just have 3 copies of ourselves each...

I will probably replay the hell out of this game until I unlock all of the achievements. I can't really say too much bad about the game in all honestly so I would have to give the game somewhere around a 4.5/5.

16089449.review: This game has fantastic artwork, fluid gameplay, and a lot of fun little bits and pieces that reference gaming history or culture or whatever you want to call it. The writing is well done, and I'm going to praise the artwork for a second time. Great game for fans of metroidvania!

16059626.review:
[h1]「 Sorry Luchador, but your princess is in another castle. 」[/h1]

HELL YES. I absolutely love this game. It really was just so much fun to play. The style, the music, the puzzles, the combat, I dig it. So much. 

[h1]C-c-c-combo breaker (!!)[/h1]

So Guacamelee is an action platformer. The level designs are really cool, in the smart platform design sense and in the 'aw yeah this place looks bangin' sense. The levels weren't exactly hard (I don't know if this or just the combat changes in hard mode though), but mixed with the combat, it was fast-paced, kept you on your toes, utilized all your powers, and generally makes you feel awesome while playing. 

But aside from the actual platforming aspect, I think the combat is where it's at. I don't know much about pro-wrestlers, but I sure as hell felt like one. Every so often, you get a new power, and you incorporate those new powers into progressing through the levels and for creating some new killer combos. When you get all the new powers, you pretty much feel like a god. At least I felt that way. Was nice. Very nice. Punch enemy into air, follow them, 1-2-3 combo, slap them back down, follow with a body slam, pick them back up, throw them to the left, roll to the left, HEAD BASH THEM INTO OBLIVION. Yes I love the combat and one day I hope to become the master of all the Guacamelee combos and to make the Combo Chicken proud of me.

[h1]We are Sex Bob-omb (!!)[/h1]

Simply put, the music is amazing. I actually found myself shaking my body to the music while practicing my pro-wrestling ways. I don't know how to really describe it, but the music really added that extra 'unf'. Especially the boss theme. I totally would have welcome any 3rd/4th/5th boss phases if it meant I could listen to this music and kick ass at the same time. 

[h1]Eye Candy (!!)[/h1]

When I look at the graphics, the word that comes to mind is charming. Also beautiful and simple. And crisp for some reason. I think besides that, I'm just becoming a fan of this style of art, something that I also see in works like The Book of Life (movie) and Grim Fandango. 

Not much else to say other than this game was just as much a pleasure to look at as it was to fulfill my unknown pro-wrestler dreams.

[h1](Chorus)(Outro)(Fade-out)[/h1]

So yeah. Sweet game. I look forward to starting hard mode (re-re-replayability !!!) one of these days when my backlog isn't clawing at me. 

Guacamelee doesn't take itself too seriously which allows for some really funny moments. Also, references. References everywhere. All in all, I had a blast playing it and -looks straight into the camera with a generic smile and gives a thumbs up- you will too! Did I mention you can transform into a chicken at will.

15684945.review:
[h1] Pueblucho si arricchisce di 2 aree nuove, di un'ottima boss fight e di un combat system ancora più vario.
E' ancora teatrale, con un level design eccezionale, nella sua doppia anima frizzante e malinconica. [/h1]

Ho giocato principalmente alla versione gold edition; questa è una revisione completa dei contenuti aggiuntivi. Ci regala qualche ora e qualche colorato abito in più, per il resto vale quanto già lodato nella versione precedente.

Molto colorato, con una doppia anima artistica molto ispirata; DrinkBox ci regala un doppio mondo di gioco in rapida evoluzione con un crescendo di abilità, umorismo e zone da scoprire condito da un sano backtracking.
Raramente si riesce ad avere in un solo prodotto 1 storia narrata in maniera interessante, un combat system profondo, un level design eccezionale in grado di esaltare un gameplay a tratti sorprendentemente tecnico e un ritmo crescente così ben curati.

Un intrecciato mondo da scoprire grazie ad una maschera; un inno a titoli ricchi di atmosfera e magia come Super Mario e Metroid, le cui statue di Choozo richiamano chiaramente l'antica razza aliena dal volto rapace dei Chozo di Zebes, che creò i Metroid.

L'aggiunta della co-op locale è una funzione gradita e troppo spesso dimenticata in produzioni moderne; se avete un/a complice con cui condividere lo schermo troverete questa opzione molto soddisfacente...se sarete affiatati! Si perchè in alcune zone la sincronizzazione dei movimenti tra i 2 mondi e tra i 2 giocatori sarà fondamentale per proseguire il livello.

Un saggio-capra vi guiderà dunque in questa telenovela in salsa messicana, in cui dovremo ovviamente salvare la principessa dal cattivone di turno oltre a tramutarci di tanto in tanto in pollo...ma la banalità non fa parte di Pueblucho, qui dimorano citazioni, modi di dire, tabelloni magistralmente dipinti con la passione tipicamente latina.

Ottimo il doppiaggio e il comparto tecnico con comandi sempre precisi in grado di approfondire le meccaniche senza lag. Semplicemente sorprendente il sonoro, con una tracklist travolgente in piena anima messicana.

Se non ci fossero stati livelli a volte troppo sbilanciati con alcuni enigmi mal calibrati saremmo di fronte ad un titolo quasi perfetto. Qualcuno lo eleverà a capolavoro, di sicuro è un indie di grande personalità che non ha paura di essere confrontato con le produzioni tripla A.

15345713.review:
When put in comparison to the Gold Edition, you would expect this game to be better. It is... but at the same time it's not. It features more content, but half the achievements are gone, and what is added isn't really that much of a difference in the first place,and could've simply been a DLC.

That being said, the visuals are really something to be seen, the soundtrack is good (and even more so when you notice the small differences when you swap worlds), the gameplay is tight, and it feels consistent... Until the bright colors get old fast, and the game will play a cheap trick and force you to play the game again to get a single achievement because it doesn't let you choose hard mode from the get go.

Speaking of the hard mode, the only real difference I felt was in X'tabay and Javier Jaguar fights. And boy, let me tell you , Javier was NOT ballanced at all. His dodging feels like the game is cheating you and the white barrier is absolutely cheap, when it regenerates and he will just dodge and swap worlds, or use his aura to blast you away.

With all that said, the game is still recommended. I just had a few bones to pick with it. It's not THAT hard, but something might not be enjoyable if you're trying to look for a game to complete. However, yes, this is a game that must be played.

Worth playing even if not a big fan of platformers or indie games, cant wait for a sequel or more games made by these devs.

This is going to be my first negative review, and i feel so bad for giving a thumbs down for a gorgeous game like " Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition ".

I was looking for so much in this game, but i guess looks can be decieving.

But the game itself, is so so slow, it takes a while for you to be able to do anything, it also takes a while for you to progress in the story, and will take even more time for you to understand where you're supposed to go.

Guacamelee is one of the best platformers I played lately. 
Is the first game that my girlfriend also enjoyed playing so we get to play it co-op(probably because she can pick the female character and she also gets to dress her). 
- also, it can be played up to 4 players co-op(which probably is too much for 1 screen)

I have to say it's far more complex and has a lot more content than what I thought when I got it: you can change dimensions, transform in a chicken(to fit through narrow places) and you have enough skills to play around with. Also you can buy upgrades or new costumes that each has benefits and drawbacks.

What I like:
- the graphics
- storyline is funny
- lot of content(10h+ of gameplay(played some offline) and it seems we're only halfway)
- some rounds require a little "puzzle solving"
- various enemies and also boss levels are cool
- you can become a chicken

What I don't like:
- Some levels require maybe too much button mashing, and you have to retry lots of times until you get it perfect
- When playing local co-op, the screen follows player one(which seems normal) but lots of times even if player2 manages to cross some intricate button mashing section it will be returned back to player1's location. While if player1 succesfully passes an area, player2 will be again automatically teleported to player1 so he doesn't have to do it also. So lots of times the levels that require perfect combos to pass them are only dependend on player1(if he passes, all pass. If he doesn't noone pass)

I bought Guacamelee! originally for the PS3. I also bought the soundtrack and all DLC as soon as it became available. You better believe I bought this and the soundtrack the first chance I had.

Guacamelee! embodies the ingenuity, creativity, and efforts of many indie game companies striving to take the game industry out of an era of abundant brown military shooters, mmorpgs, and other quick cashgrab schemes. The environment vividly portrays Mexican culture along with references to many other games, movies, and memes without being too heavyhanded with it. The combat and platforming are quick and easy to learn but show a level of depth some games can only dream of achieving. Collectibles and challenges will have you running back and forth to grow stronger and complete areas 100%. 

If you're a fan of Metroidvania games, platformers, or just any good game you owe it to yourself to at least try Guacamelee!. I promise that $15 will be well worth the investment.

An absolute platforming blast. Gold edition was fantastic and even if you have beaten it I still would reccomend super turbo championship edition. It just tightens everything up; expands the story, allows for 4-person local co-op, adds egg bombs... it's just so much fun to play, especially with friends. This game has actual skill requirements for its platforming puzzles and that is where the only flaw I can imagine for this game comes from (though completely avoidable in this version with moderate skill): co-operative platforming often results in getting in eachother's way.

In gold edition everybody was locked to the same phase as eachother meaning that platform puzzles that involved phase swaps got complicated, nigh impossible, fast. IN this one everybody can control their phase independantly, which makes it completely plausible, just confusing. When we played through we usually dropped to one player for difficult puzzles to keep camera in the best location.

Overall I loved this game, my absolute favourite platformer thus far.

14075755.review:
A polished action 2d platformer.

This game is an 'upgrade' of previously released Guacamelee Gold Edition.

Looks simple, but when you play it - it's a bit complicated since it requires a bit of learning mostly for combos and memorizing the pattern of enemies' shields in order to break it. Chaining combos also feels smooth in battle, if you master it literally you'll stomp on enemies. 

There's a regular platformer features like Double Jump, Air Combo, but what's best from this game is that the game cleverly incorporates it but sometimes it's irritating and requiring you to replay a part of the level again and again because it requires precise movement and fast fingers. I also like the swapping dimension between living and the dead, required when you progress through the game - quickly reminds me to Giana Sisters Twisted Dream and to some extent, Soul Reaver. 

Game graphic overall I'm satisfied, it has unique feel for me. Certainly not pixel level. Performance wise, I play no problem on my mediocre 635m with highest quality settings available for me, no screen tearing, no sudden FPS drops.

Game's a platformer, and so as it stands it's best played with controller. While combos are easy to perform (only directional button + action button each), I'm not sure how fast my fingers would be had I played this with KB/M especially when you're required to be fast finger during a fight or moving thru a tricky level.

As for replayability, when you finish the game you're given hard level to beat. And achievements adding more appeal to come back and obtain. But for one simple playthrough, game's a bit short - I'm clocking at 6.5 hours or so for my first.

There's a leaderboard supposedly for bragging, but how someone beats the game less than 30 minutes baffles me to no end. I checked around and found it requires tricks, well.... not so good in my opinion.

Verdict, good game, but if you own previous title you'll be sorely disappointed that there's no loyalty discount anymore. I'd wait for a sale or bundle since the improvements are not worth 15 extra USDs alone.

超级棒的游戏。音乐与场景洋溢着浓浓的墨西哥风情，一看就知道制作团队化了大力气。在这略带魔幻的世界中展开冒险，绝对是一件振奋人心的事情。游戏的战斗系统我非常喜欢，简约而不简单的操作真正是为玩家而贴心设计的，一拳一脚都畅快淋漓。众多的收集要素需要仔细地探索才能完成。总而言之，这款游戏简直就是一件华美的艺术品，值得收藏！
还有一点，昨天玩的时候出现一个小bug，当打破酒桶时，如果钱在追踪你的时候你恰巧进入别的场景中，会出现卡场景的情况，人已经到了别的场景中而画面仍停留在上一场景中，不过这个bug可以通过重新读档解决，无伤大雅啦。

13516243.review:
Within a few days, Guacamelee went from a cool demo I played for a few minutes to one of my favorite games of all time that I was putting hours into every night.

How I got to that point is simple: its FANTASTIC. A beat-em-up/platformer/metroidvania/whatever sounds like a lot but it doesnt feel like much in-game, where you can do pretty much whatever you want most of the time. You can explore, you can beat things into a pulp, you can throw a bunch of chickens into a wall--you can even BE a chicken! The learning curve builds up perfectly from familiar platforming and simple combos to nearly DMC-level battles and quite literally the single-hardest platforming section I have ever seen (and beaten). And do I even need to mention how beautiful the backgrounds and level design is?? It forced me to stop playing and just stare on some occasions. My screencap folder for this game is INSANE.

I have not played the Gold edition at all but if you're new to Guac like I was, this is the version I would recommend, hands down. If you're looking to upgrade from Gold, I'd still say go for it because I love it that much. I do know one of the new areas in this version is one of the largest in the game and gives a nice twist to the plot that I enjoyed, but that's something that either matters to you or not. I would especially sugest getting the soundtrack bundle of either version (I regret not getting it myself) simply because its amazing in the way it conbines the sounds of a retro sidescroller with traditional Mexican music.

The co-op is another thing I've yet to try, especially since 4-player is exclusive to this version, but everything I've seen of 2-player looked good. It definitely makes arenas easier, but I wouldn't do any especially challenging platforming on anything but single player. That stuff is hard enough to do alone sometimes, let alone trying to catch up when your partner is ahead. But if you just wanna screw with your friends, then go right ahead.

Some rumblings I've heard involve people saying the use of Mexican folklore here is racist, and as a Mexican with personal ties to that folklore, I heartily disagree. Yeah, its weird that a Canadian studio made an essentially Mexican game. But personally? It's not near the worst I've seen in terms of using sterotypes. And the accuracy and respect present in the style and lore of this game more than make up for that kind of stuff. It seriously feels like a love letter to a part of my culture that I hardly ever get to see in ANY media, let alone games, and we need more of it. I need to be able to walk up to another NPC singing "Cielito Lindo" at the top of their lungs for no reason. 

I'm THISCLOSE to fully completing the game (damn El Infierno challenges) but I'd definitely say I've gotten my money's worth out of it and more. My first playthrough went a bit longer than the average because I wanted the happy ending and that involves basically another playthrough worth of work. If 14.99 isn't that cool to you, its been on sale a lot in the short time I've had it so just stick it on the wishlist and be a little patient. It'll be worth it :)

11/10 would buy a sequel immediately

13244354.review: Don't get me wrong, Guacamelee is a pretty looking platformer with great fighting. There is just one major flaw in it that almost kill the experience for me. The developers substitute actual difficulty with piling so many enemies in a tiny room to where you can't tell what's going on and you can't see your character. There is so much shit going on in this tiny room that you can't hit anyone. The reason for that is when an enemy hits you, you get stunned for a split second. That isn't a problem with reasonable, spaced out enemies, but since there are so many enemies another one hits in your stunned faze. Then another. Then another. Then another. The only way to finish these kinds of room is to get lucky and hope you can keep from getting hit even once. 13211429.review:
Guacamelee is brilliant; tremendous; fan-fucking-tastic. If you're any sort of a fan of 2D platformers, buy it. The game is a triumph and I will recommend it to anybody. But that's not what this review is about. This review is about which version to buy.

There is much hoo-hah in the reviews here pertaining to the inclusion of Intenso mode, and the concurrent rebalancing of difficulty. I've beaten the original game twice - once on normal, and another time on hard - and I honestly didn't notice much of a difference. There are a few more enemies in some sections, but nothing that gave me any serious grief. If you're skilled you won't even need to use Intenso mode, but some people struggled with the difficulty of the original game, so I don't begrudge its inclusion. Think of it as an alterable in-game difficulty setting and if you don't like using easy mode, well then you won't need to use Intenso.

The purported remixing of existing levels is also very slight - basically a few new chests have been added and some old ones relocated. It's a non-event.

Perhaps most worthless is the new power-up, the Pollo Bomb. Once you've obtained it, pressing B while in the form of a chicken will make you lay an egg that explodes after a second or so, delivering a ridiculously small amount of damage to nearby enemies. There is literally no situation in which a pollo bomb would be preferable to straight-up melee. It only really serves to break a few new types of barrier rocks, which typically lead to some of the 'remixed' sections.

If you're not going to be using the 4-player co-op, which I haven't tested, this really only leaves the two new areas as an incentive to buy the game. And they're good - nothing has been half-assed, and they don't feel like they've been shoe-horned in. They fit in seamlessly on narrative, geographic and aesthetic levels. They offer an extra hour or two of fun gameplay. But that's all they offer.

So ultimately, if you don't own any version of Guacamelee at all, buying this one is a no-brainer - it has the most content, and is the must customisable to your ability as a gamer. However, if you already own Gold, you need to ask yourself how much 2 hours of gameplay is worth to you, because that's the only thing of substance STCE offers over Gold. To market it as a completely separate game really does seem like a cash-grab, as I see no reason this couldn't have been sold as relatively inexpensive DLC.
